div2.p: Socrates reverenced the gods of the Athenian state, and introduced no new divinities.

div3.p: polla/kis e)qau/masa: with these words Isocrates begins his Panegyricus, and Theophrastus his Characteres.

ti/si pote: by what possible. The use of ti/s, poi=os, po/sos, pw=s, etc., makes the indirect question more vivid and forcible. G. 1012; H. 1011. So poi/w| pote/ in 2. For a similar intensive use of pote/ (Lat. tandem) with questions, cf. ti/ pote le/gei o( qeo/s Plato Apol. 21B, ti/pt' [ ti/ pote ] ei)lh/louqas Hom. A 202. Xenophon surely was not unacquainted with the contents of the judicial indictment against Socrates; but he regarded its grounds as wholly unsatisfactory, and wondered what arguments could have persuaded the judges to render such a verdict. At the time of the trial (399 B.C.), Xenophon was not in Athens, and could only have heard from others in regard to the speeches.

*)aqhnai/ous: here (as *)aqhnai=oi in 20) refers immediately to the judges. So, in addressing the court, w)= a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi was allowable, instead of w)= a)/ndres dikastai/, since every Athenian citizen over thirty years of age could become a judge. The actual number of judges sitting on each case was very large, usually 501, which must have made the court resemble somewhat a New England town meeting. In the popular jury court of the Heliaea, the term dikasth/s really is equivalent to ‘judge-juryman.’ (See Schömann, Antiq. of Greece, Eng. transl., i. 474 ff.; Gow, Companion to School Classics, p. 126.) Both here, however, and in 20, dikasth/s is purposely avoided, to indicate that the guilt of condemning Socrates affected the whole Athenian state.
e)/peisan, w(s ei)/h: in 20, e)pei/sqhsan with acc. and infinitive.
oi( graya/menoi: the accusers, viz. Meletus, Anytus, and Lycon (Introd. § 5).
th=| po/lei: dat. of relation or interest. G. 1172; H. 771. Cf. i.2.62, 63.
me/n: not followed by a correlative de/. A contrast is not expressed, though perhaps suggested. “How unfounded, however, the accusation was will appear hereafter.”

grafh/: the
term for a public indictment. See Gow, p. 127.
kat' au)tou=: without repetition of the art. (after grafh/), as often after a noun expressing action. Cf. h)=n ga\r e)f' e(no\s h( kata/basis e)k tou= xwri/ou An. v.2.6

ti\s: after toia/de, shows that the author is more concerned with the substance than with the exact words. The indictment is probably, however, quoted nearly verbatim. We find it somewhat differently given by Plato, Apol. 24B, where the two principal counts stand in the reverse order. There, too, an e)/xei de/ pws w(=de precedes.

ou(\s ... nomi/zwn: the rel. clause ou(\s ... nomi/zei has the force of an attrib. adjective. qeou/s is obj. of nomi/zwn, recognizing. For the circumstantial participle of means or manner, see G. 1563, 3; H. 969 a.
a)dikei= de\ kai/: the first a)dikei= was not followed by me/n, an omission which occurs chiefly when, as here, de\ kai/ follows. Cf. i.2.22; ii. 6. 23; An. iii.1.23

2-9. Socrates not only sacrificed to the gods, but also availed himself of divination, as is proved by his belief in the daimo/nion. But he thought that we should not question the gods on matters which human understanding is capable of ascertaining without divine aid.
2. prw=ton me\n ou)=n: “as to the first charge, then.” The de/ corresponding to me/n is at the beginning of chapter 2.
qu/wn: for the participle in indirect discourse with dh=los and fanero/s ei)mi, see G. 1589; H. 981.

oi)/koi: at home, i.e. in the au)lh/, the interior court of the dwelling, where stood the altar of *zeu\s *(erkei=os. See Seyffert, Dict. Class. Antiq. p. 704. For the accent of oi)/koi, see G. 113; H. 102 b.
tw=n koinw=n bwmw=n: these stood in the open spaces of the city, so that the worshipers were ‘seen of men.’
ou)k a)fanh/s: ‘litotes.’

dieteqru/lhto ga/r: for it was commonly reported (dia/ indicating the spread of the report) that Socrates believed in his daimo/nion, and hence in divination. The parenthetical sentences from o(/qen dh/ to ga\r e)/fh in 4 carry this thought farther.
daimo/nion: an adj. used as a noun, like to\ qei=on. Cf. divinum quiddam, quod daemonium appellat (Socrates) Cic. de Div. i. 54. See Introd. §27 ff.

o(/qen dh\ kai\ ma/lista:
for which very reason especially. Other utterances of Socrates were also used by his opponents as evidence that he introduced kaina\ daimo/nia. Cf. kathgo/roun au)tou=, w(s o(/ti kaina\ daimo/nia ei)sfe/rei toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, le/gwn dei=n se/bein o)/rnea kai\ ku/nas kai\ ta\ toiau=ta Isoc. xi (First Hypothesis), edit. Blass.
tw=n a)/llwn: gen. of the person, although the real comparison is between things. Cf. purami/da a)peli/peto pollo\n e)la/ssw tou= patro/s Hdt. ii. 134. See G. 1178; H. 773 b.

mantikh/n (i.e. th\n mantikh\n te/xnhn): divination in general, followed by the four varieties oi)wnoi=s, fh/mais, sumbo/lois, qusi/ais. In the case of birds, their flight and cries were observed (Lat. augurium); fh=mai were sayings of men; su/mbola (sumba/llw) were originally coincidences, or meetings of men, then, generally, natural phenomena, or other occurrences which may serve as omina; qusi/ais refers to the inspection of the viscera of victims sacrificed. Cf. Theophrastus peri\ deisidaimoni/as; Gardner and Jevons, Manual of Greek Antiq., p. 256 ff. For the dat. of means with xrw=ntai (lit. serve themselves by), see G. 1183; H. 777.
ou) tou\s o)/rniqas: not that the birds.
ta\ sumfe/ronta toi=s manteuome/nois: what is of advantage to the persons resorting to divination.
dia\ tou/twn: through these instrumentalities. The gen. is of means, as in e)/lege di) e(rmhne/ws, he spoke through an interpreter, An. ii.3.17 G. 1206, 1; H. 795, 1.
au)ta/: i.e. ta\ sumfe/ronta.
oi( plei=stoi: the great majority.
fasi/n: say, i.e. they so express themselves, and yet believe, like Socrates, that the omens come from the gods.

to\ daimo/nion shmai/nein: the thought is, that Socrates said that he obeyed his daimo/nion, and thus did not really differ from the others, who obeyed the gods while saying that they were following the signs. To him, the inner voice was a sign from the gods.

suno/ntwn: not maqhtw=n, since
Socrates did not have pupils, in the ordinary sense of the term; he did not teach for money, like the Sophists. Both Xenophon and Plato sedulously avoid the use of the term maqhtai/ for the followers of Socrates, employing, in its stead, suno/ntes, sunousiastai/, sundiatri/bontes, etc. Cf. i.2.3; i. 6.1; Plato Apol. 33A.

ta\ me\n poiei=n, ta\ de\ mh\ poiei=n: acc. to Plato (Apol. 31D; Theag. 128 D), the daimo/nion confined its activity to restraining, and did not encourage or urge on. The apparent difference between this statement and that of Xenophon may be explained by assuming that to Socrates the silence of the divine monitor implied assent and even encouragement. Cf. Plato Apol. 40A ff.

w(s proshmai/nontos: i.e. le/gwn to\ daimo/nion proshmai/nein. The gen. or acc. abs. of a participle with w(s or w(/sper assigns a reason on the part of the speaking or acting subject, without implying the truth or falsity of the statement expressed by the participle. Both cases (gen. and acc.) occur near each other in i. 6. 5. See G. 1574, 1593; H. 978.
toi=s peiqome/nois au)tw=|: those who followed his counsel.
mete/mele: translate as if personal, “had cause for regret.”
o(mologh/seien: for the potential opt., see G. 1327 ff; H. 872.
au)to/n: i.e. Socrates.
h)li/qion mh/t' a)lazo/na: a fool nor an impostor.

e)do/kei d' a)/n, ei) e)fai/neto: impf., instead of aor., denoting cond. unfulfilled in past time, the verbs expressing continued acts. So ou)k a)\n proe/legen, ei) mh\ e)pi/steuen just below. See GMT. 410; H. 895 a.
a)mfo/tera tau=ta: i.e. h)li/qios kai\ a)lazw/n. For the gender of the pred. adj., see H. 617. Cf. o(po/te (a)delfo\s) pa=n to\ e)nantiw/taton ei)/h ii. 3. 5.
w(s: see on 4.
yeudo/menos: for the supplementary participle, see G. 1588; H. 981.
tau=ta: in these matters.
pisteu/wn de/: equiv. to ei) e)pi/steue, cond. assumed as real, and itself a logical conclusion from the preceding sentence. For the circumstantial participle of cond., see G. 1563, 5; H. 969 d.
ou)k ei)=nai qeou\s e)no/mizen: this was the meaning of the charge quoted in 1, ou(\s me\n h( po/lis nomi/zei qeou\s ou) nomi/zwn.

a)lla\ mh/n: but further, marks a transition to a new phase of the
discussion. Xenophon makes frequent use of this phrase. Cf. i.1.10, iv. 5. 10.
e)pithdei/ous: another substitute for ‘disciples’ (maqhtai/). See on suno/ntwn in 4.
ga/r: after ta/de (in preceding clause) has an introductory force. Cf. e)k tw=nde ske/yai: ei) ga\r ktl. ii. 6. 38.
ta\ a)nagkai=a: the necessary duties of life, the result of which can be readily foreseen. Cf. ii.1.6, iv. 5. 9.
kai/ (before pra/ttein): here equiv. to ou(/tw. Cf. w(s de/ oi( tau=ta e)/doce, kai\ e)poi/ee Hdt. i. 79. In comparisons, kai/ often stands in both clauses. H. 1042. Cf. i.6.3.
w(s nomi/zoien: for the cond. rel. corresponding to past general cond., see G. 1431, 2; H. 914 B (2).
a)\n praxqh=nai: represents the potential opt. of direct discourse. G. 1522, 1328; H. 946.

a)dh/lwn (sc. o)/ntwn) o(/pws a)pobh/soito: “whose result was doubtful.” a)pobh/soito is fut. opt. (never used with a)/n) in indirect question. GMT. 129; H. 932, 2. The adv. o(/pws should not be confounded with the conj. o(/pws. See GMT. 376.

manteusome/nous pe/mpein: to send and consult the oracles. Xenophon himself received this advice from Socrates (An. iii.1.5). Cf. ei)/ge mh\n tau=ta do/ceien u(mi=n pra/ttein, sumbouleu/saim' a)\n e)/gwge pe/myantas kai\ ei)s *dwdw/nhn kai\ ei)s *delfou\s e)pere/sqai (to question) tou\s qeou/s Vect. vi. 2; Hdt. i. 46, 85. For the fut. participle of purpose, see G. 1563, 4; H. 969 c.
ei) poihte/a (sc. ei)/h): whether they should be done. For the verbal in -te/os, see G. 1595; H. 989: and for the opt. in indirect question, see on a)pobh/soito above.
kai/: introduces an illustration, “so, for example.” Cf. kai\ oi( moixoi/ ii. 1. 5.

tou\s me/llontas kalw=s oi)kh/sein: qui vellent bene administrare. Cf. eu)= oi)kou=si i. 2. 64, where the phrase is used in a pass. sense, “are well managed.” For the periphrastic fut. inf. (with me/llw), see G. 1254; H. 846.
oi)/kous te kai\ po/leis: “not only domestic, but also public affairs.”
prosdei=sqai: needed in addition to their human abilities and attainments.
me\n ga/r: for while, contrasted with ta\ de\ me/gista below.
tektoniko/n: for the formation and accent of denominative adjs. in -iko/s, see G. 851; H. 565.
tw=n toiou/twn e)/rgwn e)cetastiko/n: a competent critic of such works.
logistiko/n: lit. skilled in calculation, an accountant.
pa/nta ta\ toiau=ta: sums up the preceding items, their common inf. gene/sqai being understood with each.
maqh/mata: objects of study, pred. (like ai(reta/) to ta\ toiau=ta.
kai\ a)nqrw/pou gnw/mh| ai(reta/: and attainable by human understanding. For the verbal in -to/s, see G. 776, 2; H. 475.
ta\ de\ me/gista tw=n e)n tou/tois: “but the point of greatest importance in these matters” (lit. of the things in these), i.e. the result in each case.
katalei/pesqai: reserve.
ei)=nai: for the inf. by assimilation in indirect discourse, see G. 1524; H. 947.
kalw=s (in both clauses): well.
futeusame/nw|: for denominative verbs, see G. 861; H. 570 ff.

oi)ki/an oi)kodomhsame/nw|: the apparent redundancy of “housebuilding a house” is explained by the fact that oi)kodome/w (like Lat. aedificare) early lost its special meaning, and was used with tei=xos, ge/fura, nau=s, etc. Cf. oi)noxo/ei gluku\ ne/ktar Hom. A 598.

ei) a)nia/setai: after verbs or phrases expressing doubt or ignorance, ei) should be translated whether, or whether not, acc. to the necessities of the Eng. idiom. For the fut. ind. with ei) after expressions of uncertainty, see Kr. Spr. 65. 1. 8.
sterh/setai (the usual form, instead of sterhqh/setai): passive, as is also a)nia/setai. G. 1248; H. 496, and a.
mhde/n: for the occasional use of mh/ with the inf. after verbs which regularly take ou), see GMT. 685 fin.
daimo/nion: adj., “dependent on divine influence.”
th=s a)nqrwpi/nhs gnw/mhs: within the province of human understanding. For the pred. gen., see G. 1094, 1; H. 732 a.

daimona=n: equivalent to u(po\ dai/monos kate/xesqai. Notice the word-play (‘paronomasia’) between daimo/nion and daimona=n. The latter gains further emphasis by its repetition at the
beginning of the next sentence.
manteuome/nous: sc. peri\ tou/twn.
e)/dwkan: for the form, see G. 670; H. 432.
maqou=si: by learning, “by experience.” The participle is attracted to the case of a)nqrw/pois. G. 928, 1; H. 941.
oi(=on ei): as if for example.
krei=tton: sc. ei)/h.
mh/: with a participle, equivalent to a cond. rel. clause. G. 1612; H. 1025.
e)pi\ th\n vau=n: upon his ship, with reference to the implied subj. of labei=n. For the art. as possessive, see G. 949; H. 658.
h)\ a(\ e)/cestin ei)de/nai: or in regard to matters which we may determine.

sth/santas: by weighing. For the circumstantial participle of means, see G. 1563, 3; H. 969 a.—tou\s ta\ toiau=ta ktl.: sums up briefly (like pa/nta ta\ toiau=ta in 7) what precedes; hence the ‘asyndeton.’ Cf. ii.1.33; iv. 3. 14.
maqo/ntas: see on maqou=si above.
oi(=s a)\n w)=sin: cond. rel. clause. G. 1431, 1; H. 914 B (1).
i(/lew|: for the ‘Attic’ second decl., see G. 196; H. 227.

10-20. While Socrates always lived in the public view, and spoke and taught openly in the city, yet no one ever heard him utter an impiety; for he busied himself, not, like other philosophers, with speculations concerning the universe, but with the problems of making men better and more self-controlled. How faithful he could be to his principles was amply shown at the trial of the nine generals.
10. a)lla\ mh\n: see on 6.
a)ei\ me/n: contrasted with ou)dei\s de\ pw/pote in 11.
e)n tw=| fanerw=|: cf. Eng. ‘in the open.’
prwi+/: the day was divided into several parts (w(=rai),— prwi+/ or o)/rqros, morning; plh/qousa a)gora/, 9-12 A.M.; meshmbri/a, noon; dei/lh, afternoon; and e(spe/ra, evening.

peripa/tous: colonnades or halls. Aristotle and his followers, who carried on discussions while walking in
the paths and colonnades of the Lyceum, were called Peripatetics.
a)gora=s: for the gen. of time, see G. 1136; H. 759.
plei/stois: very many.
me/lloi: opt. in cond. rel. clause, denoting repeated action in past time. See on w(s nomi/zoien 6.
w(s to\ polu/: for the most part.

ou)dei\s de\ pw/pote *swkra/tous ktl.: but no one ever saw Socrates do, or heard him say, anything profane or impious. *swkra/tous is gen. with verbs of perception. G. 1102; H. 742. The two participles pra/ttontos and le/gontos are supplementary. G. 1582; H. 982.
ou)de\ ga/r: the neg. extends also to skopw=n.
tw=n pa/ntwn: the universe.

h(=|per: ea quidem ratione, qua. To serve ethical or teleological purposes, Socrates brought the consideration of the universe into his discussions (cf. i. 4, iv. 3). Xenophon is careful, however, to say that he did not discourse thereon after the manner of natural philosophers (in order to preclude the assumption that Socrates, by such discussions, laid himself open to the charge of a)se/beia, as did other philosophers, e.g., Anaxagoras). Cf. oi( ga\r a)kou/ontes h(gou=ntai tou\s tau=ta (viz. ta/ te mete/wra [celestial phenomena] kai\ ta\ u(po\ gh=s) zhtou=ntas ou)de\ qeou\s nomi/zein Plato Apol. 18 c.
kalou/menos: attrib. participle. G. 1559; H. 965.

tw=n sofistw=n: here, as in iv. 2. 1, philosophers, without unfavorable added meaning, which sofisth/s did not have before the time of Socrates. For its use in the less favorable sense, see i. 6. 13. The student may consult, on this subject, the histories of philosophy, as Zeller, Schwegler, Ueberweg, etc.; and, especially, Grote's famous discussion (Hist. of Greece, c. lxvii).
ko/smos: the world of order, corresponds exactly to the Lat. mundus, and is said to have been first employed in this sense by Pythagoras (about 500 B.C.).

e)/fu: the origin of the world was a favorite subject of speculation with the earliest Greek philosophers. ‘Ay, sir, the world is in its dotage; and yet the cosmogony, or creation of the world, has puzzled philosophers of all ages. What a medley of opinions have they not broached upon the creation of the world!’ Goldsmith, Vicar of Wakefield, c. 14.
ti/sin a)na/gkais: by what eternal laws.

fronti/zontas
ta\ toiau=ta: pondering such subjects. toiau=ta replaces a cognate acc. implied in the verb. G. 1054; H. 716 and b. Cf. me/giston and tau)ta/ 13, and ta\ mete/wra frontisth/s Plato Apol. 18B. So Aristophanes (Clouds 94) calls Socrates's house a frontisth/rion, and (ibid. 102) the philosophers generally merimnofrontistai/ ponderers of trifles.
prw=ton me/n: corresponds to e)sko/pei de/ in 15.

au)tw=n e)sko/pei po/tera: he would raise the question in regard to them, whether. au)tw=n (regarded as attrib. gen.) may be referred to the general rule given in G. 1084; H. 728, the other subst. in this case being the interr. sent. po/tera ktl. Cf. e)neno/hse de\ au)tw=n kai\ w(s e)phrw/twn a)llh/lous toiau=ta Cyr. v. 2. 18.
pote/: adds intensity to the question, as in 1 and 2. Cf. po/tera/ pote po/lemos, h)\ ei)rh/nh ei)/h Hell. v.4.16
ta)nqrw/pina, a)nqrw/peia: without perceptible difference in meaning. Cf. a)nqrwpi/nois pra/gmasi iv. 1. 2, with a)nqrw/peia pra/gmata iv. 6. 5.
to\ fronti/zein: for the articular inf., see G. 1546; H. 959.
pare/ntes (pari/hmi): in ignoring.
e)qau/maze ei): the prot. with ei), after verbs expressing emotion in past time, is equivalent to a causal clause, and might take the optative. GMT. 697; H. 926. ei) mh/ is equivalent to o(/ti ou).
e)sti/n, e)sti/n: such repetitions are frequent in Xenophon. So dokei=n ei)=nai, ei)=nai dokei=n in 14.
tou\s me/giston fronou=ntas: those who most pride themselves. me/giston, instead of me/gista, on the analogy of me/ga fronei=n.
ou) tau)ta\ doca/zein: do not hold the same opinions. For the inf. in subord. clause of indirect discourse, see on ei)=nai in 8.
a)llh/lois: for the abridged expression, see on tw=n a)/llwn 3.
toi=s mainome/nois: madmen, as a class. For the generic use of the art., see G. 950; H. 659.
diakei=sqai pro\s a)llh/lous: are affected, in comparison with one another.

tw=n te ga\r mainome/nwn: for, as among madmen (part. gen.), followed by tw=n te merimnw/ntwn as a parallel. Notice the ‘concinnity’
of this passage; both the maino/menoi and the merimnw=ntes are divided into three groups, each containing two contrasts.
dedie/nai: see on doca/zein in 13.
ta\ mh\ fobera/: mh/ instead of ou), since ta\ fobera/ is indefinite. G. 1613; H. 1026. Distinguish between dedie/nai and fobei=sqai.
o(tiou=n: -ou=n, like Lat. -cunque, is equivalent to Eng. ‘-ever,’ ‘-soever.’ G. 432; H. 285.
e)cithte/on: equivalent to e)cite/on. G. 808; H. 477. For the impers. const. of the verbal, see G. 1597; H. 990.

ta\ tuxo/nta: chanced on, hence “common.” The whole phrase is nearly equivalent to Eng. ‘stocks and stones,’ and seems to indicate a sort of fetichism. Breitenbach understands it of grotesque stone or wooden images, and cites ta\ de\ e)/ti palai/tera (in still more remote times) kai\ toi=s pa=sin *(/ellhsi tima\s qew=n (divine honors) a)nti\ a)galma/twn (statues) ei)=xon a)rgoi\ (undressed) li/qoi Paus. vii. 22. 3.

to\ o)/n: all existence, “the universe,” to be supplied also as subj. for a)/peira (ei)=nai) to\ plh=qos. That the universe was a unit (e(\n mo/non) was the doctrine of the Eleatic philosophers, and esp. of Xenophanes (about 540 B.C.), the founder of that school. Plato discusses this doctrine in the Parmenides. The contrary view (a)/peira to\ plh=qos) was held by the Atomists, esp. Leucippus (about 500 B.C.) and his pupil Democr&ibreve;tus, both of Abdēra in Thrace.

a)/n pote kinhqh=nai: equivalent to a)/n pote kinhqei/h in direct discourse. G. 1494; H. 964. The doctrine was that of the Eleatic Zeno (about 460 B.C.): ‘Motion is impossible,’ said he, ‘for it must take place either where a body is, or where it is not; it cannot move where it is, and it certainly cannot where it is not.’ On the other hand, the ‘perpetual flux’ (a)ei\ kinei=sqai) was maintained by Heraclītus of Ephesus (about 500 B.C.). For an account of these various schools, see Schwegler's, Zeller's, or Ueberweg's Hist. of Philosophy, or Marshall's Hist. of Greek Philosophy.
a)=ra: whether, introducing nomi/zousin, and followed by h)\ e)lpi/zousin as the alternative.
ma/qwsin, bou/lwntai, gnw=sin: for the cond. rel. subjv., see G. 1434; H. 916.
a)na/gkais: as in 11.
u(/data: rains.
o(/tou: for the form, see G. 425; H. 280 a.
h(=: qua ratione. The passage suggests a definition of ‘pure’ and ‘applied’ science.

peri\ me\n ou)=n: an extended enumeration of details is often closed, in Greek, with a clause or sent. which sums them all up; and which is commonly introduced by me\n ou)=n or dh/. Cf. the beginnings and endings of Xenophon's chapters.

au)to\s de/: for the uses of the intensive pron., see G. 989; H. 680.— ti/ eu)sebe/s, ti/ a)sebe\s ktl.: Socrates sought to define his conceptions by examining opposed qualities, which accordingly are here arranged in pairs until po/lis is reached, when the opposition ceases. Since the question is as to the essential nature of each quality, eu)sebe/s and the following adjs. are virtually abstract nouns. G. 933; H. 621 b (Rem.).—a(\ tou\s ei)do/tas ktl.: quas res qui scirent honestos esse arbitrabatur. To Socrates, the proper study of mankind was man. In his view the expression kalou\s ka)gaqou/s contained the idea of men of culture, viros liberaliter institutos; while a)ndrapodw/deis servile conveyed the opposite meaning. Other Greeks (than Socrates) often used kaloi\ ka)gaqoi/ in a political sense, like optimates.

a)\n keklh=sqai: equivalent to pf.
opt. in direct discourse. See on a)\n kinhqh=nai 14.

o(/sa me\n ou)=n mh\ fanero\s h)=n ktl.: the views and conversations of Socrates thus far described could not have been known to everybody, and might easily have remained unknown to the judges. mh/ is explained by the cond. force of the rel. clause. G. 1610; H. 1021. o(/sa is loosely connected with fanero/s and e)gi/gnwske, which verb, in the sense of ‘think’ or ‘believe,’ is often employed with peri/ and the genitive. Cf. i.2.19. For the pers. const. of fanero/s, see on i.1.2.
u(pe/r: chosen to avoid a repetition of peri/.
paragnw=nai: “went astray in their judgment.”
e)nequmh/qhsan: with the gen., had regard to; with the acc., more in the sense of ‘ponder.’ For ei) with the ind. after qaumasto/n, see on 13 above.

bouleu/sas: senator factus. So ii. 6. 25, where a)/rcas is equivalent to magistratus factus. The aor. denotes the election to the office, the pres. would indicate continuance in it. G. 1260; H. 841. The senate, or council (boulh/), of the Athenians was, under the constitution of Clisthenes, composed of five hundred citizens, fifty being chosen from each of the ten tribes (fulai/). The whole collective body was divided into ten sections of fifty each, corresponding to the ten tribes. Each of these sections (called pruta/neis) in turn served as an executive committee of the boulh/ for a period of thirty-five or thirty-six days in ordinary years (thirty-eight or thirtynine days in intercalary years). From the prytany of fifty members one man was chosen by lot each day to act as presiding officer (e)pista/ths) in conducting the debate and in putting questions to vote. This latter function, in the present instance, as we see, Socrates refused to exercise. Cf. Plato Apol. 32B, and for an account of the boulh/, its functions, divisions, etc., see Schömann, Antiq. of Greece, i. 371 ff., Gardner and Jevons, Manual of Greek Antiq., 484 ff.
to\n bouleutiko\n o(/rkon o)mo/sas: having taken the senatorial oath of office. o(/rkon is cognate accusative.

e)n w(=| h)=n: in which it was stipulated. We might expect e)n w(=| e)sti, but the impf. indicates what obligations Socrates assumed when he took the oath.— para\ tou\s no/mous ktl.: after the naval victory of the Athenians over the Spartans off the Arginusae
islands (406 B.C.), the Athenian generals omitted to take adequate measures to rescue the crews of the disabled vessels, or to gather the dead for burial. A violent storm, arising after the battle, hindered the detachment left behind for that purpose from performing this duty, so sacred in Hellenic eyes. The generals were publicly impeached; and, in spite of Socrates's protest, were condemned to death in one vote (mia=| yh/fw|). This proceeding, and the refusal of a fair trial to the generals, were illegal (para\ tou\s no/mous); for the law expressly provided that when several persons were accused together, a separate trial and vote should be held in the case of each (Hell. i.7.26). The full number of generals was ten: but Conon was blockaded at Mytilene, Archestratus had died, two had fled to avoid trial; and only six were actually executed. Cf. Hell. i. 7, Plato Apol. 32B, and see Grote, Hist. of Greece, c. lxiv.

tou\s a)mfi\ *qra/sullon kai\ *)erasini/dhn: Thrasyllus and Erasinides with their colleagues. For the phrase oi( a)mfi/ tina, see H. 791, 3. In the nine here spoken of should probably be included Leon, who was superseded in command by Lysias during or just before the battle (Hell. i.5.16, 6. 30, 7. 2); Xenophon must therefore omit his name when speaking (Hell. i.7.34) of sentence being passed on ‘eight.’
ou)k h)qe/lhsen: refused. The illegal vote must have been taken, after Socrates's refusal, by the ‘prytanes’ directing some other more compliant member of their body to put the question.
eu)orkei=n: to keep his oath.
fula/casqai: for differences of meaning in the act. and mid. of certain verbs, see G. 1246; H. 816.
qeou/s: “beings who deserve the name of gods.” tou\s qeou/s might be understood to mean the special divinities of the Athenians.
o(\n tro/pon: equivalent to to\n tro/pon, w(=|.

ta/ te lego/mena ktl.: cf. ‘For there is not a word in my tongue, but lo, O Lord, thou knowest it altogether,’ ‘thou understandest my thought afar off,’ ‘whither shall I flee from thy presence?’ Psalm cxxxix; and ou(=toi toi/nun oi( pa/nta me
 ei)do/tes pa/nta de\ duna/menoi
qeoi\ ou(/tw moi fi/loi ei)si
 w(/ste dia\ to\ e)pimelei=sqai/ mou ou)/pote lh/qw au)tou\s ou)/te nukto\s ou)/q' h(me/ras ou)/q) o(/poi a)
 o(rmw=mai ou)/q) o(/ ti a)/n me/llw pra/ttein Sym. iv. 48.
qauma/zw ou)=n ktl.: repeats, in conclusion, the thought of 1.

mh\ swfronei=n: did not hold sound opinions. For mh/ instead of ou), after oi)=mai, cf. i.2.41; after u(popteu/ein, An. ii.3.13 GMT. 685 fin.; H. 1024.—to\n a)sebe\s ktl.: the rest of the section is an expansion of the idea peri\ qeou\s swfronei=n. Note the significant change in tense from ei)po/nta and pra/canta to le/gonta and pra/ttonta.
oi(=a: obj. of le/gwn and pra/ttwn. For the cond. force of these participles, see on i.1.5.

div2.p: 1-11. In refutation of the second charge against Socrates, that of corrupting the youth, Xenophon shows that he dissuaded young men from vice and impiety, and led them, by the example of his own life, to revere the laws and abhor violence.

div3.p: to\ peisqh=nai tinas: that any were persuaded (by the arguments of the accusers). For the inf. with to/, as subj., see G. 1555; H. 959.
o(/s: a man who. Cf. 64; oi(/ i. 4. 11, iii. 5. 15.
pro\s toi=s ei)rhme/nois: sc. in the previous chapter.
gastro/s: appetite, as in i. 6. 8, a case of ‘metonymy.’ For the gen. with adjs., see G. 1140; H. 753 b.
ei)=ta: without de/, as often after a prw=ton me/n. So e)/peita in i. 4. 11, iv. 2. 31. On Socrates's hardy endurance of heat and cold, and other physical discomforts, cf. i.6.2, Plato Sym. 220 B.
karterikw/tatos: most inured.
pro\s to\ metri/wn dei=sqai: ‘to moderation in his wants.” For the articular inf. as obj. of a prep., see GMT. 800; H. 959.

pa/nu mikra/: Socrates estimated his entire estate at five minae, or 500 drachmae (Oec. ii. 3.). Reckoning
the drachma at eighteen cents, this would nominally be equivalent to ninety dollars. The purchasing power of money, however, was much greater in ancient than in modern times. The orator Lysias, who was reputed rich, was robbed by the Thirty of the bulk of his fortune, amounting to about 312 minae (Lys. xii. 11.). Boeckh (Staatshaushaltung der Athener 142 ff.) estimates that in the time of Socrates a family of four grown persons could live comfortably on five minae per annum; but as a man's entire estate, this sum would be, indeed, pa/nu mikro/n. On Attic money and its purchasing power, see Gow, Companion to School Classics, p. 88 ff.
kekthme/nos: for the circumstantial participle of concession, see G. 1563, 6; H. 969 e, and, for the case of the pred. participle, G. 927; H. 940. Cf. tw=| fanero\s ei)=nai 3.
e)/xein: inf. of result. G. 1450; H. 953.
pw=s ou)=n a)\n e)poi/hsen: how then could he have made. For the potential indic., see G. 1338; H. 903.
pro\s to\ ponei=n malakou/s: soft as to toil.
a)ll' e)/pause tou/twn pollou/s: nay, he freed many from these vices.

a)\n e)pimelw=ntai: the use of a)/n for e)a/n is not infrequent in Xenophon. Cf. a)/n ti o(rw=men i. 6. 14. Of the three forms of the cond. conj. with a)/n, it may be remarked that in Attic inscriptions of the classical period (fifth to third century B.C.) a)/n is found but six times, e)a/n being the prevailing form; while h)/n does not occur at all, though frequent in MSS. of literature of the fifth century. Meisterhans, Grammatik der attischen Inschriften, p. 213. For the subjv. in indirect discourse, see G. 1497, 2; H. 932, 933.
e)/sesqai: fut. inf. after e)lpi/das, as after a verb of hoping. In direct discourse, we should have a)\n u(mw=n au)tw=n e)pimelh=sqe, kaloi\ ka)gaqoi\ e)/sesqe.
kai/toi ge: and yet, indeed, opposed to me/n in the preceding sentence. So ge\ me/ntoi in ii. 1. 9. The restrictive force of ge/ applies to the whole clause.
dida/skalos: cf. ou(\s oi( diaba/llonte/s me/ fasin e)mou\s maqhta\s ei)=nai. e)gw\ de\ dida/skalos me\n ou)deno\s pw/pot' e)geno/mhn Plato Apol. 33A. See on i. 1. 4.
tou/tou: i.e. tou= kalou\s ka)gaqou\s e)/sesqai.

a)lla\ tw=| fanero\s ei)=nai toiou=tos w)/n: but because it was evident that he was such a one. For the articular inf. in the dat., see G. 1547; H. 959, and for w)/n, see on qu/wn i. 1. 2. For the case of fanero/s, see on kekthme/nos 1.—
sundiatri/bontas: see on dida/skalos above.
e(autw=|: for the indir. refl., see G. 993; H. 683 a.
mimoume/nous: imitando.

e)kei=non: refers more distinctly to Socrates, from the point of view of the sundiatri/bontes, than au)to/n would do. e)kei=nos is apt to be used when the person has already been mentioned by au)tou= or e(autou=. Cf. ou)k e)/fh e(autou= ge a)/rxontos ou)de/na *(ellh/nwn eis to\ e)kei/nou dunato\n a)ndrapodisqh=nai Hell. i.6.14
a)lla\ mh/n: as in i. 1. 6.

ou)k e)ph/|nei: improbabat. Cf. o(/ti *de/cippon me\n ou)k e)painoi/h, ei) tau=ta pepoihkw\s ei)/h An. vi.6.25—to\ me\n ou)=n u(peresqi/onta ktl.: he accordingly disapproved of overeating along with overworking. u(peresqi/onta agrees with the understood subj. (tina/) of u(perponei=n. The allusion is to the enormous appetites of athletes while in training, a process which must have been more one-sided in its results than our modern training is. In Plato and Euripides the professional athletes are stigmatized as lazy, greedy, and sleepy. In the fourth idyl of Theocritus, the boxer Aegon is described as taking with him twenty sheep for his month of training, and as eating eighty barley-cakes in one day.
a)ll' ou) mh\n qruptiko\s h)=n: “but he did not carry care for the body so far as to be effeminate.”
a)lazoniko/s: ostentatious, as the professional Sophists often were. See on i. 6. 2.

a)mpexo/nh|, u(pode/sei: clothing, footgear. Cf. soi\ me
 ga ou)k a)
 pre/poi toiou/twn o)noma/twn a)napi/mplasqai (to be soiled by), kalw=s me
 ou(twsi\ a)mpexome/nw| (clothed), kalw=s de\ u(podedeme/nw| (shod) Plato Hipp. Maj. 291 A.
ou) mh\n ou)de/: ac ne quidem.

e)piqumiw=n, e)piqumou=ntas: obs. the ‘paronomasia.’ “Not only did Socrates free his associates from the tyranny of other passions (beside avarice) which demand money for their satisfaction, but he gratified the sole desire aroused by himself (i.e. to hear him converse) without putting them to any outlay of money” (Gilbert).

tou\s e)piqumou=ntas e)pra/tteto xrh/mata: for the
double acc. with e)pra/tteto, see G. 1069; H. 724. This also is aimed at the Sophists, many of whom charged extravagant prices for their instruction. Protagoras is said to have received 100 minae (nominally about $1800, but see on pa/nu mikra/ in 1), which must have been out of all proportion to ordinary fees.
e)leuqeri/as e)pimelei=sqai: he was preserving his independence.
a)ndrapodista\s e(autw=n: enslavers of themselves. Cf. i. 5. 6.
diale/gesqai: sc. tou/tois. Cf. i.6.5.

a)\n la/boien: for a)\n la/bwsi of direct discourse. For the retention of a)/n in rel. and temporal clauses even when the verb has been changed to the opt., see GMT. 702. On this section, cf. Plato Apol. 31B, C, 33 A.
e)paggello/menos: professing to teach, a technical expression.
pra/ttoito: for the opt., see on i.1.13, and G. 1502, 2 (2), last example but one; H. 932, 2.

mh/, mh\ e(/coi: we should expect mh\ ou)x e(/coi, acc. to the rule (G. 1364; H. 887), but ‘after mh/ had come to be felt as a conjunction, and its origin was forgotten, the chief objection to mh/, mh/ was probably in the sound, and we find a few cases of it where the two particles are so far apart that the repetition is not offensive’ GMT. 306 (where the sent. of the text is cited). Another instance of this rare usage is found in Thuc. ii. 13.
e)phggei/lato, e)pi/steue: note the difference between the aor. and the imperfect.
diafqei/roi: potential optative.
ei) mh\ a)/ra: unless, forsooth. Cf. ei) mh\ a)/ra deino\n kalou=sin ou(=toi le/gein to\n ta)lhqh= le/gonta unless, forsooth, these gentlemen call him eloquent who speaks the truth Plato Apol. 17B.
a)lla\ nh\ *di/a: often used to introduce an objection. For the use of the advs. nh/ and ma/ in swearing, see G. 1067; H. 723.
o( kath/goros: possibly the author of a kathgori/a *swkra/tous, written after Socrates's death. See Dakyns, Works of Xenophon Vol. III, Part I, pp. xxxviii ff.
e)/fh: in direct discourse usually before its subj., as in 12.
u(perora=n tw=n no/mwn: the gen. after the analogy of a)melei=n tinos. The acc. is more usual, as in i. 3. 4, 4. 10.
a)po\ kua/mou: by the bean. The Athenians used black and white beans in selecting certain officials by lot; hence kuameuto/s is equivalent to klhrwto/s or ai(reto/s.

Xenophon cannot wholly refute the charge that the teachings of Socrates weakened public respect for existing laws; so he blends it with the other charge poiei=n biai/ous, maintaining that while Socrates criticised certain governmental institutions, his criticism could never lead to acts of violence.
tou\s fro/nhsin a)skou=ntas: those who cultivate practical wisdom.
ta\ sumfe/ronta: as in i. 1. 3. For the double acc., see G. 1069; H. 724.
tou\s poli/tas: their fellowcitizens.

ei)do/tas: because they know. —oi( me\n ga\r biasqe/ntes ktl.: for men who have suffered violence are filled with hatred, feeling that they have been robbed. For the thought, cf. Aesop's fable of the Wind and the Sun.
kexarisme/noi: beneficiis affecti.
ou)/koun: declarative negation.
tw=n a)skou/ntwn: pred.gen.of characteristic.
to\ toiau=ta pra/ttein: i.e. to\ bia/zesqai.
a)lla\ mh/n: as in 4, i. 1. 6.
summa/xwn: for the gen. with verbs of wanting, see G. 1112; H. 743.
ou)k o)li/gwn: ‘litotes’; the position also helps the emphasis.
mo/nos: by himself.
h(/kista sumbai/nei: it least of all occurs, a strong negation.
zw=nti peiqome/nw| xrh=sqai: “to have his faithful service while living.” For the pred. dat. with xra/omai, see H. 777 a.

12-48. The fact that Alcibiades and Critias wrought great evil in the state should not be laid to the account of Socrates. They were impelled by measureless ambition and lust for power; and in Socrates they only sought a man from whom they could learn the art of persuasion, so as to win thereby positions of political influence. But they sufficiently showed in the sequel that they had not learned to imitate the character and life of their teacher. Socrates did not fail to set before them the attractions of a virtuous life; and, in fact, so long as they remained with him, they showed moderation. But virtue must be practiced to be retained; and they quickly fell a prey to all manner of temptations after leaving Socrates. For this he is not to be held responsible, the less so as he reproached them severely for their unworthy conduct,—incurring thereby the hate of Critias, as he later had cause to know. Thus they only followed their own natural bent after leaving Socrates; while many other friends of Socrates remained true through life to the principles of virtue which they had learned from him.
12. e)/fh ge: with marked emphasis, like Mark Antony's ‘But Brutus says he was ambitious.’
genome/nw: the kath/goros seems to insinuate a causal, as well as a temporal, force of the participle; post hoc, propter hoc.

*kriti/as: son of Callaeschrus, was one of the thirty men who were placed in power at Athens (by the aid of the victorious Lacedaemonians) at the close of the Peloponnesian war (404 B.C.). He took a prominent part in the cruelties practiced by the Thirty, and fell in the final conflicts with the Liberators under Thrasybulus. He had associated, as a young man, with Socrates and Gorgias of Leontini, and was a poet and dramatist of some repute. For an account of his activity, see Hell. ii.3.11 ff.

*)alkibia/dhs: son of Clinias, born at Athens about 450 B.C.;
he was distinguished for his personal beauty, talents, and wealth, and was notorious for his reckless profligacy. Socrates took great interest in him, and seems in return to have been respected and loved by him. At the siege of Potidaea (432 B.C.) Socrates saved his life, a service which Alcibiades returned by aiding Socrates at the battle of Delium (424 B.C.). For his connection with the Sicilian expedition (415 B.C.), see Thuc. vi, passim. Plutarch brackets him with Coriolanus in the Parallel Lives.
th\n po/lin: for the double acc., see G. 1073; H. 725 a.

e)n th=| o)ligarxi/a|: i.e. in 404 B.C., when the Thirty, with Critias at their head, were in power at Athens. Cf. Hell. ii. 3. 11 ff. See on nomoqe/ths 31. Aeschines (Contra Timarchum 173) says, with exaggeration, e)/peit' u(mei=s, w)= *)aqhnai=oi, *swkra/th me
 to
 sofisth
 a)pektei/nate, o(/ti *kriti/an e)fa/nh pepaideukw/s, e(/na tw=n tria/konta tw=n to
 dh=mon katalusa/ntwn (who overthrew the democracy).
klepti/statos, biaio/tatos: so, in ii. 6. 24, xrh/mata/ te kle/ptein kai\ bia/zesqai a)nqrw/pous are mentioned as low motives for attaining power in the state.
e)n th=| dhmokrati/a|: refers to the public and private life of Alcibiades, down to his return to the army at Samos in 411. See Grote, Hist. of Greece, cc. lv, lxiii.
ei) e)poihsa/thn: for the past supposition assumed as real (a simply logical cond.), see G. 1390; H. 893.
sunousi/an: ‘prolepsis.’ Cf. ‘I knew thee, that thou art a hard man’ Matt. xxv. 24.
e)gene/sqhn me/n: corresponds to h)/|desan de/ in the following sentence. In this case, me/n and de/ will scarcely be over-translated by on the one hand, on the other.
dh/: “as is known,” almost equivalent to our colloquial ‘you know.’
h)/|desan: changes from dual to pl. and vice versa, in the same sent., are common. G. 903; H. 634. Cf. 16, 18, 33; Hell. iv.4.7
zw=nta: for the supplementary participle in indirect discourse, see on i.1.5.

h(donw=n: equivalent to e)piqumiw=n, the
object of desire being substituted for the desire itself. Cf. 23.
xrw/menon: “influenced.”
bou/loito: for the opt., see on me/lloi i. 1. 10.
o(rw=nte, o)/nte: accs. agreeing with au)tw/, and having a causal force.
fh=|: interr. subjunctive. G. 1359; H. 866, 3 c. To complete the sense, fh=| tis (sc. au)tw\ o)re/casqai th=s o(mili/as au)tou=) should be repeated after h)/.
ei) o(milhsai/thn, gene/sqai a)/n: for the modes in indirect discourse, see G. 1494, 1495, 1497; H. 932, 2(2), 946.

i(kanwta/tw le/gein te kai\ pra/ttein: very proficient in speech and action. The Greeks often used le/gein kai\ pra/ttein to indicate the theory and practice of an art or a profession. Cf. iv.2.6. For the inf. with adjs., see G. 1526; H. 952.
qeou= dido/ntos: if God had offered. The gen. abs. is equivalent to a past unfulfilled condition. For the force of the pres. participle, see G. 1255; H. 825.
zw=nta: supplementary participle, to be distinguished from zw=nta in 14, which also is a supplementary participle, but in indirect discourse. G. 1582, 1583, 1588; H. 982.
e(le/sqai a)\n teqna/nai: in i. 6. 4, Socrates imputes this same disposition to Antiphon. Const. a)/n with e(le/sqai.
dh/lw d) e)gene/sqhn ktl.: “their motives became manifest from their actions.”
a)pophdh/sante, e)pratte/thn: they leaped away, and were busied in. Note the change of tense.
swfronei=n: correlative with ta\ politika/.

pro\s tou=to me\n ou)k
a)ntile/gw ktl.: “I do not deny that this was the duty of Socrates; but I claim that he actually did lead his friends to virtue through his precepts and example.” Xenophon postpones the formal refutation of the charge here suggested to iv. 3. 1 ff., where he shows that Socrates strove to secure for his friends a firm foundation in morals, before advising them to enter public life.
probiba/zontas: sc. au)tou\s (tou\s manqa/nontas) as object.
deiknu/ntas, deiknu/nta: for the first, cf. zw=nta in 16; for the second, cf. zw=nta in 14.
tw=n a)/llwn a)nqrwpi/nwn: not different in meaning from tw=n a)nqrwpei/wn in i. 1. 16.
ka)kei/nw: i.e. Critias and Alcibiades.
sunh/sthn, zhmioi=nto: for the change of number, see on 14, and for the opt. in clauses expressing apprehension, see G. 1378; H. 887.
foboume/nw: causal.
tw=n fasko/ntwn filosofei=n: refers to the Sophists. fa/skwn often suggests the idea of alleging, pretending. For the form, see G. 812; H. 481 a.
a)/llo ou)de/n: best const. as the obj. of the trans. phrase a)nepisth/mwn ge/noito. H. 713. Cf. e)pisth/mones h)=san ta\ prosh/konta they were acquainted with their duty Cyr. iii. 3. 9.
w(=n: with antec. omitted. G. 1026; H. 996.
o( maqw/n: he who has once learned it.
gignw/skw: think, judge.
w(/sper ta\ ... duname/nous poiei=n: the const. of the subord. clause is attracted to that of the main clause.
e)/rga: obj. of poiei=n, to be supplied with duname/nous.
dio/ [dia\ o(/]: for which reason.

w(s o(mili/an ou)=san: for the acc. abs., see on w(s proshmai/nontos i. 1. 4, and G. 1570; H. 974.—e)sqlw=n ktl.: these verses, forming an elegiac distich, are from Theognis, a gnomic poet of Megara, who flourished about 530 B.C., and are Nos. 35 and 36 of his 1400 extant verses; for which, see Bergk's Anthologia Lyrica and Poetae Lyrici Graeci. The sympathies and tendencies of Theognis were all aristocratic; his e)sqloi/ were the nobles, and his kakoi/ the common people: but his sententious wisdom lent itself readily to quotation, and his poetry was popular in Attica. This couplet is quoted by Socrates (Sym. ii. 4) in answer to the question as to whence kaloka)gaqi/a could be learned; and again (Plato Meno 95 D) as proof that virtue can be learned. For the meter, see G. 1670, 1671; H. 1101.—au)ta\r a)nh\r ktl.: the author of this verse is unknown. It is quoted by Plato (Prot. 344 D) in confirmation of the assertion tw=| me\n ga\r e)sqlw=| e)gxwrei= kakw=| gene/sqai for it is possible for the good man to become a wicked one.
w(/sper ... e)pilanqanome/nous: for the attraction, cf. 19.
e)n me/trw| pepoihme/nwn e)pw=n: poetry. e)pw=n is obj. of e)pilanqanome/nous.
didaskalikw=n: instructive.
nouqetikw=n: admonitory. —e)pile/lhstai ktl.: he has forgotten also the frame of mind in which his soul once longed for virtue.

w(=n: i.e.
tou/twn a(/, the latter to be closely connected with pa/sxousa. For the case of the rel., see G. 1032; H. 996 a (2).
proaxqe/ntas: swept away. paraxqe/ntas would mean led aside.
e)/rwtas: concrete, love affairs.
h(=tton duname/nous: sc. than they were before surrendering to these passions.
kerdw=n: incorporated in the rel. sentence. G. 1037; H. 995.
nomi/zontes: causal.
ou)k: we might expect ou)ke/ti.
pw=s ou)=n ou)k e)nde/xetai: how then is it not possible? The indic. strengthens the rhetorical force of the question. Cf. pw=s ou)k e)no/mizen i. 1. 5.
a)skhta\ ei)=nai: to be capable of attainment by practice.
ou)x h(/kista: most of all, ‘litotes.’ Cf. ou)k a)fanh/s i. 1. 2, ou) tou\s xeiri/stous i. 2. 32, ou)k o)li/ga iv. 2. 12, ou)de\n h(=tton iii. 7. 4.
swfrosu/nh: without the article. So often abstract nouns, regarded as simple conceptions, e.g., ka/llos 24, h(/bhn ii. 1. 21, w(/ra ii. 1. 22, a)reth/ iv. 1. 2, sofi/a iv. 6. 7.
h(donai/: voluptates, the passions. Cf. 14.
pei/qousin: tentative present. Cf. dido/ntos 16.
th\n taxi/sthn: sc. o(do/n. For the adv. acc., see G. 1060; H. 719.
e(autai=s: to them, i.e. tai=s h(donai=s. See on e(autw=| 3.
dh/: so, then, returning to the discussion in 12-16.

summa/xw|: as
a helper.

fugw/n: in technical sense, being exiled. In 407 B.C., Critias was banished from Athens, and betook himself to the Thessalians, who had an undesirable reputation for license and immorality (cf. e)kei\ ga\r plei/sth a)taci/a kai\ a)kolasi/a Plato Crito 53 D). He did not return till after the disaster of Aegospotami, 405 B.C. Cf. Hell. ii. 3. 36; Grote, Hist. of Greece, c. lxv.
semnw=n: highborn.
qhrw/menos: a common metaphor.
kolakeu/ein: prob. an interpolation to explain dunatw=n.
ka)kei=nos: renewal of the remote subj. (*)alkibia/dhs) for the sake of the contrast to a)qlhtai/. Cf. iv.2.25.

au)toi=n: dative.—Notice the different metaphors employed. o)gko/w is lit. swell, as of a tumor; e)pai/rw lift up, fusa/w puff up, as of a bladder or bellows; diaqru/ptw break down, hence enervate; diafqei/rw corrupt.
e)pi\ de\ pa=si tou/tois: and in addition to all this.
ti/ qaumasto/n: why is it surprising?
ei) e)gene/sqhn: for the cond. in causal sense, see on i.1.17.
e)plhmmelhsa/thn: went wrong. For the cond., see on e)poihsa/thn 13, and obs. that here there is also a causal force.
tou/tou: for the gen. of cause, see G. 1126; H. 744.
h(ni/ka: at an age when.
ei)ko/s: sc. e)sti/.
dokei=: sc. o( *swkra/ths.
ou) mh/n: neque vero. Cf. i.2.5.
au)lhth/s: master of the flute.
e)a\n fanw=sin: for the pres. general supposition, see G. 1393; H. 894.
ai)ti/an e)/xei: is blamed.
tou/tou: as in 26.

to\n pro/sqen: for the adv. as adj., see G. 952; H. 600.—a)ll) ou)x o(/sw| a)/n ktl.: “on the contrary, does he not rather award praise to the first teacher, just in proportion as his son seems to have deteriorated while in the society of the second?”
o(/sw|, tosou/tw|: for the dat. of degree of difference, see G. 1184; H. 781.
a)ll' oi(/ ge pate/res au)toi/: nay, the very fathers themselves.
suno/ntes: concessive.
tw=n pai/dwn plhmmelou/ntwn: with conditional force.
e)a/n: provided.
ei) e)poi/ei, a)\n e)do/kei: see on e)do/kei d' a)/n, ei) e)fai/neto i. 1. 5.

ei) swfronw=n diete/lei: for the supplementary participle with diatele/w, see G. 1587; H. 981. For the simple past supposition (assumed as real), see on e)poihsa/thn 13. The unfulfilled cond. is again returned to in ei) e)ph/|nei 29.
*kriti/an me\n toi/nun: the me/n (without a correlative de/, as in i. 1. 1) introduces the passage closing with 38. toi/nun marks the transition from the previous sentence.

*eu)qudh/mou: in iv. 2. 1, designated as o( kalo/s. —
a)pe/trepe: for the impf. of attempted action, see G. 1255; H. 832.
w(/sper tou\s ptwxou/s: i.e. w(/sper oi( ptwxoi\ prosaitou=si, a form of attraction found also in Latin. Cf. te suspicor iisdem rebus, quibus me ipsum, interdum gravius commoveri Cic. de Am. i. 1.
prosdou=nai: to grant also, followed by the part. gen. mhdeno/s. Cf. ou)dei\s prosdw/sei moi spla/gxnwn Ar. Peace 1111. For the thought, cf. Sym. viii. 22.
tou= *kriti/ou, to\n *swkra/thn: the arts. in this section seem intended to heighten the contrast between the persons. Thus far in this chap. the proper names have lacked the article.

e)c w(=n dh\ kai\ e)mi/sei o( *kriti/as: as a result of which, accordingly, Critias even hated. This does not contradict what is said in 15 and 47: Critias had a grudge against Socrates, yet remained with him until he thought he had learned enough from him.
tw=n tria/konta: for the pred. gen., see G. 1094, 7; H. 732.

nomoqe/ths: in the year 404 B.C., the oligarchical party at Athens, backed by the all-powerful Spartan Lysander, succeeded in having a commission of thirty appointed, ostensibly to exercise the ancient function of Nomothetae, or revisers of the laws. Among these, Critias (see on 12), Theramenes, and Charicles were the most prominent. The Thirty soon usurped all the powers of government and inaugurated a reign of terror, which lasted for eight months. For an account of these events, see Grote, Hist. of Greece, c.lxv, and Hell. ii. 3, 4.
a)pemnhmo/neusen: here in a hostile sense, he remembered it against him.

lo/gwn te/xnhn: the art of speaking. The law was broad enough to include the conversational utterances of Socrates.—
o(/ph| e)pila/boito: how to reach him. For the opt. representing interr. subjv. of direct discourse, see G. 1490; H. 932, 2.

to\ koinh=| ... e)pitimw/menon: the charge commonly brought by the many against philosophers. Acc. to Sym. vi. 6; Oec. xi. 3; Ar. Clouds 100 ff.; Plato Apol. 18B, this charge was that philosophers were a race of busybodies, who meddled with things in ‘the heaven above, the earth beneath, and the water under the earth’; and secondly, that they were jugglers with words, making the worse appear the better reason. Cf. also ta\ kata\ pa/ntwn tw=n filosofou/ntwn pro/xeira (commonplaces) tau=ta le/gousin, o(/ti ta\ mete/wra (celestial phenomena), kai\ ta\ u(po\ gh=s, kai\ qeou\s mh\ nomi/zein, kai\ to\n h(/ttw lo/gon krei/ttw poiei=n (dida/skei) Plato Apol. 23D.
ga/r: explains the preceding diaba/llwn, “slander must we call it,” for.
fa/skontos: see on 19. For the supplementary participle, see on ou)dei\s de\ pw/pote *swkra/tous i. 1. 11.
h)|sqo/mhn: instead of h)/kousa, to avoid repetition.
e)dh/lwse: impers., events showed, that the prohibition was aimed at Socrates. Cf. Cyr. vii. 1. 30.
ou) tou\s xeiri/stous: see on ou)x h(/kista 23. For the comparison of the adj., see G. 361, 2; H. 254, 2.
a)dikei=n: to commit unlawful acts. Cf. polloi=s polla\ prose/tatton boulo/menoi w(s plei/stous a)naplh=sai (to involve) ai)tiw=n Plato Apol. 32C.
ei)=pe/ pou: said, I suppose. Xenophon vouches for the thoughts, not for the words. See on i. 1. 1.
oi(=: for the indir. refl. use of the pron., see G. 987; H. 685.
bow=n a)ge/lhs nomeu/s: a comparison perhaps suggested by Hom. B 474-483. Cf. iii.2.1; Plato Gorg. 516 A, B.
ei) o(mologoi/h: see on e)qau/maze i. 1. 13.

ei) ai)sxu/netai: above, where an imaginary case was suggested, the opt. (o(mologoi/h)
was used; here, to mark the actual fact, the indic. of direct discourse is retained. Cf. ii.6.4.
kale/santes, e)deiknu/thn: for the change in number, see on 14.
to\n no/mon: sc. th\n lo/gwn te/xnhn mh\ dida/skein.
mh/: for the neg. particle with verbs of forbidding, see G. 1615; H. 1029.
ei) e)cei/h: indir. question.
ei) a)gnooi=to: in case he failed to understand.
tw=n proagoreuome/nwn: “the published injunctions.”
tw\ d' e)fa/thn: and they said yes. For the dem. use of the art., see G. 983; H. 654 e; and for fhmi/ as an affirmative answer, cf. the trial-scene of Orontas, An. i. 6.
la/qw paranomh/sas: for the supplementary participle with lanqa/nw, see G. 1586; H. 984.
th\n tw=n lo/gwn te/xnhn: cf. 31. From this definite reference, it would seem that Socrates knew very well what was meant by the prohibition toi=s ne/ois mh\ diale/gesqai.
su\n toi=s o)rqw=s legome/nois ei)=nai: to be associated with right teachings.
mh\ o)rqw=s: sc. legome/nois. For mh/ with the participle, see on i.1.9.
a)fekte/on: for the impers. use of the verbal in -te/os, see on i.1.14.
ta/de eu)maqe/stera o)/nta: “these orders in more intelligible terms.”
o(/lws mh\ diale/gesqai: well illustrates the arrogance of arbitrary power.
i(/na mh\ a)mfi/bolon h)=|: “that there may be no question,” lit. that it may not be doubtful.

w(s ... prohgoreume/na: “as to the question
whether I am acting in violation of the injunctions.”
o(ri/sate: define.
me/xri po/swn e)tw=n: until what age. For po/swn, see on ti/si i. 1. 1.
ne/ous: predicate.
o(/souper xro/nou: for just as long a period.
bouleu/ein: see on bouleu/sas i. 1. 18.

w(s ou)/pw froni/mois ou)=sin: as not yet having arrived at years of discretion. For the participle, see on i.1.4. All members of the boulh/ must be at least thirty years of age. See Gardner and Jevons, Manual of Greek Antiq., c. ix.
e)a\n w)nw=mai, h)\n pwlh=|: if I wish to purchase, if he offer to sell. The pres. implies desired action. See on dido/ntos 16. For the variant forms of the conj., see on i.2.2.

mhd' e)/rwmai: for the interr. subjv., see G. 1358; H. 866, 3; and, for mhde/ with the interr. subjv. expecting an affirmative answer, GMT. 293. Cf. mh\ a)pokri/nwmai, a)ll' e(/teron ei)/pw Plato Rep. 337 B.
ei)dw/s: concessive.
pw=s e)/xei: “the facts of the case.”
ta\ plei=sta: cognate accusative.
e)a/n: provided that, introduces a second and subord. protasis. GMT. 510.
oi(=on: for example. Cf. i. 1. 9.
a)pe/xesqai deh/sei: it will be necessary to keep away from, with sarcastic formality.

skute/wn, tekto/nwn, xalke/wn: Socrates, like a greater Teacher, sought his illustrations in the familiar and homely things of daily life, and especially in the handicrafts. Cf. iv.2.6, 4. 5; also, a)te/xnws (actually) ge a)ei\ skute/as te kai\ knafe/as (fullers) kai\ magei/rous (cooks) le/gwn kai\ i)atrou\s ou)de\n pau/ei, w(s peri\ tou/twn h(mi=n o)/nta to\n lo/gon Plato Gorg. 491 A.

kai\ ga\r oi)=mai ... u(po\ sou=: for I think that they have become worn out, being constantly talked of
by you.
tw=n e(pome/nwn tou/tois: the subjects which are connected with these, sc. in our conversations. tw=n e(pome/nwn is explained by the following appositives tou= dikai/ou etc.
kai\ tw=n bouko/lwn ge: This allusion by Charicles to the words of Socrates in 32 completes the list of prohibited topics; and completes, also, the evidence introduced in 32 by e)dh/lwse de/.
o(/pws mh\ poih/sh|s ktl.: A thinly disguised threat; for the failure of such attempts to coerce Socrates, cf. the incident related in Plato Apol. 32C, D.
oi(/a me\n ou)=n: closes what was begun in 13. Both there and here the relation between Socrates and the two young men is called sunousi/a. A pai/deusis is denied in the following sentence.
mhdeni\ mhdemi/an: for mh/ and its compounds with the inf. of indirect discourse, instead of ou), see GMT. 685, and Gildersleeve, Am. Jour. Philol., i. p. 51.
ou)k: belongs grammatically to w(milhsa/thn, but practically denies a)re/skontos as a motive for the action of Critias and Alcibiades, and contrasts it with the real motive w(rmhko/te.
w(milhsa/thn, w(milei/thn: note the significant change of tense.
a)ll' eu)qu\s e)c a)rxh=s w(rmhko/te: but because from the very beginning they had set out.

pri\n ei)/kosin e)tw=n ei)=nai: viz. before 430 B.C.; for Alcibiades was born about 450 B.C. For the inf. with temporal particles, see G. 1469 ff.; H. 955; and, for the pred. gen. of measure, G. 1094, 5; H. 732.—
toia/de dialexqh=nai: had some such conversation as this, a good example of how the younger friends of Socrates imitated their master in e)ceta/zein. Cf. kai\ au)toi\ (oi( ne/oi moi e)pakolouqou=ntes) polla/kis e)me\ mimou=ntai, ei)=ta e)pixeirou=sin a)/llous e)ceta/zein Plato Apol. 23C.
ei)pe/: for the accent, see G. 131, 2; H. 387 b.
*peri/kleis: for the decl. of proper nouns in -kle/hs, see G. 231; H. 194.
e)/xois a)/n: potential opt. of courteous inquiry.
me/: for double acc. with verbs of teaching, see G. 1069; H. 724.
ti/ e)sti no/mos: for a short definition of no/mos, cf. iv.4.13.
tinw=n e)painoume/nwn: for the supplementary participle with verbs of perception, see on i.1.11.
oi)=mai mh\ tuxei=n: see on mhdeni/ 39, and on i. 1. 20.
ou)de/n ti: not at all, adv. acc. with xalepou=. See on th\n taxi/sthn 23.
to\ plh=qos: the people, plebs. The orators often used the phrase to\ u(me/teron plh=qos, referring to the democracy at Athens.
e)/graye: enacts.
fra/zon: stating.
nomi/san: sc. to\ plh=qos e)/graye.
w)= meira/kion: my lad.
w(/sper o(/pou: as is the case where.
to\ kratou=n th=s po/lews: ‘the powers that be’ in the state. For the subst. use of the participle, see G. 1560; H. 966.

tu/rannos: with
no implied reproach as in Eng. ‘tyrant.’ The word is one of many which have degenerated. Cf., and trace to their origin, our villain, knave, and varlet.
gra/fei: ind., being an accepted particular case of the previous general supposition.
a)=r' ou): sc. bi/a e)sti/.
pei/sas: participle of means.

biasa/menos: a rigid definition of bi/a would exclude biasa/menos here, as containing in itself the idea to be defined. Yet, as a)nomi/a also was to be defined, the participle contrasted with pei/sas may be admitted, as suggesting some of the elements of a)nomi/a.
a)nati/qemai: I retract, lit. put back, a term borrowed from games like checkers, in which the player ‘takes back’ the pieces moved (a)natiqe/nai pettou/s). The mid. voice is significant.

mh\ pei/sas: these words were not uttered in 43 (kai\ o(/sa tu/rannos gra/fei), but they are inserted here, as having been easily understood in the words of Pericles, and as having actually been used by Alcibiades.
mh\ fw=men: see on e)/rwmai 36.
bi/a: nom. after ei)=nai, as pa/nta is subj. of dokei= as well as of the infinitive. See G. 927; H. 940.
to\ pa=n plh=qos: the collective people.
a)/ra: sc. “according to your view.”
a)\n ei)/h: for the ‘mixed’ const., see G. 1421, 1, 1437; H. 901 b, 918.

h)\ no/mos: a positive answer to the question ti/ e)sti no/mos (41) is, after all, not given. Xenophon is only trying to show what subjects Alcibiades liked to discuss, and how well he had learned from Socrates the art of ‘cornering’ an adversary.
ma/la toi: connect with deinoi/.
kai\ h(mei=s: for the pl. of ‘modest assertion,’ see H. 637. Pericles speaks with a touch of ironical humor, as the next words show.
deinoi\ ta\ toiau=ta: strong at such things (the arts of debate).
e)sofizo/meqa: we used to discuss.
sunegeno/mhn: for the indic. in expressions of wishing, see G. 1511; H. 871.
deino/tatos sautou=: “at the height of your powers.” Pericles is compared with himself at different periods of his life. The gen. is partitive. G. 1088 (last example); H. 729 e.
e)pei\ ta/xista: as soon as.
ou)/te, te/: nec, et.
a)/llws, for other reasons, than the one to be mentioned.
prose/lqoien: for the opt. in past general suppositions, see G. 1393, 2; H. 894, 2.
u(pe\r w(=n: for the assimilation, see on w(=n 21.
w(=nper e(/neken kai/: for which very reason also.

*kri/twn ... *faidw/ndas: for Crito, see ii. 9. 1 ff.; for Chaerephon, Ar. Clouds 104; Plato Apol. 20E, 21, and ii. 3, q.v. also for Chaerecrates. Cebes and Simmias left their native Thebes to become companions of Socrates. Cf. iii.11.17 and Plato Phaedo 59 C. Phaedondas also was a Theban. For Hermogenes, see on ii.10.3; iv. 8. 4.
dhmhgorikoi\ h)\ dikanikoi/: public or forensic orators.

ou)dei/s, ou)/te, ou)/te: for the strengthened negation expressed by a series of compound negs. following a neg., see G. 1619; H. 1030.—
ai)ti/an e)/sxen: incurred reproach. See on ai)ti/an e)/xei 27.

49-55. Socrates had no desire to disturb the relations of children with parents, or of kindred to one another. But he recognized how external and material these relations remain in the case of many; while in other affairs little value is assigned to the material unless inspired by a soul: and he set himself, accordingly, to give to the relations of kinsfolk a moral content and a firmer basis, by the aid of mutual forbearance and assistance.
49. kath/goros: see on 9.
prophlaki/zein e)di/daske: in Ar. Clouds 1321 ff., Phidippides strikes his father, and argues that he has the right to do so.
au)tw=|: for the use of au)to/s in its oblique cases as a refl. pron., see G. 992; H. 684 a. Cf. tou\s o(milou=ntas au)tw=| iv. 7. 1.

th=s paranoi/as e(lo/nti: if one convicted (his father) of dementia. For the gen., see G. 1121; H. 745. The reference is to the legally authorized complaint paranoi/as, as it was brought, e.g., against Sophocles by his sons. Cf. oi)/moi, ti/ dra/sw parafronou=ntos tou= patro/s; | po/teron paranoi/as au)to
 ei)sagagw
 e(/lw, | h)\ toi=s sorophgoi=s th
 mani/an au)tou= fra/sw; (or inform the coffin-makers of his insanity) Ar. Clouds 844 ff. The accuser charged Socrates with using the existence of this law as an argument that the ignorant could always be legally imprisoned by the more learned.
kai\ to\n pate/ra: even his father.
tekmhri/w|: as an indication, pred. appos. with tou/tw|. G. 916; H. 777 a.
desmeu/onta: sc. a)/llon tina/.
a)\n au)to\n dede/sqai: would himself be kept in prison.
ti/ diafe/rei mani/as a)maqi/a: discussed in iii. 9. 6.
e(autoi=s, fi/lois: depend on sumfero/ntws. G. 1174; H. 767.
para/: in the opinion of.— w(s ou)/te tou\s ka/mnontas ktl.: the Eng. idiom is best attained by preserving the Greek order of words and translating w)felou=sin as passive.
oi( sundikei=n e)pista/menoi: “their legal advisers.”
w(s o)/felos: sc. e)sti/.
ei) mh\ dunh/sontai: unless they are going to be able. For the ind. in fut. cond. of the ‘more vivid’ form, see G. 1387; H. 899.

e(rmhneu=sai: cf. Thuc. ii. 60, where Pericles says ou)deno\s oi)/omai h(/sswn ei)=nai gnw=nai/ te ta\ de/onta kai\ e(rmhneu=sai I think I am inferior to none in both seeing and explaining what ought to be done.
a)napei/qonta: by persuading.
diatiqe/nai: disposed. Cf. diatiqei/s An. i.1.5
mhdamou=: of no account. Cf. Plato Gorg. 456 C.
pro\s e(auto/n: in comparison with him.

oi)=da me/n: not correlative to e)/lege de/ of the next section. Rather in both sections is the assumption of the accuser admitted, and even reinforced by other assertions of Socrates which stand in close connection with it. This admission is introduced by oi)=da me/n, the implied contrast being anticipated from 55, viz., that the accuser wholly misconceived the meaning of the assertions cited. For me/n, see on i.1.1.
le/gonta: for the supplementary participle, see on i.2.14.
kai/, ge/: nay, even.
o(/ti a)fani/zousin: depends on le/gonta.

tou= oi)keiota/tou a)nqrw/pou: their nearest
kinsman.
a)fani/zousin: a term freq. used for burial. Cf. Soph. Ant. 255.

e(/kastos e(autou= ktl.: const. e(/kastos o(/ ti a)\n tou= sw/matos (o(\ e(autou= pa/ntwn ma/lista filei= which of all things belonging to himself he most loves) a)xrei=on h)=| kai\ a)nwfele/s, au)to/s te a)fairei= ktl.
pare/xei: permits, sc. a)fairei=n.
au)toi/ te/ ge au(tw=n a)fairou=si: men both themselves rid themselves of.
kai\ toi=s i)atroi=s ... a)pokai/ein: naturally refers only to tu/lous.
xa/rin: for the adv. acc., see on i.2.23.
ti/nein: in this sense, a)poti/nein or telei=n is more common.
e)no/n: sc. tw=| sw/mati.
e)pideiknu/wn: not correlative with dida/skwn, but belonging as a circumstantial participle of manner to pareka/lei.
tou= ei)=nai: for the articular inf., see on i.1.12.
tw=| oi)kei=os ei)=nai pisteu/wn: relying on his being a relation. For the nom., see on bi/a i. 2. 45.
a)melh=|: for the subjv. in final clauses, see G. 1365; H. 881.

56-64. The charge that Socrates spread immoral and pernicious doctrines by perverting passages from the poets is refuted by citing two quotations on which Socrates put a quite different interpretation from that imputed to him by the accuser: and is also sufficiently disproved by his blameless, unselfish, and patriotic life. To sum up, this man of pure character, this promoter of all that was good, deserved from the state, not death, but the highest honor.
56. e)klego/menon ... dida/skein: for the basis of fact underlying this distorted assertion, cf. i.6.14.

tw=n e)ndocota/twn poihtw=n: of the three divisions of instruction, gra/mmata, mousikh/, and gumnastikh/, the first-named, as a rule, included most of the formal instruction in language and literature received by the Greek boy at school. As soon as a boy had learned to read and write, he was ‘encouraged or compelled to learn by heart great masses of poetry, especially of Homer or Simonides, or the gnomic poets. Many a Greek knew by heart the whole of the Iliad and Odyssey.’ Gardner and Jevons, Manual of Greek Antiq., pp. 307, 308. Cf. Sym. iii. 5, 6.

tou/tois marturi/ois xrw/menon: cf. tekmhri/w| tou/tw| xrw/menos 49.—e)/rgon d) ou)de\n o)/neidos ktl.: from Hesiod's didactic poem Works and Days 311, where the reference is to agricultural labor only. The accuser seems to have perverted the sense of the verse by connecting ou)de/n with e)/rgon, whereas it belongs to o)/neidos.
a)ergi/h: with long penult. So Hom. w 251, kakoergi/hs x 374.
dh/: now, with resumptive force. So in 58; in both places dh/ has a somewhat fainter effect than, e.g., in 24.
e)pei\ diomologh/saito: for the opt., see on me/lloi i. 1. 10.
to\ me\n e)rga/thn ei)=nai: subj. of w)fe/limo/n te kai\ a)gaqo\n ei)=nai.
to\ de\ a)rgo/n: sc. ei)=nai.
a)peka/lei: see on i.2.6.
e)k de\ tou/twn: “and with this interpretation.”
o(/n tina me\n basilh=a ktl.: the verses are from Hom. B 188-191, and 198-202, and depict Odysseus repressing the tumult among the Achaeans.
kixei/h: for the opt., cf. diomologh/saito 57.
e)pe/essin: Epic for e)/pesin.
e)rhtu/saske: for the form, see G. 778, 1298; H. 493.
w(/s: for the accent, see G. 138, 2; H. 112 b.
se/o: for the form, see G. 393; H. 261 D.
e)chgei=sqai, w(s: interpreted, to the effect that.

dhmo/tas: of Greek prose writers only Herodotus and Xenophon use dhmo/ths in the sense of ‘a common man,’ the usual Attic word for which is dhmotiko/s. In 60, however, dhmotiko/s is equivalent to popularis, a friend of the people.

ou(/tw g' a)\n w)/|eto: in that case he would have been thinking, i.e. “would have been forced to think,” as Socrates himself was one of the pe/nhtes. For the impf., see on i.1.5; and for the meaning of pe/nhtas, cf. the discussion between Socrates and Euthydemus iv. 2. 37 ff.—a)lla\ dei=n ktl.: “he who neither in war nor in public life can serve the state or be useful to the people should be kept out of public and military life.”

a)/llws te: and especially, not to be confused with the similar and more common a)/llws
te kai/ both in other respects, and particularly.
ta)nanti/a tou/twn: sc. tw=n qrase/wn kai\ tw=| dh/mw| bohqei=n mh\ i(kanw=n. ta)nanti/a is adv., and takes the gen. after the analogy of certain adjs. of place. G. 1146; H. 754 f.
e)piqumhta/s: eager followers.
a)stou/s, ce/nous: in partitive appos. with e)piqumhta/s. G. 914; H. 624 d.
ou)de/na, misqo/n: for the double acc., see on 5.
sunousi/as: cf. 39.
tw=n e(autou=: “of his own good things.”
w(=n tines: Aristippus of Cyrene was the first of Socrates's followers to demand pay for his services. Cf. Diog. Laert. ii. 65.
xrh/mata dido/nai: for the limiting inf. with nouns, see G. 1530; H. 952.
pro\s tou\s a)/llous a)nqrw/pous: in his relations to other men. Cf. kai\ pro\s fi/lous de\ kai\ ce/nous i. 3. 3.

*li/xas: acc. to Plutarch (Cim. 10), Lichas was renowned for his hospitality toward strangers who visited Sparta at the festival of the Gymnopaedia, when naked youths danced and sang round the statue of Apollo Carneius, in honor of the Spartans who fell at the battle of Thyrea.
gumnopaidi/ais: for the dat. of time, see G. 1192; H. 782.
ta\ me/gista, tou\s boulome/nous: for the double acc., see on th\n po/lin 12.

poiw=n: equiv. to impf. e)poi/ei, the action being regarded as freq. repeated. Here, as often, the partic. contains the main thought, the finite verb the subord.
one. Cf. tou/tous eu)= poih/santes a)pope/mpete Cyr. viii. 7. 27.
e)moi\ dh\ ktl.: with allusion to i. 1. 1, where see on me/n and th=| po/lei.
kai\ de/: see on ka)kei=nos de/ i. 1. 3.
tou/tois: refers, by ‘synesis,’ to the collective ti\s. H. 633. Cf. e(/kastos, au)toi/ 54.
qa/natos: for the omission of the art. with a pred. noun or adj., see G. 956; H. 669.
a)lla\ mh/n: see on i.1.6.

pole/mou kakw=s sumba/ntos: of a war's turning out badly. The participle contains the main idea, and the whole phrase may be conveniently const. as objective gen. with ai)/tios. G. 1139, 1140; H. 753, and e. Cf. the acc. with prep. in such phrases as meta\ *ku=ron qano/nta after Cyrus's death, and the Lat. ab urbe condita.
e)/noxos ei)/h: be liable to (lit. held in).
o(/s: see on 1.
nomi/zein: as in i. 1. 1.
ge/grapto: stood charged. The aug. omitted, as freq. with the plpf. in prose, apparently for the sake of euphony.
o(/, au)to/n: for the double acc., see G. 1076; H. 725. Cf. ou)k ai)tiw=mai ta/de to\n qeo/n Cyr. vii. 2. 22, to\ geno/menon to\ qei=on ai)tia=sqai Hell. vii.5.12

eu)= oi)kou=si: are prosperous. Cf.
poi=ai de\ po/leis nomi/mws a)\n oi)kh/seian; Cyr. viii. 1. 2. In Homer, the meaning of naieta=n, nai/ein is, in like manner, weakened to something like ei)=nai.
mega/lhs timh=s: such as the reward suggested in Plato Apol. 36D.
a)/cios th=| po/lei: as in i. 1. 1.

div2.p: In the two preceding chapters it was shown that Socrates did not influence his followers to their injury (negative proof); in what follows, it is shown in detail that he understood how to encourage them in all that is good, by word and example (positive proof). His piety is first depicted, and especially the manner in which he would have the gods honored; afterwards, his temperance in all bodily pleasures is described.

div3.p: w(s, dh/: (to show) that, really.
kai\ w)felei=n: even to be aiding, not only to be abstaining from injuring.
ta\ me/n, ta\ de/: partly, partly. G. 982; H. 654 b.
deiknu/wn e(auto/n, oi(=os h)=n: for the ‘prolepsis,’ see on sunousi/an i. 2. 13.
diamnhmoneu/sw: for the mode, see G. 1434; H. 916.
ta\ me\n toi/nun: toi/nun indicates the transition to the detailed discussion of what has been announced; me/n introduces the first part of the discussion, and de/ at the beginning of 5, the second.

h( *puqi/a: the Pythia, the priestess of Apollo at Delphi. For an account of the oracles in general, and the Delphic oracle in particular, see Gardner and Jevons, Manual of Greek Antiq., pp. 106, 107, 264, 265.
pw=s: see on ti/si i. 1. 1.
progo/nwn qerapei/as: for the place of ancestor worship in Greek religion, see Gardner and Jevons, p. 72 ff.
h(/ te ga\r *puqi/a, *swkra/ths te: “for as the Pythia, so Socrates.” Cf. e)gw/ te ga/r, ai(/ te po/leis ii. 1. 9.
a)nairei=: the technical term for the answers of the Pythia. Cf. kai\ a)nei=len au)tw=| o( *)apo/llwn qeoi=s oi(=s e)/dei qu/ein An. iii.1.16

parh/|nei: sc. poiei=n. Cf. Deinceps in lege est, ut de ritibus patriis colantur optimi: de quo cum consulerent Athenienses Apollinem
Pythium, quas potissimum religiones (rites) tenerent, oraculum editum est, eas quae essent in more maiorum Cic. de Legg. ii. 15. 40.
eu)/xeto pro\s tou\s qeou/s: eu)/xesqai pro/s tina is usual when an inf. follows. Kr. Spr. 48. 7. 14. Cf. *ce/rchs eu)/xeto pro\s to\n h(/lion Hdt. vii. 54.

w(s ei)do/tas: see on w(s proshmai/nontos i. 1. 4. tou\s qeou/s is purposely repeated. For the thought, cf. Socrates, inquit, nihil ultra petendum a diis immortalibus arbitrabatur, quam quid unicuique esset utile, nos autem id plerumque votis expetere, quod non impetrasse melius foret Valer. Max. vii. 2.
ei) eu)/xointo: for the ellipsis of the apod., see G. 1420; H. 905 a, 3.
o(/pws a)pobh/soito: depends on a)dh/lwn (sc. o)/ntwn). See on i. 1. 6.
meiou=sqai: fall short of.
kalw=s e)/xein: without a)/n, after the analogy of kalw=s ei)=xe, kalo\n h)=n, e)ch=n, etc. See G. 1400; H. 897.
ei) e)/xairon: for the impf. in dependent clauses of indirect discourse, see GMT. 691; H. 936.
a)\n ei)=nai kexarisme/na: sc. ei) e)/xairon.

ka\d du/namin: equivalent to kata\ du/namin. For the ‘apocope’ and ‘assimilation,’ see G. 53; H. 84D. The verse is from Hesiod
Works and Days 336.
th\n a)/llhn di/aitan: “our other relations in life.” th\n ka\d du/namin d' e)/rdein: the admonition (parai/nesin) to act according to our powers. Cf. to\ gnw=qi sauto/n iv. 2. 24.
ei) do/ceien au)tw=|: “as often as it seemed to him.” See on e)pei/ i. 2. 57.
a)\n e)pei/sqh: the prot. really suggested by this apod. is ei)/ tis au)to\n e)/peiqen, if any one tried to persuade him; and this prot. is found, without its apod., in the next sentence.
e)/peiqen: impf. of attempted and continued past action.
tw=n a)/llwn: for the gen. with compounds of kata/, see G. 1123; H. 752.
pa/nta, u(perew/ra: see on i.2.9.
pro/s: in comparison with, as in i. 2. 52. The Lat. ad is used in the same sense.
xrw/menos: for the participle of cond., see on le/gwn i. 1. 20.
ti\ daimo/nion: “something extraordinary.” Cf. h)\n mh/ ti daimo/nion kwlu/h| Eq. xi. 13. For the two prots. with same apod., see GMT. 510.
kai\ ou)k a)\n ... dapa/nhs: and would not lack the means for such an outlay. For the gen. of plenty or want, see G. 1112; H. 743.
eu)telh/s (sc. h( di/aita): frugal.
ou)k oi)=d' ei)/ tis: “scarcely any one.”
e)rga/zoito: would work for, potential optative. For e)rga/zomai in this sense, cf. ta\ e)pith/deia e)rga/zesqai ii. 8. 2.
w(/ste mh\ lamba/nein: for the inf. of result, see G. 1450; H. 953.
ta\ *swkra/tei a)rkou=nta: what sufficed for Socrates. For the thought, cf. i.6.4.
h(de/ws: with relish. Cf. h(/dista e)sqi/wn i. 6. 5.
e)pi\ tou=to: i.e. e)pi\ to\ e)sqi/ein.

th\n e)piqumi/an o)/yon ei)=nai: cf. limw=| de\ o(/saper o)/yw| diaxrh=sqe Cyr. i. 5. 12. Cf. the Lat. proverb fames optimum condimentum. Athenaeus (4, p. 157) describes Socrates as taking long walks in the evening, ‘to collect,’ as he said, ‘sauce (o)/yon) for his supper.’
dia\ to\ pi/nein: see on e)pi\ to\ fronti/zein i. 1. 12.
o(/: precedes its grammatical antec. tou=to.

w(/ste fula/casqai: namely, to guard against, added in explanation of the rel. clause. For w(/ste with the inf., instead of the simple inf. as subj., see GMT. 588.— ta\ pei/qonta ktl.: “tempting dishes.” Cf. o( *swkra/ths parakeleuo/menos fula/ttesqai tw=n brwma/twn o(/sa mh\ peinw=ntas e)sqi/ein a)napei/qei (as persuade those who are not hungry to eat) Plut. Mor. 128 D. For e)sqi/ein and pi/nein as objs. of pei/qonta, see G. 1519; H. 948.
th\n *ki/rkhn: the famous sorceress who bewitched the companions of Odysseus. Cf. Hom. k 229 ff.
tou\s pollou/s: opposed to to\n *)odusse/a. For the double acc. with poiei=n, see G. 1077; H. 726.
u(poqhmosu/nh|: Ionic for sumboulh=|, like u(poti/qesqai for sumbouleu/ein.
o)/nta: causal.
tou= a(/ptesqai: for the gen. of the articular inf. with verbs of hindering or freedom, see G. 1549; H. 963.
dia\ tau=ta: like ei)=ta, e)/peita, ou(/tws, often used after participles to bring out the relation (in this case a causal one) of these to the main verb. GMT. 857; H. 976 b.

e)/paizen a(/ma spouda/zwn: “he used to say jestingly but with an earnest inner meaning.” See on
iv. 1. 1.
tw=n kalw=n: limiting gen. with a)frodisi/wn. G. 1085; H. 729. Cf. toi=s tw=n w(rai/wn a)frodisi/ois h(do/menoi ii. 6. 22.
a(pto/menon: see on pisteu/wn i. 1. 5.
a)lla\ kai/: atque adeo.

*krito/boulon: for the ‘prolepsis,’ see on i.2.13. In Oec. ii. 7, Socrates says to Critobulus o(rw= se oi)o/menon ploutei=n kai\ a)melw=s me\n e)/xonta pro\s to\ mhxana=sqai xrh/mata, paidikoi=s de pra/gmasi prose/xonta to\n nou=n (giving your mind to frivolous matters).

to\n *)alkibia/dou ui(o/n: as Alcibiades, so far as known, had but one son, born in 416, after the probable date of this conversation, it has been conjectured that both here and in 10 the reference is to Clinias, the son of Axiochus and a cousin of Alcibiades. Cf. Sym. iv. 12.
ei)pe/: for the accent, see on i.2.41.
a)nqrw/pwn: for the partitive pred. gen., see on tw=n tria/konta i. 2. 31.
r(iyokindu/nwn: foolhardy, lit. hurlers of risks.

lewrgo/taton: one who will do anything, hence most reckless.—ei)s maxai/ras ktl.: proverbial expressions for incurring great risks. Cf. dokei= ou)=n moi ei)s maxai/ras kubista=n kindu/nou e)pi/deigma (an exhibition) ei)=nai, o(\ sumposi/w| ou)de\n prosh/kei Sym. vii. 3.
ei)s pu=r a(/loito: cf. e)gw\ meta\ *kleini/ou ka)\n dia\ puro\s i)oi/hn Sym. iv. 16.
ti/: obj. of poiou=nta.
toiau=ta kate/gnwkas au)tou=: have you formed such a bad opinion of him. For the gen. and acc. with compounds of kata/, cf. 4.
ou) ga/r: in a question containing a quick retort, as in ii. 3. 16.
a)ll' ei) me/ntoi: at si profecto.

to\
r(iyoki/ndunon e)/rgon: “what you have just described as a foolhardy act.” to/ is equivalent to illud.
a)\n u(pomei=nai: see on a)/n pote kinhqh=nai i. 1. 14.

a)=r' ou)k: For the interr. particle, see G. 1603; H. 1015.— pollh\n de\ a)sxoli/an ktl.: “to have no leisure for giving attention to any noble or honorable thing,” lit. to have great lack of leisure. For the gen. of the articular inf., see GMT. 798; H. 959.
e)f' oi(=s: sc. e)pi\ tou/tois as antecedent. e)pi/ with the dat. here denotes the motive or end in view. See G. 1210, 2 c; H. 799, 2 c.
maino/menos: for the omission of the art. with a subst. participle, see G. 1560, 2; H. 966.
*(hra/kleis: for the decl., see on *peri/kleis i. 2. 41.
w(s deinh/n tina: what a terrible sort of thing. ti\s, like Lat. quidam, may be added to adjs. to express indefiniteness of nature. G. 1016; H. 702.
ta\ fala/ggia: for the generic art., see G. 950; H. 659.
o)/nta: concessive.
tou= fronei=n e)ci/sthsi: mente destituit, deprives of reason. Cf. e)cista/menoi tou= a)nalogi/zesqai ii. 1. 4.
e)ni/hsi, kata\ to\ dh=gma: inject along with their bite.
tou\s de\ kalou\s ktl.: with ellipsis of the correlative me/n clause ta\ me\n fala/ggia e)nie/nai ti le/geis. Cf. ou) d' w)/|ou iii. 3. 11.
qhri/on: for the application of this term to human beings, cf. iii.11.11.

tosou/tw|
deino/teron, o(/sw|: as much more dangerous, in proportion as. In the clauses introduced by o(/sw| there is another comparison, between the easier method of avoiding (suggested by a(ya/mena), and the more difficult one (suggested by ou)d' a(pto/menon): Cf. Cyr. vi. 2. 19.
e)kei=na, tou=to: tou=to sometimes, as here, refers to what is nearer in importance to the speaker, though more remote in the sentence. e)kei=na, therefore, refers to tw=n falaggi/wn.
kai/: refers back to the advice given in 6, which here finds its application to sensual pleasures. For the thought, cf. Sym. iv. 38.
a)frodisia/zein: const. with pro\s toiau=ta.
ou(/tw pareskeuasme/nos h)=n: sic paratam sententiam habebat.
a)\n h(/desqai: see on a)\n kinhqh=nai i. 1. 14.
lupei=sqai: sc. a)/n.

div2.p: In a conversation with Aristodemus, Socrates shows that there are gods: they have given to man powers of mind and body admirably adapted to his needs: and they will care for his welfare, if he will only honor them. Whoever is thoroughly convinced of this is lastingly won to virtue. So Socrates understood not only to\ protre/pein, but also to\ proa/gein e)p' a)reth/n.

div3.p: tekmairo/menoi: “conjecturing, on superficial observation,” without obj., as in Cyr. i. 3. 5.

protre/yasqai: that Socrates regarded the most important step as taken when enthusiasm for virtue had been aroused, is stated by several writers, e.g., Plut. Mor. p. 798 B, Plato Rep. i. 336. Cf. ut Socratem illum solitum aiunt dicere, perfectum sibi opus esse, si quis satis esset concitatus cohortatione sua ad studium cognoscendae percipiendaeque virtutis: quibus enim id persuasum esset, ut nihil mallent se esse quam bonos viros, iis reliquam facilem esse doctrinam Cic. de Or. i. 47.
skeya/menoi, dokimazo/ntwn: “let them first examine, and then decide.”
