mh/: instead of ou), as the participle is subordinated to the imv. dokimazo/ntwn. G. 1614; H. 1027.
a(\ e)rwtw=n h)/legxen: the questions by which he used to refute, e.g., iii. 6, iv. 2.
sundiatri/bousi: see on tw=n suno/ntwn i. 1. 4.
ei) h)=n: for the mode, see G. 1487; H. 932.
a(/ pote au)tou= h)/kousa dialegome/nou: a conversation of his that I once heard. For the supplementary participle, see on i.1.11.
tou= daimoni/ou: the Deity, as manifested to men.

*)aristo/dhmon: afterward a warm friend of Socrates; cf. *)aristo/dhmos h)=n tis, *kudaqhnaieu/s, smikro/s, a)nupo/dhtos a)ei/, *swkra/tous e)rasth\s w)\n e)n toi=s ma/lista tw=n to/te Plato Sym. 173 B.
qu/onta: for the supplementary participle in indirect discourse, cf. i.2.14.
a)lla\ kai/: but even.
tw=n poiou/ntwn: for the gen., cf. tw=n a)/llwn i. 3. 4.
e)/stin ou(/stinas: equivalent to a)=ra e)ni/ous. G. 1029; H. 998 c.
teqau/makas: admire, i.e. “have come to admire.”
sofi/a|: genius.
kai\ o(/s: and he. For the rel. in its original dem. meaning, see G. 1023, 2; H. 275 b.
toi/nun: well then.
e)pw=n poih/sei: epic poetry.
diqura/mbw|: often in pl., like i)/amboi, a)na/paistoi, hence some editors read e)pi\ de\ diqura/mbwn (sc. poih/sei).
*melanippi/dhn: there were two lyric poets of this name, grandfather and grandson, both of the island Melos. The younger was a contemporary of Socrates, and is prob. the one here meant.
*sofokle/a: the famous tragic poet of Athens, 495-406 B.C.
*polu/kleiton: the sculptor, of Sicyon, who flourished about 430 B.C. and was celebrated for his statues of athletes.
*zeu=cin: the painter, of Heraclea in Magna Graecia, of about the same date. For an account of these artists, see Tarbell's History of Greek Art.
po/tera, h)/: for the use of particles in alternative questions, see G. 1606; H. 1017. po/tera is omitted in translation.

ei)/per ge: an emphatic if indeed, intimating that Aristodemus reserves decision on this point. Cf. kai\ ei)/per ge/ tinas de/oi, peri\ th=s a)naire/sews ou)de/na ma=llon e)/xein au)tou\s ai)tia/sasqai h)\ tou/tous, oi(=s proseta/xqh and if blame should attach to any one with regard to the failure to rescue (the shipwrecked crews, after the battle of the Arginusae), they could hold no one more responsible than those to whom this duty had been assigned Hell. i. 7. 6.
tu/xh| tini/: obs. the difference between the dat. of means and a)po\ gnw/mhs, which suggests a creative agency.

tw=n ... e)xo/ntwn ... e)/sti: of those things which afford no indication of the purpose for which they exist. Cf. a)dh/lwn o(/pws a)pobh/soito i. 1. 6. The gens. tw=n e)xo/ntwn and tw=n o)/ntwn depend respectively upon the pronominal adjs. po/tera, po/tera.
pre/pei me/n: it certainly stands to reason, with the inf. ei)=nai as subj. of pre/pei. For me/n with the force of mh/n, see H. 1037, 12.
ou)/koun: nonne igitur. For the distinction between ou)/koun and ou)kou=n, see on ii.1.3.
e)p' w)felei/a| prosqei=nai au)toi=s: bestowed upon them for a useful purpose.
di) w(=n ai)sqa/nontai e(/kasta: the organs through which they perceive different objects. For the omission of the antec., see on i.2.19.
o)fqalmou/s, w)=ta: for the partitive appos., see on i.2.60.
o)smw=n: subjective gen. with o)/felos. G. 1085, 2; H. 729 b.
ge\ mh/n: further, employed here to avoid the monotony of a too frequent repetition of de/.
ei) mh\ prosete/qhsan: for the supposition contrary to fact, see G. 1397; H. 895.
o)/felos: for defective nouns, see G. 289; H. 215 b.
tw=n dia\ sto/matos h(de/wn: “things pleasant to the taste.”
gnw/mwn: a critic (not to be confused with gnwmw=n). Cf. Eng. ‘gnomon’ of a sundial. For the pred. nom., see G. 907; H. 614.

ou) dokei= soi ktl.: do you not think that the following things also resemble works of design? ta/de introduces the infs. with to/ as far as a)pogeisw=sai, and the remaining infs., beginning with to\ de/xesqai, are summed up in tau=ta ou(/tw pepragme/na.
to\ blefa/rois au)th\n qurw=sai: the providing it with a door of eyelids, lit. dooring it with eyelids. Similarly a)pogeisw=sai below. For the denominative verbs, cf. futeusame/nw| i. 1. 8.
au)th=| xrh=sqai/ ti: to use it for any purpose. For the neut. pron. with xra/omai and the dat. of means, see H. 777 a.
w(s a)/n: for a)/n in final clauses, see G. 1367; H. 882.
h(qmo/n: as a screen, pred. accusative.
zw/|ois: dat. of possessor. H. 768 b.
oi(/ous: i.e. toiou/tous, w(/ste. For oi(=os alone with the inf., see G. 1526, last example; H. 1000.
tou\s gomfi/ous: the molars.
para\ tou/twn decame/nous leai/nein: to receive it (the food) from these, and masticate it.
kataqei=nai: placing, with resumption of the subj. of qurw=sai and a)pogeisw=sai. Here, as in 11, the Creator is thought of as an artist who arranges at will the materials before him.
e)pei\ dusxerh=: sc. e)sti/.
a)postre/yai kai\ a)penegkei=n: turning away and removing.
h(=| dunato/n proswta/tw: quantum fieri potest remotissime.
ou) ma\ to\n *di/a: sc. a)porw=. For the particles of swearing, cf. i.2.9.
ou(/tw ge skopoume/nw| (sc. tini/): to any one considering it from that point of view. For the dat. of relation, see on th=| po/lei i. 1. 1.
texnh/masi: contrivances.
to\ de\ e)mfu=sai: the omitted pred. (ti/ni tau=ta e)/oike;) of this sent. may be readily anticipated from the answer.
a)me/lei: originally an imv. equivalent to feel no anxiety, hence, as adv., assuredly.
mhxanh/masi: not essentially different from texnh/masi.
tino\s zw=|a ktl.: of one who has determined the existence of living beings.

Aristodemus has now conceded the existence of a being who, with wise forethought, has provided men with admirably contrived bodies and the impulse toward propagation and support of offspring. In this section, he is shown that the
existence of gods may also be inferred from the intellectual nature of man. As the component elements (gh= and u(gro/n) of our bodies have been obtained from an external material universe, so our reason may be supposed to be a part of a Reason to be sought beyond ourselves; in default of whose presence and power the world of order could owe its existence to blind chance only. In opening this line of thought, Socrates begins with the abrupt question su\ de\ sauto\n dokei=s ti fro/nimon e)/xein; to which Aristodemus, not seeing the connection of this with the preceding discussion, cautiously answers: ‘Well, ask on, and I will answer.’ The substance of the passage is given by Cicero, Pro Mil. 31. 84. Cf. also his De Nat. Deor. ii. 6, Plato Philebus 30 A.

kai\ tau=ta, ei)dw/s: and that too, although you know. For the participle, see on kekthme/nos i. 2. 1.—nou=n de\ mo/non ktl.: but mind alone then, which does not exist elsewhere, you think that you have caught up by some lucky chance? Cf. unde enim hanc mentem homo arripuit? ut ait apud Xenophontem Socrates Cic. de Nat. Deor. ii. 6. 18.

ma\ *di/a: certainly, i.e. “I do not believe in an overruling intelligence.” ma\ *di/a, instead of ou) ma\ *di/a, may be used when a neg. precedes (as here a)/lloqi ou)damou= ou)de\n ei)=nai), or follows, or is implied in the context.

ou)de\ ga/r: why, neither. ga/r, in an answer, generally refers to an assertion implied in the question or statement preceding, or readily supplied from the connection, as here ou)x o(ra=s tou\s kuri/ous: ou)de\ ga\r ktl. Cf. i.3.10, ii. 1. 2.
kata/ ge tou=to: according to this reasoning, at least. For the position of ge/, see H. 1037, 1 a. Cf. h)/kousen ou)dei\s e)/n ge tw=| fanerw=| An. i.3.21
to\ daimo/nion: the Deity, as in 2.
e)kei=no: expressing remoteness, hence chosen instead of au)to/.
h)\ w(s: equivalent to h)\ w(/ste, cf. iii.5.17. For w(s and the inf. after the comparative with h)/, see G. 1458; H. 954.

ou)/koun: as in 5.—o(/sw| megaloprepe/steron ktl.: the more magnificent he is and yet deigns to care for you. The very sublimity of the Deity, taken with his benevolence, is an additional reason for honoring him, and not an excuse for ignoring him.
ei) nomi/zoimi, ou)k a)\n a)meloi/hn: for fut. conds. of the less vivid form, see G. 1408; H. 900.
fronti/zein: the omitted subj. (au)tou/s) is unmistakably suggested by the preceding au)tw=n.
oi(/: see on o(/s i. 2. 1.
mo/non tw=n zw/|wn: alone among living beings.
a)ne/sthsan: 1 aor., the trans. use. For trans. and intr. senses in the same verb, see G. 1231; H. 500, and a.
ple/on: belongs to proora=n.
e)/peita: without de/, as ei)=ta in i. 2. 1.
e(rpetoi=s: elsewhere used for zw=|a chiefly by the poets. Cf. o(/ss' e)pi\ gai=an | e(rpeta\ gi/gnontai kai\ u(/dwr kai\ qespidae\s pu=r Hom. d 418.
oi(=s: for the dative of means, see G. 1181; H. 776.
e)kei/nwn: i.e. tw=n e(rpetw=n.
kai\ mh/n: ac profecto, and further. See on a)lla\ mh/n i. 1. 6.
oi(/an: capable. See on oi(/ous 6.— a)/llote a)llaxh=| ktl.: cf. (lingua) sonos vocis distinctos et pressos efficit, cum et ad dentes et ad alias partes pellit oris Cic. de Nat. Deor. ii. 59. 149.
sto/matos: for the gen. with verbs of touching, see G. 1099; H. 738.
a)rqrou=n fwnh/n: to produce articulate speech.

kai\ shmai/nein: i.e.
kai\ w(/ste h(ma=s shmai/nein, the subj. of the inf. being anticipated from a)llh/lois and boulo/meqa.
to\ de\ dou=nai ktl.: sc. ou) qaumasto/n e)stin;
tau=ta: refers to ta\s h(dona/s, the neut. generalizing the conception. Cf. dei= pro\s tau=ta (sc. e)piqumi/as) ou)k h(=tton diama/xesqai Oec. i. 23.
toi/nun: further. For toi/nun as a particle of transition, see Kr. Spr. 69. 62.
mo/non: the usual position of mo/non belonging to the inf., when the latter is preceded by ou)k a)rkei=. Cf. Cyr. viii. 8. 16, 17.
krati/sthn: as supreme. For the pred. position of the adj., see G. 971; H. 670.
e)ne/fuse: implanted, as in 7.
yuxh/: “intelligence.”
prw=ta me/n: rarer than prw=ton me/n, and followed here by de/ only, instead of e)/ti de/, or e)/peita.
qew=n h)/|sqhtai, o(/ti ei)si/: has perceived that the gods exist, lit. has perceived the gods that they exist. For the ‘prolepsis,’ see on sunousi/an i. 2. 13.
fu=lon: race.
qerapeu/ousi: for the pl. after a collective subj., see G. 900; H. 609.
yu/xh, qa/lph: pl. in abstract sense. H. 636.
i(kanwte/ra e)sti/: the closing of a sent. with a question which recalls the beginning, and repeats its words, is common with Xenophon, e.g., ii. 1. 8; Hell. iv.4.12; Oec. ii. 15.
para/: in comparison with. G. 1213, 3 d; H. 802, 3 c.
fu/sei: by nature. For the dat. of manner, see reference on oi(=s 11.
kai/, kai/: correlative, and subordinating the two dats. sw/mati and yuxh=| to fu/sei.

kratisteu/ontes: “being lords of
creation.”

a)
 e)/xwn, e)du/nat' a)/n: for the cond., see on ei) prosete/qhsan 5, and, for the partic. containing a prot., on i. 1. 20. For the repetition of a)/n, see G. 1312; H. 864. Cf. labw
 d' a)
 to
 i(/ppon e)k tou= paraxrh=ma a)
 e)strateu/eto Hell. vi.4.11
a(\ e)bou/leto: quae vellet (not volebat). For the assimilation of the mode in cond. rel. sents., see G. 1440; H. 919 b. Cf. iii.5.8.
e)/xei, e)sti/: ind., as Socrates is now speaking of animals that really exist, e.g., apes.
ple/on ou)de\n e)/xei: have no advantage.
a)mfote/rwn: i.e. sw/matos and yuxh=s.
o(/tan ti/ poih/swsi nomiei=s: when they do what, will you think? i.e. “what must they do to make you think?” For the interr. depending on a dependent word, see H. 1012.

sumbou/lous: Aristodemus is thinking of the daimo/nion of Socrates, of which he has no very clear conception, and uses sumbou/lous, perhaps with a touch of irony, for the impersonal sumboulh/n, advisers instead of “advice.”—o(/ ti xrh\ poiei=n ktl.: the clause may be taken as obj. of the verbal idea in sumbou/lous.
*)aqhnai/ois, *(/ellhsi, pa=sin a)nqrw/pois: an ascending climax.
punqanome/nois: inquiring.
a)lla/ ... katati/qentai: the change from indirect to direct discourse adds to the sarcastic emphasis, “but they select you alone, do they, and leave you in neglect?”
a)\n e)mfu=sai: for examples of the inf. with a)/n in indirect discourse, see G. 1308; H. 964 b. Cf. iii.5.2.
w(s: that, depends on do/can belief.
kai/ (before tou\s a)nqrw/pous): or, since e)capatwme/nous suggests an alternative condition.
dunatoi/: sc. eu)= kai\ kakw=s poiei=n.

poluxroniw/tata:
most time-honored.
qew=n: for the gen., see references on gastro/s i. 2. 1.
e)/fh: he continued, the speaker remaining unchanged, Lat. inquit.
e)nw/n: sc. e)n tw=| sw/mati. Cf. e)no/n i. 2. 54.
o(/pws a)\n au)th=| h(du\ h)=|: as it pleases.
metaxeiri/zetai: administrat, manages.
ou)=n: so, then, “in like manner.”
kai\ mh/: sc. xrh\ oi)/esqai, which is also to be supplied with the following mhde/.

to\ so\n me\n o)/mma: that, while your eye. The neg. mh/ grammatically attaches to the whole of the following sent., but really belongs only to the second inf. in each pair (o(ra=n, e)pimelei=sqai), the me/n clauses being really subordinate; i.e. “you must not believe only in your own vision and intelligence, but must infer from them those of the Deity.” For a similar use of the a fortiori argument, cf. Plato Apol. 28D, E.
h)/n: introduces the subjv. lamba/nh|s, the sent. from w(/sper to froni/mous being parenthetical.
qerapeu/wn: by serving.
qew=n: obj. gen. with pei=ran. G. 1085, 3; H. 729 c.
ei): whether. G. 1605; H. 1016. On the thought of the passage, cf. i.1.9.
tw=n a)dh/lwn a)nqrw/pois: sc. o)/ntwn. Cf. i.1.6.
gnw/sh| to\ qei=on, o(/ti e)sti/n: ‘prolepsis.’ Cf. 13, and sunousi/an i. 2. 13.
e)moi\ me\n ou)=n ktl.: sums up the chapter, as in i. 1. 20, 2. 62, et al.
ou) mo/non: belongs to o(po/te o(rw=nto. See on mo/non 13.
a)pe/xesqai: depends on poiei=n.

e)pei/per h(gh/sainto: since (as we have seen) they had come to believe. For the opt. in causal sents., see GMT. 714; H. 925 b. For the thought, cf. the injunctions of Christ against ostentatious almsgiving and praying ‘to be seen of men,’ Matt. vi. 1-18.

div2.p: Self-control is the foundation of every virtue recommended and practiced by Socrates.

div3.p: ei) dh/: si iam, introduces a settled and recognized fact.
ei) prou)bi/baze: whether he led (his friends) forward. For ei) with indir. question, cf. i.4.18.
ei)s tau/thn (sc. e)gkra/teian): connect with prou)bi/baze. For the dislocation of the usual order (‘hyperbaton’), see H. 1062.
w)= a)/ndres: there was evidently a circle of hearers. So in 6. 1, paro/ntwn au)tw=n.
o(/ntina: equivalent to ei)/ tina.
ai)sqanoi/meqa: for the assimilation of the cond. rel. clause, see G. 1439; H. 919 a.
h(/ttw (sc. o)/nta): “one who is not master of.” For Socrates's self-control in these matters, cf. 3.

sw=sai, krath=sai: save, conquer. The aor. shows that the actions are conceived without reference to a def. time or duration. GMT. 127, Kr. Spr. 53. 6. 9. kratei=n (tina) is equivalent to conquer, kratei=n (tinos) to have control.
paideu=sai: for the inf. expressing a purpose, see G. 1532; H. 951.
diafula/cai, diasw=sai: obs. the force of dia/ in composition, thoroughly, to the end.
h(ghso/meqa: the fut. ind. in apod. breaks the monotony of the repeated opts. with a)/n.
to\n a)krath=: the man without self-control.
e)/rgwn e)pistasi/an: supervision of works.
a)gorasth/n: the terim for the slave who went to market. For the formation of nouns denoting the agent, see G. 833; H. 550.
toiou=ton: i.e. to\n a)krath=.
a)lla\ mh\n ei): atqui si, and yet
ei) decai/meq' a)/n: for the potential opt. (with a)/n) in a cond., see G. 1421, 3; H. 900 a.
au)to/n: a man himself, subj. of fula/casqai. Not in the pl., although decai/meqa precedes, as au)to/s indicates the master, in contrast with dou=lon in the previous clauses.
gene/sqai: for the inf. with verbs of caution, see GMT. 374; H. 948.
kakou=rgos, kakourgo/teros, kakourgo/tatos: obs. the climax, heightened in rhetorical effect by the chiastic order of the first two clauses.
to\n oi)=kon to\n e(autou=: one's own house.
o(\n ei)dei/h: for the assimilation of the mode, see on ai)sqanoi/meqa in 1.
a)=ra ge ou)/: nonne certe.
h(ghsa/menon: for the participle of cond., see on pisteu/wn i. 1. 5.
ou)k ai)sxrw=s diateqei/h: would not be put into a shameful condition. So diakei=sqai in i. 1. 13.
nh\ th\n *(/hran: an expression used by women, and, among men, apparently used by Socrates only. Cf. iii.10.9, 11. 5, iv. 2. 9, 4. 8.

douleu/onta: sc. tina/. The dat. is the usual case for the agent with verbals in -te/os. When the acc. was used, it was perhaps because the verbal was regarded as equivalent to dei= with the infinitive. G. 1188; H. 991 a.
despotw=n a)gaqw=n: i.e. masters who set their servants a good example (Kühner). Cf. Oec. i. 23.
toiau=ta de\ le/gwn ktl.: “his practice was even better than his preaching.”
tw=n dia\ tou= sw/matos h(de/wn: cf. tw=n dia\ sto/matos h(de/wn i. 4. 5.

para\ tou= tuxo/ntos: from any one who happened along. Cf. i. 2. 6, and see on i.1.14.—despo/thn e(autou= ktl.: was establishing a master over himself; and entering upon a slavery than which none is more shameful. For the special form of ‘litotes’ involved in ou)demia=s h(=tton ai)sxro/n, cf. iv.2.12. Cf. also ou)damw=n ei)si kaki/ones a)ndrw=n Hdt. vii. 104. Kr. Spr. 47. 27. 3.

div2.p: 1-10. In a conversation with Antiphon, Socrates defends himself against the charge that his simple mode of life makes him and those who imitate him unhappy rather than happy.

div3.p: au)tou=: depends on a(\ diele/xqh “those conversations of his.” H. 733.

*)antifw=nta: described by Suidas as follows: *)antifw=n *)aqhnai=os, teratosko/pos kai\ e)popoio\s kai\ sofisth/s,
e)kalei=to de\ logoma/geiros. He was the author of a work on the interpretation of dreams which had considerable reputation. Cf. de quibus (somniis) disputans Chrysippus multis et minutis somniis colligendis facit idem quod Antipater, ea conquirens, quae Antiphontis interpretatione explicata declarant illa quidem acumen interpretis, sed exemplis grandioribus decuit uti Cic. de Div. i. 20. He should not be confused with the orator Antiphon.
sunousiasta/s: see on suno/ntwn i. 1. 4.

*swkra/tou: the name expressed for clearness, after the twice-used au)tou=. Cf. pollh\ h)=n a)fqoni/a au)tw=| tw=n qelo/ntwn kinduneu/ein, o(/pou tis oi)/oito *ku=ron ai)sqh/sesqai An. i.9.15, where the emphasis of *ku=ron is even more marked.
w)/|mhn: I always supposed. Impf. of habitual past action.

tou\s filosofou=ntas: lovers of knowledge. Cf. the Platonic use of filoso/fous equivalent to filomaqei=s, and a)lla\ me/ntoi, ei)=pon e)gw/, to/ ge filomaqe\s kai\ filo/sofon tau)to/n; tau)to\n ga/r, e)/fh Plato Rep. 376 B. Cf. also Plato's use of o)rqw=s filosofou=ntes (Phaedo 67 E) to avoid the use of filo/sofoi in a technical sense.
eu)daimoneste/rous: happier, “more prosperous.” The opposite condition is kakodaimoni/a in 3.
xrh=nai gi/gnesqai: necessarily become.
a)polelauke/nai: to have enjoyed, ironical. For a similar use of e)pauri/skomai, cf. i(/na pa/ntes e)pau/rwntai basilh=os Hom. A 410.
ou)d' a)\n ei(=s: stronger than ou)dei\s a)/n. Cf. iv.3.15, and the Eng. ‘no one’ and ‘none.’
w(s: connect with diaitw/menos.

mei/neie: opposed to a)podidra/skein. In this sense, parame/nein is generally used, as, e.g., Oec. iii. 4, Plato Meno 97 D.—si=ta/ te ktl.: in explanatory appos. with the preceding. What conj. might have been used? For the decl. of si=ta, see G. 288; H. 214.
h)mfi/esai: pf. with pres. meaning. For aug. before prep., see G. 544; H. 361.
ou) mo/non, a)lla/: like the Lat. non solum, sed. The second notion, as the more important, is added to the first, but without excluding it, as would be the case with ou)k, a)lla/ (non, sed).

a)nupo/dhtos: no special singularity is implied in assigning to Socrates a custom adopted by many of the more ascetic philosophers. Aristophanes
(Clouds 103) applies this epithet, with others, to the followers of Socrates. For an interesting account of Greek shoes in the classical period, see an article by A. A. Bryant in Harvard Studies in Classical Philology, vol. x. p. 57 ff.; and for the hardihood manifested by Socrates at the siege of Potidaea, see Plato Sym. 220 A, B.

a)xi/twn: i.e. without the outer xitw/n (e)pendu/ths). Under this outer garment was generally worn an inner xitw/n (u(pendu/ths), with which and his i(ma/tion Socrates seems to have been content. See Guhl and Koner, The Life of the Greeks and Romans, p. 161 ff.
diatelei=s: without w)/n, as Cyr. i. 5. 10.
kai\ mh/n: see on i.4.12, and cf. 8; ii. 3. 4.
xrh/mata: emphatic position.
w(/sper kai/, ou(/tw kai/: the first kai/ remains untranslated, like kai/ before pra/ttein in i. 1. 6. So in Oec. vi. 3. Cf. kai\ h(mi=n tau)ta\ dokei= a(/per kai\ basilei= An. ii.1.22
diaqh/seis: for the fut. denoting pres. intention, see G. 1391; H. 893 c.
ti/: see on ti/si i. 1. 1.
bi/ou: for the case, see on au)tw=n i. 1. 12.
po/teron (sc. xalepo\n h)/|sqhsai), o(/ti: is it because. po/teron is correlative to h)/ below.
toi=s me/n, e)moi\ de/: for me/n with subordinate effect, see on to\ so\n me\n o)/mma i. 4. 17.
h(=tton (with pare/xonta): to a less degree.

xalepw/tera: pred. after o)/nta (to be supplied from the following sent.), with which diaith/mata is acc. abs. with w(s, while e)mou= e)sqi/ontos in the preceding sent. is gen. absolute. G. 1568, 1570;
H. 970, 974.
h(/dista: with greatest relish. Cf. h(de/ws i. 3. 5. Note the assonance of h(/dista, h(/kista.
mh\ paro/ntos: not at hand.
i(ma/tia: emphatic position.
poreu/esqai: for the inf. with verbs of hindering, see G. 1519; H. 948.
tou= (equivalent to tino/s): for the form, see G. 416; H. 277.
e)/ndon: indoors.
to\ a)lgei=n tou\s po/das: pain in my feet. po/das is acc. of specification. G. 1058; H. 718.
o(/pou: for o(/poi, like our ‘where’ for ‘whither.’
meleth/santes: by practicing.
au)ta/: sc. a(\ a)\n meleth/swsi.
a)ei/: const. with karterei=n, at all times to bear patiently.
meletw=nta karterei=n: for the inf. with verbs of practicing, cf. iii.9.14, and e)mele/twn toceu/ein An. iii.4.17
tou= douleu/ein: const. with ai)tiw/teron. G. 1140; H. 753 e.
gastri/: appetite. Cf. i. 2. 1; i. 5. 1.
to\ e)/xein: sc. e)me/ as subject.
e)n xrei/a| o)/nta: while in use.
ou) mo/non, a)lla\ kai/: see on ou) mo/non, a)lla/ in 2.
kai\ mh/n: as in 3.
mhde/n: for the use of mh/ with verbs of thinking etc., cf. i.1.20; 2. 39, 41.

eu)= pra/ttein: are fortunate,
“doing well.” Some editors see a play on words between this and eu)= pra/ttontes below, where the sense seems to be “managing matters well.”
e)rgazo/menoi: for the supplementary participle with tugxa/nw, see G. 1586; H. 984.
e(auto/n: oneself.
filou\s a)mei/nous kta=sqai: acquiring better friends, not by getting new friends, but by improving those we have. a)mei/nous is pred. adjective. G. 919; H. 594 b.
e)gw\ toi/nun ... nomi/zwn: well then, I never cease to believe this (that I am improving myself and my friends).
e)a/n, dh/: see on i.5.1.
e)kpoliorkhqei/h: would succumb to a siege.
toi=s r(a/|stois e)ntugxa/nein: what is easiest to obtain, opposed to tw=n xalepwta/twn eu(rei=n. On the use of the inf. with adjs., see G. 1528; H. 952. Cf. ii.1.22; iii. 8. 8.
a)rkou/ntws xrw/menos: “contented to use,” “contented with.”
e)/oikas oi)ome/nw|: you are like one who thinks, “you seem to think.”
ei)=nai: “consists in.”
qei/ou: for the gen. with advs., cf. ii.1.23.

kra/tiston: “perfect.” The selfdenial here described was carried to an extreme by the sect of philosophers known as Cynics, founded by Antisthenes, a devoted follower of Socrates (cf. iii.11.17; Sym. viii. 4). Its most famous representative was Diogenes, who came from Sinope to Athens some years after the death of Socrates, and was
speedily attracted to the school of Antisthenes. The extravagances and ostentation of his ascetic life are in strong contrast to the generally sane and unaffected simplicity of Socrates.
11-14. In another conversation Socrates refutes Antiphon when he charges him with folly in teaching without compensation.
11. ou)d' o(pwstiou=n: ne tantillum quidem. For -ou=n, cf. i.1.14.
tou=to gignw/skein: to be aware of this.
ou)de/na: for the double acc. with pra/tth|, see on i.2.5.
th=s sunousi/as: gen. of ‘the thing bought,’ by analogy to the gen. of price. G. 1134; H. 746 c.
w(=n: for the ‘assimilation’ of the rel. to the case of its omitted antec., see on i.2.21.
mh\ o(/ti: “not to say,” “let me not say that,” with ellipsis of the verb of saying. Cf. on ou)x o(/ti ii. 9. 8. G. 1504; H. 1035 a.
kai\ th\n sunousi/an, kai\ tau/ths: for the repetition of kai/ in compound sents., see on w(/sper kai/ 3. For the case of tau/ths, see on sunousi/as in 11.
e)pra/ttou: note the transition from the opt. doi/hs in 11 to the indic. of unfulfilled condition.
di/kaios me\n ou)=n a)\n ei)/hs: emphatically put, honest, then, you would be.
e)pista/menos: change of const. from o(/ti ou)k e)capata=|s. Thucydides is specially fond of this change to participial construction.
par' h(mi=n: with us, apud nos.
nomi/zetai ... ei)=nai: “there is a noble as well as an ignoble disposition of wisdom as of personal charms.”

diati/qesqai: to expose for sale. Obs. the condensed expression in w(/ran, sofi/an, kalo/n, ai)sxro/n. Each adj.
belongs to each noun in turn.

th\n sofi/an, tou\s pwlou=ntas: the noun is placed before its governing participle, to correspond with th/n te ga\r w(/ran in the preceding sentence. For a similar order, cf. tou/tou tw=n a)poluso/ntwn ii. 2. 4, peri\ a)riqmw=n toi=s e)rwtw=sin iv. 4. 7.
sofista/s: see on i.1.11. In setting a price on their wisdom, they dishonored it, as did po/rnoi beauty.
o(/ ti a)\n e)/xh|: “what he has in him,” “what he understands.” Cf. e)a/n ti e)/xw in 14, and see on iii.10.1.
a(\ prosh/kei, tau=ta poiei=n: for the dem. referring back with emphasis to the omitted antec. of the rel., see G. 1030; H. 996 b.
o)/rniqi: perhaps an allusion to the Greek fondness for training quails to fight. See Becker, Charicles (Eng. transl.), p. 77 ff.
a)/llois suni/sthmi: introduce them to others. Cf. iv. 7. 1.
w)felh/sesqai: passive.
tou\s qhsaurou\s ... gra/yantes: cf. gra/mmata polla\ poihtw=n te kai\ sofistw=n iv. 2. 1.
kate/lipon gra/yantes: wrote and left behind. Eng. idiom would use gegramme/nous agreeing with ou(/s.
fi/loi gignw/meqa: become dear. “Already friends (toi=s fi/lois), we are glad to have our mutual affection strengthened by the uniting force of a noble sentiment.”
e)moi\ me/n: for me/n, see on i.1.1.
au)to\s de/: while he himself.
ei)/per: if indeed (as Antiphon doubted).
pote/rws: in which way, introduces the double question ei) ... h)\ ei), hence does not correspond to h)/, and should not be confused with po/teron or po/tera. Cf. ii.7.8.
tou= ei)=nai: for the gen. of the articular inf. with verbs, see G. 1547; H. 959.

p.gloss: Socrates dissuades his friends from boastful pretense, which not only brings ridicule and misfortune upon the pretender, but also injures others.

div3.p: a)lazonei/as: Cf. Xenophon's own explanation of the term, o( me\n ga\r a)lazw\n e)/moige dokei= o)/noma kei=sqai e)pi\ toi=s prospoioume/nois kai\ plousiwte/rois ei)=nai h)/ ei)si kai\ a)ndreiote/rois kai\ poih/sein a(\ mh\ i(kanoi/ ei)sin u(pisxnoume/nois, kai\ tau=ta faneroi=s gignome/nois, o(/ti tou= labei=n e(/neka kai\ kerda=nai poiou=si Cyr. ii. 2. 12. See also Theophrastus Char. c. 23.
h)/: sc. au(/th.
tou=to: for the case, see on po/das i. 6. 6.
a)\n ge/noito: would become, potential optative. See on o(mologh/seien i. 1. 5. For the thought, cf. ii.6.39; Cyr. i. 6. 22.—For kai/ after o(/, see on i.1.6.
ga/r: its use suggests that the preceding ou)k ei)/h kalli/wn ktl. is felt as the beginning of the conversation.
ta\ e)/cw: the externals. For the double acc. with mimhte/on, see G. 1076; H. 725.
skeu/h: collective pl., equipment. Cf. Lat. apparatus.

e)/peita:
without de/, as in i. 2. 1.
a)lla\ mh/n: at vero.
h)/: or else.
a)lazw/n: adj. use, gloriosus.
dapanw=n: circumstantial participle of condition. See on pisteu/wn i. 1. 5.
w(s d' au)/tws: and in the same way. Cf. w(sau/tws in 4.
ti/ a)\n au)tw=| sumbai/noi: what would happen to him?
a)=r' ou)k a)\n ... tou=t) ei)/h luphro/n: the sent. is twice interrupted, as e)piqumw=n is equiv. to a clause. For an even more involved structure, cf. h)\ o(/stis, w(/sper ktl. iv. 2. 25.
luphro/n: painful.

kuberna=n te: instead of kai\ strathgei=n, this is followed by h)\ strathgei=n, with a slight change in the thought. Cf. h( gh=, u(grote/ra te ou)=sa pro\s to\n spo/ron h)\ a(lmodeste/ra (too saltish) pro\s futei/an Oec. xx. 12.
a)palla/ceien: would come out of it. In this sense, the pass. is somewhat more common.
dokei=n (sc. ei)=nai): the pretense of being. The thought is “if one should endeavor to seem to excel (§2), he would have much trouble; and the false reputation, when acquired, is injurious.”
a)lusitele\s a)pe/faine: sc. o)/n. After verbs of knowing, declaring, etc., the participle of ei)mi/ is sometimes omitted. Cf. ii.3.14; An. iii.1.36
h)\ kata\ du/namin: “than their strength would bear.”
suggnw/mhs: indulgence. For the case, see on sto/matos i. 4. 12.
ou) mikro/n: ‘litotes,’ as shown by the following polu\ de\ me/giston. Cf. i.2.23.
ei)/ tis: “whoever,” referring to a)patew=na.
o(/stis: instead of ei)/ tis. For the same variation, cf. i.6.13.
e)chpath/koi: the pf. emphasizes the deception as an accomplished fact.—e)moi\ me\n ktl.: Xenophon's conclusion. For me/n, see on i.1.1.
toia/de: instead of the more usual toiau=ta, perhaps as bringing the whole conversation more vividly before the eye. See H. 696 a.

div2.p: No one can govern who does not govern himself. He who does not rule must serve: there is no middle path. To reach self-mastery, we must take pains. This thought is illustrated by the allegory (21-33) of Hercules at the parting of the ways.

div3.p: toiau=ta: in the rare use of pointing forward. Cf. An. v. 8. 7. It has been conjectured that this pron. and toia/de at the close of the preceding chap. have changed places.

e)gkra/teian: self-control. This virtue shows itself as temperance in respect to the pleasures of sense, as perseverance and endurance where difficulties are to be met. Hence its use with the gen. not only of nouns which denote pleasures, but of those also which denote hardships. In this more comprehensive meaning the term has already been used (i. 5).
pro\s e)piqumi/an: inapplicable to the last three gens. (r(i/gous, qa/lpous, po/nou), and prob. a gloss.
gnou\s ga/r: the conj. is introductory, and serves to connect its sent. with the preceding toiau=ta.

*)ari/stippe: of Cyrene in Africa, founder of the Cyrenaic school of philosophy, which regarded pleasure as the highest good, and pain as the greatest evil. Another conversation with him is recorded iii. 8.
o(/pws e)/stai: fut. ind. in obj. clause, on account of the idea of ‘caring for,’ ‘effecting,’ contained in the foregoing paideu/ein. G. 1372; H. 885.
a)rxh=s: for the gen. with verbs of disputing or contesting, see G. 1128; H. 739 a.
bou/lei skopw=men: visne consideremus rem? For the interr. subjv. with bou/lei, see G. 1358; H. 866, 3 b.
a)po\ tw=n stoixei/wn: ab elementis literarum, from the A B C's.
gou=n: certainly.

ou)kou=n: in questions, ou)/koun is equivalent to nonne igitur, expecting an affirmative answer; ou)kou=n (so then) introduces the view of the speaker, giving it an interr. inflection. The latter particle often seems more suited to the gentle irony of Socrates's method, in which he apparently let his interlocutor find out his answer for himself, while really suggesting it to him. So twice just below in 4. Cf. the use of this particle in the examination of Orontas by Cyrus, An. i. 6.
w(/ra: the right time.
ei)ko/s: sc. e)sti/.
ga/r: see on i.4.9.
to\ katepei=gon: pressing duty.
proairei=sqai ma=llon: cf. the same pleonasm in the Lat. malle potius.

po/teron: which of them (sc. the two young men). For the double acc. with a verb of teaching, see on i.2.10. Cf. kai\ tou\s met' au)tou= de\ tau)ta\ ei)/qiken Hell. vi.1.15, and (with to/ and the inf., as here) a)gaqo\n de\ e)qi/zein au(to\n kai\ to\ e)rhmei=n Eq. ix. 9.
mh\ a)/prakta gi/gnhtai: may not be left undone.
para/: during, lit. along the course of. G. 1213, 3 (b); H. 802, 3 b.

tw=| a)/rxein paideuome/nw|: short form of expression equiv. to to
 ei)s to\ a)/rxein paideuo/menon in 2. Cf. oi( ei)s th
 basilikh
 te/xnhn paideuo/menoi 17.

to\ maqei=n, ei)/ ti ma/qhma: the acquirement
of whatever knowledge.
polu/: sc. ma=llon.

tw=n a)/llwn o)/felos: for the subjective gen. with o)/felos, see on o)smw=n i. 4. 5, and, for the decl. of o)/felos, same section. Cf. a)kola/stou ga\r strateu/matos ou)de\n h(gei=to o)/felos ei)=nai An. ii.6.10
h(=tton a)\n dokei= a(li/skesqai: seems less likely to be captured. For the inf. with a)/n in indirect discourse, cf. gene/sqai a)/n i. 2. 15.

kai\ ma/la e)/nia duswpou/mena: and some (of these) very shy by nature. For the partitive appos., see G. 914; H. 624 d. Cf. a)kou/omen u(ma=s ei)s th\n po/lin bi/a| parelhluqo/tas e)ni/ous skhnou=n (are quartered, some of you) e)n tai=s oi)ki/ais An. v.5.11
oi( pe/rdikes: cf. Xenophon's description of the bustards (w)ti/das) as easily caught, pe/tontai ga\r braxu/, w(/sper pe/rdikes An. i.5.3
e)cista/menoi tou= a)nalogi/zesqai: see on tou= fronei=n e)ci/sthsi i. 3. 12.
ou)/koun: at nonne, seems preferable to ou)kou=n, as being followed by the decisive a)=r' ou)k, e)sti/n at the close of the section.
kai/: introduces an example. Cf. i.1.7.
ta\s ei(rkta/s: i.e. the women's apartments, gunaikwni=tis.
ki/ndunos: sc. e)sti/.
o( no/mos a)peilei=: acc. to Attic law, the injured husband could either himself punish the adulterer, or accuse him before the Thesmothetae.

o)/ntwn de\ pollw=n
tw=n a)poluso/ntwn: although there are so many means to free him from (i.e. gratify). tw=n a)poluso/ntwn is neuter.
e)n a)dei/a|: with impunity.—a)=r) ou)k h)/dh tou=to ktl.: is not that, then, the act of an utter madman? kakodaimona/w, lit. to be possessed by an evil genius. The participle is pred. genitive.
ei)=nai me/n, tou\s de\ e)/xein: for this use of me/n, de/, see on i.4.17.
ta\s a)nagkaiota/tas plei/stas pra/ceis: the greatest part of the most necessary employments.
a)nqrw/pois: connect with ei)=nai.
ou) ta\s e)laxi/stas: see on ou)x h(/kista i. 2. 23.
a)gumna/stws e)/xein: are untrained.
dokei=: sc. tou=to.
kai\ tau=ta: sc. yu/xh kai\ qa/lph.
fe/rein: const. with a)/skein, and for the inf., see on meletw=nta karterei=n i. 6. 7.
e)gkratei=s: see on 1.
ei) ta/ttomen: “if we include,” a good example of the simple logical condition. G. 1390; H. 893.
tou\s mhd' a)ntipoihsome/nous tou= a)/rxein: those who will not even contend for high office. For the gen. tou= a)/rxein, see on a)rxh=s 1, and for the attrib. participle, cf. i.2.43.
ta/comen: distinguish the simple fut. ind. in apod. from the interr. subjv., shall we include.

tou/twn e(kate/rou tou= fu/lou th\n ta/cin: the respective position of each of these classes of men, lit. the rank of each class of these men. The two individuals are now identified with the classes of which they are types. For the position of the dem. pronominal adj., see G. 974; H. 673 a. Cf. e)f' e(kate/rw| tw=| ke/ra| Thuc. v. 67.
e)/gwge (sc. e)skeya/mhn): yes, indeed.
a)nqrw/pou: for the pred. gen. of characteristic, see on gnw/mhs i. 1. 9.

to\ mh\ a)rkei=n tou=to: sc. au)tw=|. We might have expected a)rkei=sqai (contentum esse) tou/tw|, a)lla\ prosanaqe/sqai, but it is common in Greek for a dependent word of one clause to become the subj. in the next, as here, where au)to/n is to be supplied as subj. of prosanaqe/sqai.
e(autw=| me\n e)llei/pein, tou/tou di/khn u(pe/xein: a compound subj. as in 6, here summed up by tou=to.
tou=to pw=s ... e)sti/: the thought stated as a belief at the beginning of this passage (pa/nu ... a)/fronos ... ei)=nai) is repeated at its close in the form of a question. See on i. 4. 13.

e)gw/ te ga/r, ai(/ te po/leis: for as I, so also the states. See on i. 3. 1.—tou\s me\n boulome/nous ktl.: with these words Aristippus indicates the position and function of a statesman who, at the demand of the state, must lay on himself and others heavy burdens: and, in rejecting this for himself, Aristippus indirectly gives utterance to the view afterward developed by his pupil Epicurus. Cf. to\ maka/rion kai\ a)/fqarton ou)/te au)to\ pra/gmata e)/xei, ou)/te a)/llw| pare/xei Diog. Laert. x. 39, words which Cicero renders quod aeternum beatumque est, id nec habere ipsum negoti quicquam nec exhibere alteri De Nat. Deor. i. 17. The use of the dat. au(toi=s with e)/xein may be
explained by the analogy of the following a)/llois.
ou(/tws: i.e. as previously described.
a)\n paideu/sas: “would educate and.”
me/ntoi: a stronger adversative than de/.
h(=| r(a=|sta: for the strengthened superlative, see H. 651.
bou/lei, skeyw/meqa: see on 1.
w(=n: for the attraction, see G. 1031; H. 994; o(/pws ou)=n e)/sesqe a)/ndres a)/cioi th=s e)leuqeri/as h(=s ke/kthsqe An. i.7.3
*pe/rsai me\n a)/rxousin, a)/rxontai de\ *su/roi: obs. the chiastic order. In the two following sents. the more natural order is followed.
*su/roi, *fru/ges, *lu/doi: purposely mentioned, as names of races despised by the Greeks.
*maiw=tai: a people near the Sea of Azof.
e)n oi(=s kai\ au)to\s ei)=: “to come a little nearer home.”

oi( kratou=ntes, oi( kratou/menoi: i.e. the more powerful states and their tributary allies. Under the leadership of Pericles, Athens had developed to its utmost the system of a central power with many dependent allies. For an account of it, see Schömann, Antiq. of Greece, i. passim.
au)=: on the other hand, with reference to the beginning of 8, ei)s th\n doulei/an being used for ei)s th\n tw=n dou/lwn ta/cin.
tou/twn: const. as a gen. of place with me/sh, which here is equivalent to e)n me/sw| between.
h(/n: for the cognate acc. with verbs of motion, see G. 1057; H. 712.
eu)daimoni/an: for true happiness described as the reward of virtue, cf. 33. See Introd. § 22.
me/n, me/ntoi: as in 9. Cf. iv.4.7.
ou(/tws mhde\ di) a)nqrw/pwn: sc. fe/roi.
i)/sws a)/n ti le/gois: “perhaps there would be something in what you say.” The opposite is ou)de\n le/gein. See Kr. Spr. 51. 16. 13.
ei) a)ciw/seis: for the fut. ind. expressing present intention, cf. i.6.3.
mhde\ e(kw\n qerapeu/seis: and do not intend to yield voluntary allegiance.
kai\ koinh=| kai\ i)di/a|: “both states and individuals.”

klai/ontas kaqi/stantes: “by bringing them to grief.” Cf. our phrase ‘come to grief,’ for any disastrous result. Cf., also, Xenophon's use of the similar klai/ontas kaqi/zein in Sym. iii. 11; Cyr. ii. 2. 15.
dou/lois: as slaves. Cf. tekmhri/w| i. 2. 49, trofh=| iii. 11. 6.

speira/ntwn: for the omission of the art. with subst. participles, see on maino/menos i. 3. 11.—to/n te si=ton te/mnontes ktl.: cf. the proceedings in the early years of the Peloponnesian war, when a Spartan army under Archidamus regularly ravaged the Attic plain. For the attrib. participle used substantively, see on tou\s a)ntipoihsome/nous 7.
poliorkou=ntes: vexantes, besieging.
pei/swsin: euphemistic for “compel.” Cf. e)pei/sqhsan a)na/gkh| An. vii.7.29, fobw=n e)/peise Cyr. v. 4. 51. For the subjv. in a temporal clause, see G. 1465; H. 921, and cf. 33; iii. 5. 6.
kai\ i)di/a| au)=: transition from states to individuals.
ce/nos pantaxou=: “a citizen of the world.”

tou=to me/ntoi ktl.: that is certainly a clever dodge you suggest. pa/laisma lit. a trick of wrestling. For the pred. use of deino/n, see
H. 618.
e)c ou(=: sc. xro/nou.

*si/nis, *skei/rwn, *prokrou/sths: three famous robbers, killed by Theseus. Cf. Plut. Theseus 8. The way in which Procrustes treated his guests has become proverbial, and has given us the word ‘procrustean.’ Cf. ou(=tos de\ tou\s pario/ntas o(doipo/rous h)na/gkasen e)pi/ tinos kli/nhs a)napi/ptein kai\ tw=n me\n makrote/rwn ta\ proe/xonta me/rh (the projecting portions) tou= sw/matos a)pe/kopte, tw=n d' e)latto/nwn tou\s po/das proe/krouen (hammered out) Diod. Sic. iv. 59.
a)lla\ nu=n: i.e. when there are no longer such robbers.

toi=s a)nagkai/ois kaloume/nois: in general, oi( a)nagkai=oi means all who are intimately associated with us; here, however, like the Lat. necessarii, the phrase is equivalent to kinsmen, hence the addition of kaloume/nois.
bohqou/s: pred. accusative.
oi(=s a)mu/nontai: with which they try to defend themselves. For the pres. of attempted action, see G. 1255; H. 825.
tou\s a)dikou=ntas: for the acc. with certain verbs of which the equivalents are intr. in Eng., see G. 1049; H. 712.
e)/xwn: although you have.
toiou=tos: i.e. without home or friends.
oi(/ois: for the pl. after a sing. antec. suggesting a class, see H. 629 a.
dia\ to\ ce/nos ei)=nai: for the articular inf., see on i.1.12.
h)/: sc. qarrei=s.

oi(=os lusitelei=n: see on oi(/ous te/mnein i. 4. 6.— ti/s ga\r a)\n e)qe/loi ktl.: a question
which seems to support the supposition attributed to Aristippus, namely, that as a slave he would be of no account: its real application is found in the following section.
a)=ra ou): belongs to each of the three following questions. For the interr., see on i.3.11.
kle/ptein: for the inf. with verbs of hindrance, see on poreu/esqai i. 6. 6.
a)lla\ ga/r: introduces (like at enim) an objection, ga/r being explained by some omitted thought like “an objection presents itself.”
ti/: adv. accusative.
peinh/sousi: for this and the following fut. inds., cf. a)ciw/seis 12.

o(/ ti a)/llo: to be read together, wherein else. After a)/llo ge h)/, acc. to Eng. idiom, a o(/ti might be expected, which is not necessary in Greek. Cf. ti/ ga\r a)/llo h)\ kinduneu/seis ii. 3. 17. “The difference between willing and unwilling submission to indignities is only this, that he who submits willingly incurs, in addition to his suffering, the charge of folly.”
o( *swkra/ths e)/fh: see on i.2.9.
tw=n toiou/twn (sc. luphrw=n): part. gen. with ta\ e(kou/sia.

h(=|: in so
far as, quatenus.
o(po/te bou/loito: for the opt. in a rel. temporal clause by assimilation, see on i.5.4; ii. 9. 2.
pi/oi: without a)/n, which is to be supplied from the preceding fa/goi a)/n.
o(po/tan bou/lhtai: obs. the a)/n retained with the subjv. in a rel. temporal clause, and omitted with the opt. (o(po/te bou/loito).
ponw=n: for the supplementary participle with verbs expressive of being pleased, see G. 1580; H. 983.
a)=qla: praemia, rewards.
mikrou= tinos a)/cia/ e)sti: have some small value. For the indef. pron. added to adjs., see on deinh/n tina i. 3. 12, and, for the gen. of value with a)/cios, G. 1135; H. 753 f.
tou/tous: repeats and emphasizes tou\s de/. Cf. iii.5.8, 7. 4.
a)game/nous e(autou/s: well-pleased with themselves.
e)k tou= paraxrh=ma h(donai/: pleasures of the moment, i.e. easilywon enjoyments (as shown by the contrasted ai( dia\ karteri/as e)pime/leiai). Cf. ta\s e)gguta/tw h(dona/s iv. 5. 10.
sw/mati, yuxh=|: for the omission of the generic art., see H. 660.

ai( dia\ karteri/as e)pime/leiai: for the use of the prep. with its case as an attrib. adj. (so e)k tou= paraxrh=ma above), see G. 952; H. 600; and for dia/ with the gen. denoting manner, cf. dia\ me/qhs Plato Sym. 176 E.
e)/rgwn: results. For the gen. with verbs of attaining and touching, see on i.4.12.
*(hsi/odos: the quotation is from his Works and Days 287 ff.
kai\ i)/ladon: and that in abundance.
e)/stin: why this accent?
lei/h: cf. the Lat. lēvis.
nai/ei: sc. h( kako/ths.

oi)=mos: seems first masc. (makro/s), and then fem. (r(hidi/h). It is more commonly fem., like other words meaning way, e.g., o(do/s, ke/leuqos, a)trapo/s, etc. Possibly the poet had one of these in mind with r(hidi/h. See G. 194, 1; H. 152 c.
xaleph/ per e)ou=sa: sc. to\ prw=ton.
*)epi/xarmos: a comic poet from Cos, who flourished in Syracuse about 500 B.C. The two verses are ‘trochaic tetrameter catalectic.’ G. 1651; H. 1083.
tw=n po/nwn: for the gen. of price, see on i.6.11.
kai\ ... e)/xh|s: the passage is prob. interpolated, as to/pos was not used in Xenophon's time to denote a ‘place’ in an author's works. See L. & S. s.v. to/pos I, 4.
mw=so: from ma/w.

*pro/dikos: of Ceos, a contemporary of Socrates and Xenophon, the latter of whom may have heard him recite his apologue of Hercules at Thebes, in the course of a professional tour. Socrates spoke of him with respect, and in Plato several times calls himself a hearer of Prodicus. The su/ggramma peri\ *(hrakle/ous was a part of a larger work entitled *(=wrai.
e)pidei/knutai: exhibits, “recites.” The exhibition or ‘show’ speeches of the Sophists were generally called e)pidei/ceis.

w(=de/ pws:
see on toia/de tis i. 1. 1.
e)k pai/dwn: from childhood, concrete for abstract. For the accent of pai/dwn, see G. 128; H. 172 a.

o(do/n: for the case, see on h(/n 11.—e)celqo/nta ktl.: cf. nam quod Herculem Prodicus dicit, ut est apud Xenophontem,—exisse in solitudinem atque ibi sedentem diu secum multumque dubitasse etc. Cic. de Off. i. 32. 118.
tra/phtai: for the interr. subjv. retained in indir. question, see G. 1490; H. 933.
i)dei=n: for the limiting inf. with adjs., see G. 1528; H. 952. Cf. i.6.9; iii. 8. 8.
e)sqh=ti: const. with kekosmhme/nhn.

teqramme/nhn ei)s polusarki/an te kai\ a(palo/thta: pampered up to plumpness and delicacy.—kekallwpisme/nhn de\ to\ me\n xrw=ma ktl.: this sent. does not correspond to the previous one, either in the order of the clauses or in the words themselves. Xenophon seems often to have avoided complete uniformity in the parallel clauses of a rhetorical period; though it certainly might have been justified here, as being quite in keeping with the character of professional declamations, which abounded in antitheses.
tou= o)/ntos, th=s fu/sews: equivalent to h)\ h)=n, h)\ e)pefu/kei. See Kr. Spr. 47. 27. 2.
w(/ste dokei=n fai/nesqai: cf. e)kplage/ntes tw=| do/cai me/gan te kai\ kalo\n fanh=nai to\n *ku=ron Cyr. viii. 3. 14.

o)rqote/ran: more erect, in order to appear taller. Tallness was esteemed by the Greeks. Cf., on the passage, i)dw/n pote au)th\n e)ntetrimme/nhn pollw=| yimuqi/w| (white lead), o(/pws leukote/ra e)/ti dokoi/h ei)=nai h)\ h)=n, pollh=| de\ e)gxou/sh| (red dye, from the plant anchusa), o(/pws e)ruqrote/ra fai/noito th=s a)lhqei/as, u(podh/mata d' e)/xousan u(yhla/, o(/pws mei/zwn dokoi/h ei)=nai h)\ e)pefu/kei Oec. X. 2, where Ischomachus is describing
his youthful wife.
w(/ra: youthful beauty, with art. omitted.
diala/mpoi: for the potential opt. in rel. final clauses, see G. 1367; H. 937 a.
e)piskopei=n: looked, to see if etc.
*(hrakle/ous: for the gen. with advs. of place, see on qei/ou i. 6. 10.
to\n au)to\n tro/pon: i.e. without altering her pace.
a)porou=nta: for the supplementary participle in indirect discourse, see on i.2.16.
o(do\n e)pi\ to\n bi/on: path in life.
tra/ph|: for the mode, cf tra/phtai 21.
poihsa/menos: participle of manner, with ellipsis of th\n o(do\n tra/ph|. Cf. nomi/san i. 2. 42.
ou)deno/s: for the gen. with verbal adjs., cf. i.2.1, 63; 6. 8.
pole/mwn: for the case, cf. i.1.11.
frontiei=s: for the ‘Attic’ future, see G. 665, 3; H. 425.
skopou/menos die/sh|: you shall all the time be considering. For the supplementary participle with verbs of continuing, see G. 1580; H. 981.
siti/on, poto/n: in appos. with ti/.
eu(/rois: potential opt. in indirect discourse.
paidikoi=s: favorites.
spa/news a)f' w(=n: equivalent to spa/news tou/twn, a)f) w(=n.
ou) fo/bos (sc. e)sti/): no ground for anxiety.

to/: connect with pori/zesqai.—
ponou=nta, talaipwrou=nta: agree with the omitted subj. of pori/zesqai.
oi(=s, tou/tois: for a(/, tou/tois with omitted indef. antec. of the relative. See G. 1030; H. 996 b. For the assimilation, see on w(=n 10.
xrh/sh|: “shall enjoy.”
pantaxo/qen: the position is emphatic.
o)/noma de/: for de/, see on i.3.13.
h( de/: for the pronominal art., see on i.2.33.
u(pokorizo/menoi: nicknaming. The word properly means ‘to talk baby talk,’ from ko/ros, ‘child,’—hence, ‘to give pet names,’ and so, in a bad sense, ‘to nickname.’
katamaqou=sa; “gauged.”
ei) tra/poio: less confident than the e)a\n [traph=|] of *kaki/a in 23.
a)\n gene/sqai: see on a)\n kinhqh=nai i. 1. 14.
e)p' a)gaqoi=s: for good actions, i.e. those which Hercules would perform under her guidance; ‘lit with the luster shed by valorous deeds’ (Dakyns).
prooimi/ois h(donh=s: promises of pleasure, like those in the speech of *kaki/a.
a)gaqw=n kai\ kalw=n: const. as preds. with o)/ntwn.
i(/lews: see on i.1.9 fin.
bou/lei, e)qe/leis, e)piqumei=s: prob. no difference in meaning is intended.

qerapeute/on: see on i. 2.
34. Note the double meaning of qerapeu/w with qeou/s and gh=n, like the Lat. colere.

au)ta/s te: the te/ is added, because the writer had in mind maqhte/on for both clauses, with some such obj. in the second as th\n xrh=sin au)tw=n, instead of which, by a slight change of construction we have o(/pws au)tai=s dei/ xrh=sqai a)skhte/on. The whole idea is sufficiently rendered by our “military science and tactics.” ei) de/: after the sevenfold repetition of ei)/te, the emphatic concluding sent. is introduced with ei) de/. Cf. the Lat. si vero after sive.

th=| gnw/mh| u(phretei=n: for when the body obeys the reason, it will do nothing which will interfere with its own best development. Cicero, in his version of this passage (exercendum corpus et ita afficiendum est, ut oboedire consilio rationique possit De Off. i. 23. 79), seems to have connected th=| gnw/mh| u(phretei=n with dunato/s, rather than with what follows.
po/nois, i(drw=ti: dats. of accompaniment. Cf. ‘in the sweat of thy brow shalt thou eat bread’ Gen. iii. 19.
h( gunh\ au(/th: that woman there. So the Lat. ista femina.

eu)frosu/nas: pleasures, in strong contrast to eu)daimoni/an. Observe the elaborate antitheses in the two clauses, and note that Vice usurps the nobler word happiness, conceding to Virtue only pleasures as the reward of toil and self-denial.
o(do/n (after braxei=an): see on 21.

h( *)areth/: that Virtue has not been previously mentioned by name is a refinement of the allegory, which has left it to the hearer or reader to identify her by her description at entrance, and by her words.
w)= tlh=mon: wretched being, uttered with righteous indignation.
ti/ de/: see on o)/noma de/ 26.
h(/tis: you who. See H. 699 a.
ou)de\ a)name/neis: cf. Sym. iv. 41. “Not only will you not do anything to secure true enjoyment, but you will not wait for the desire (hunger, thirst, etc.) of enjoyment to come of itself.”
peinh=n, diyh=n: for the special form of contraction, see G. 496; H. 412.
mhxanwme/nh, paraskeua/zh|: note the change of construction. The retention of the participle is prob. due to the influence of the two preceding participles, the finite const. being afterward resumed.
xio/na: the use of snow to cool wine, sherbet, etc. is common in southern Europe. For the thought, cf. i.6.5.
strwmna/s: beds, mattresses.
malaka/s: pred. adj., to be connected with paraskeua/zh|. G. 971, 972; H. 618.— [ta\s kli/nas kai/]: prob. an interpolation, as the possession of couches could not be a subject for reproach.

u(po/baqra: rockers. Cf. ou) ga\r e)k xrusou= kai\ e)le/fantos kateskeuasme/nai kli=nai kai\ porfuroi= ta/phtes ou)/te u(po/baqra kai\ pasta/des (colonnades) u(/pnous poiou=sin, a)lla\ e)/rga kai\ no/mimoi po/noi kai\ to\ th=s fu/sews au)th=s a)nagkai=on Teles apud Stobaeum Flor. 93. 31.
poih=|s: see on tra/phtai 21.
gunaici/: see on dou/lois 12.

u(bri/zousa, katakoimi/zousa: the participles expand and explain the preceding ou(/tw. Cf.
e)mbolh\n w(=de poiou=ntai, a(/ma me\n laqei=n peirw/menoi, a(/ma de\ fqa/sai An. iv.1.4
e)k qew=n: from the company of gods.

e)pai/nou e(auth=s: praise of yourself. For the use of the third pers. refl. instead of the second, see G. 995; H. 686 a. For the thought, cf. Themistoclem dixisse aiunt, cum ex eo quaereretur quod acroama aut cuius vocem libentissime audiret: Eius, a quo sua virtus optime praedicaretur Cic. pro Arch. 9. 32.
eu)= fronw=n: in his senses.
qia/sou: properly an assemblage of worshipers: here scornfully applied to the followers of *kaki/a.
oi(\ ne/oi: as if preceded by qiaswtw=n, instead of qia/sou, a const. kata\ su/nesin. So ai( po/leis, pau/sontes in ii. 2. 3.
liparoi\ trefo/menoi: for the pred. adj. used in adverbial sense, see H. 619.
a)poqe/menoi: laying up. Cf. with this description Shakspeare's Seven Ages of Man in As You Like It, and the imagery of Ecclesiastes xii.
su/neimi me/n, su/neimi de/: ‘anaphora,’ as in i. 1. 2, 5. 3.
kalo/n ou)/te ... ou)/te ... gi/gnetai: acc. to Greek usage, we should expect an ou)de/n before kalo/n.
oi(=s: for par' oi(=s. So ai(=s su/nei for e)n ai(=s su/nei iii. 7. 3. *kaki/a receives indeed honor, but only from those par) oi(=s tima=sqai ou) prosh/kei.

sunergo/s: sc. ou)=sa.—
sullh/ptria: an assistant.
koinwno/s: a sharer.
a)pra/gmwn: untroubled, opposed to periqe/ousa in 30.
a)ne/xontai: they hold out.
eu)= pra/ttontes: succeeding in.—o(/tan d' a)\n e)/lqh| to\ peprwme/non te/los ktl.: cf. the concluding lines of Bryant's Thanatopsis.
u(mnou/menoi qa/llousi: “they are immortalized in song.” Cf. Harmodius in ore et Aristogito, Lacedaemonius Leonidas, Thebanus Epamin ondas vigent Cic. Tusc. Disp. i. 49. 116.
toiau=ta soi: for the ‘asyndeton,’ see on i.1.9.
diw/kei: unusual in this sense, which is a common one in English. Cf. the Lat. persequi.
th\n u(p' *)areth=s pai/deusin: for u(po/ and the gen. with a verbal noun, see Kr. Spr. 68. 43. 2. Cf. h(/desqai th=| u(po\ pa/ntwn timh=| Cyr. iii. 3. 2.
gnw/mas: thoughts.
e)nqumoume/nw|: giving heed.
peira=sqai/ ti ... fronti/zein: to strive to pay some attention to those things also (kai/) which belong to the later portion of your life.

div2.p: Ingratitude is an offense, the more heinous in proportion to the benefits received. Ingratitude towards parents, therefore, is a very grave offense, punished with ignominy by the state and with contempt by all men. These thoughts are brought out in a conversation between Socrates and his son Lamprocles.

div3.p: to\n presbu/taton: acc. to Suidas (s.v. *swkra/ths), the two other sons of Socrates, Sophroniscus and Menexenus, were by Myrto, a second wife. But Plato (Phaedo 60 A), in the well-known prison- and deathscene, describes Xanthippe as sitting beside Socrates with their child (paidi/on). Cf. also ibid. 116 B. Perhaps Myrto was his first wife; but there is no contemporary evidence for more than one, and that one Xanthippe. On the violent temper of Xanthippe, cf. xrh=| (you are provided with) gunaiki\ tw=n ou)sw=n, oi)=mai de\ kai\ tw=n gegenhme/nwn kai\ tw=n e)some/nwn, xalepwta/th| Sym. ii. 10. They were an ill-assorted couple, and each had doubtless much to complain of.

tou\s ti/ poiou=ntas, a)pokalou=sin: i.e. ti/ poiou=sin ou(=toi, ou(\s to\ o)/noma tou=to kalou=sin; For the interr. depending on a participle or other dependent word, cf. i.4.14; i. 3. 10; An. iii.1.14
tou\s eu)= paqo/ntas: those who have received favors. Cf. a)nq' w(=n eu)= e)/paqon u(p) e)kei/nou An. i.3.4
ou)kou=n: as in ii. 1. 2.
ei) a)/ra: whether possibly.
w(/sper: followed by a simple kai/, instead of ou(/tw kai/. Cf. w(/sper su/, kai\ e)gw/ iv. 4. 7. Cf. also Oec. xviii. 9.
a)/dikon, di/kaion: wrong, right.
u(f' ou(= a)/n tis (equivalent to e)a/n tis u(po/ tinos) ktl.: whoever has received favors from any one, whether friend or foe, and does not attempt to return them.
ei)likrinh/s tis: a clear kind of, the adj. followed by the indef., as in Lat. by quidam with the same signification. G. 1016; H. 702.
a)\n ei)/h: potential opt. in apodosis. See G. 1421, 1; H. 901 b.
ti/nas, u(po\ ti/nwn: two questions in one clause. G. 1601; H. 1013. The same usage is found in Latin; cf. difficile est enumerare quot viri quanta scientia fuerint Cic. de Or. i. 3. 9.

e)k me\n ou)k o)/ntwn, ei)=nai: out of non-existence into being. Cf. e)k qew=n ii. 1. 31. “We owe to our parents all the blessings of life, the possession of which is regarded as the greatest happiness, and their loss (through death) the greatest misfortune.”
qa/naton: without the article. See on i. 2. 62, where zhmi/a has the art., which here it lacks.

w(s ... pau/santes: rati metu mali, quo gravius nullum esset, iniuriam coercere se posse. See on w(s proshmai/nontos i. 1. 4. The participle, by a constructio ad sensum, refers to oi( poli=tai implied in ai( po/leis. See on qia/sou, oi( ii. 1. 31.
tou/tou, tw=n a)poluso/ntwn: for the position of the art., see on i.6.13; and for the sing. tou/tou (sc. tou= tw=n a)frodisi/wn e)piqumei=n), see on iii.4.5. a)poluso/ntwn is neuter, as in ii. 1. 5.
be/ltista: finest.
ai(=s: equivalent to kai\ tau/tais. Cf. the conversation between Ischomachus and his wife, Oec. vii. 10 ff.
u(podecame/nh te fe/rei: to this corresponds kai/ tre/fei below.
dienegkou=sa: sc. in the period of pregnancy.

gignw=skon to\ bre/fos: best const. as obj. of tre/fei te kai\ e)pimelei=tai taken as one idea (tre/fei e)pimelw=s). Kühner suggests that Xenophon composed the passage rhetorically, and wrote gignw=skon to\ bre/fos in the nom. as a substitute for the gen. abs., in order to preserve ‘concinnity’ in the constructions. On the connection of the two participles (propeponqui=a, gignw=skon), one in the nom., the other in the acc., by ou)/te, ou)/te, cf. ii.7.8.
ou)de/: and not. —a)ll) au)th\ ktl.: from here the const. becomes freer, in order to avoid the obscurity resulting from too many participles.
qre/yai mo/non: an unusual position. See on i. 4. 13.

pe/mpousi: sc. tou\s pai=das. The education of an Athenian boy included the study of (1) gra/mmata (reading and writing); (2) h( mousikh\ te/xnh (poetry and music); (3) h( gumnastikh\ te/xnh (physical culture). Cf. Aristophanes Clouds 961 ff., and esp. Plato Prot. 325 ff.; and for a fuller account, see Becker, Charicles (Eng. translation), p. 226 ff., and Guhl and Koner, Life of the Greeks and Romans, §§ 50, 51.
pa/nta: everything possible.
a)lla/ toi ktl.: said in a somewhat grumbling tone.
pepoi/hke: the subj. is readily supplied from the connection.
h)\ mhtro/s: or that of a mother. Lamprocles, who has his own mother in mind, answers with the article, th=s mhtro/s, th=s ge toiau/ths the mother's, if she be such a one as mine.
dakou=sa, lakti/sasa: for the aor. participle expressing time coincident with that of the main verb, see GMT. 150; H. 856 b.

e)pi\ tw=| bi/w| panti/: for his whole life, i.e. for all that life could bring him. Cf. e)pi\ po/sw| a)\n e)qe/lois th\n gunai=ka/ sou a)kou=sai o(/ti skeuoforei=s Cyr. iii. 1. 43. G. 1210, 2 c; H. 799, 2 c.—[dusa/nekta]: found only here, is perhaps an interpolation suggested by a)nasxe/sqai above.
ei)=pa: the rare first pers. sing. of the Ionic aorist. The second pers. is much more common. Of ei)=pa only six instances in Attic are cited by Veitch (Greek Verbs, p. 205 ff.).
po/sa: cognate accusative.
a)llh/lous, e)/sxata: for the two accs. with one verb, see on i.2.12.
tw=n lego/ntwn ou)/te to/n: that of those uttering (such things) either he who.
e)le/gxein: does so (i.e. utters abuse).

i(/na zhmiw/sh|: in
order to do harm.
eu)= ei)dw/s: designedly stronger than ou)k oi)/ontai in the previous sentence.
a)gaqa/: good things.

o(/pws u(gia/nh|s, e)/sh|: subjv. and fut. indic. in close connection, with o(/pws. G. 1374; H. 885 b. Kühner suggests that the change to the indic. implies that the supplying of the child's wants is more in the mother's power than is the maintenance of his health.
eu)xome/nhn a)gaqa/: praying for blessings.
eu)xa\s a)podidou=san: paying her vows.
ei) du/nasai: see on i.2.13.
a)/llon tina/: obj. of qerapeu/ein.
pareskeu/asai: are you prepared?
pei/qesqai: depends on pareskeu/asai.

i(/na soi pu=r e)nau/h|: that he may kindle a fire for you, i.e. not refuse you a light. Cf. ex quo sunt illa communia: non prohibere aqua profluente; pati ab igne ignem capere Cic. de Off. i. 16. 52.
sullh/ptwr: cf. sullh/ptria ii. 1. 32.
a)/n ti sfallo/menos tu/xh|s: “if you fall into any misfortune.”

e)llu/qen bohqh=| soi: being at hand may aid you. —
ou)de\n a)/n soi diafe/roi: would it make no difference to you?
th=s para\ tou/twn eu)noi/as: the good will (emanating) from these.
ei)=ta: as in i. 2. 26.
e)pimelei=tai: takes cognizance of.
a)podido/ntas: supplementary participle with periora=|.
e)a\n de/ tis: correl. to a)/llhs me/n above.

a)/rxein: to serve as archon, technical term. Cf. bouleu/sas i. 1. 18. A law of Solon provided for a rigid examination into the ‘record’ of a candidate for the archonship, and if it was found that he had been guilty of violence or neglect toward his parents (ei) to
 pate/ra tu/ptei, h)\ th
 mhte/ra, h)\ mh\ pare/xei oi)/khsin) he was excluded from all public office.—w(s ou)/te a)
 ta\ i(era\ ktl.: on the ground that the sacrifices would not be offered piously on behalf of the state if this man officiated. For the participle with w(s, see on 3 and i. 1. 4. Obs. the emphatic repetition of tou/tw|, tou=ton, tou/tou.
ou)de\n a)/n: sc. pratto/menon, to be const. like quo/mena above.
e)ceta/zei: investigates.
dokimasi/ais: on this whole subject, see Schömann, Antiq. of Greece, p. 403 ff. Cf. Pollux viii. 44.
a)\n swfronh=|s: if you are wise.

mh\ ou)k e)qelh/swsin: in Attic, the use of mh\ ou) with the subjv. is
generally confined to clauses after verbs of fearing. See GMT. 305, 306; H. 1033.
ei)=ta: and then, without kai/, as often. Cf. i.2.1; iv. 5. 3, and kai\ au)toi\ polla/kis e)me\ mimou=ntai, ei)=ta e)pixeirou=sin a)/llous e)ceta/zein Plato Apol. 23C.

e)n e)rhmi/a| fi/lwn: without w)/n. So after o(ra=n, cf. e)n eu)di/a| (security) ga\r o(rw= u(ma=s An. v.8.19; and after katalamba/nein, cf. katelamba/nomen tou\s me\n h(mete/rous e)n fo/bw| Demosthenes de Cor. § 211.
gonei=s: this form of the acc. pl. of nouns in -eu/s is not rare in Xenophon. Cf. i(ppei=s iii. 5. 19, gnafei=s, skutei=s, xalkei=s iii. 7. 6, dromei=s iii. 10. 6.

div2.p: Of two brothers living in discord, the younger is reminded by Socrates that a brother is worth more than money and land. On him, as the younger, it is incumbent to win his brother by affection; the latter will be ashamed to remain alienated: and thus the two will work with combined energies, to which, indeed, they are, as brothers, summoned by nature.

div3.p: *xairefw=nta: from early youth a follower and friend of Socrates, so that Aristophanes brackets him with the latter, tou\s w)xriw=ntas (pale-faced), tou\s a)nupodh/tous le/geis, | w(=n o( kakodai/mwn *swkra/ths kai\ *xairefw=n Clouds 103, 104. He, too, it was who questioned the Pythia at Delphi as to whether any man was wiser than Socrates. The philosopher, when on trial, appealed to Chaerecrates to corroborate this, since Chaerephon was dead. Cf. Plato Apol. 21A.
diaferome/nw: see on zw=nta i. 2. 16.
ou) dh/pou: surely not, ironical in tone, yet implying a neg. answer. Cf. iv.2.11.
tw=n toiou/twn a)nqrw/pwn: of that sort of men.
xrhsimw/teron: a more useful possession. For the gender, see G. 925; H. 617.
xrh/mata: purposely chosen, instead of, e.g., kth/mata (cf. ii.4.1), on account of xrhsimw/teron, for the sake of the ‘parechesis.’ Cf. ii.4.5.
kai\ tau=ta tw=n me\n a)fro/nwn o)/ntwn: and that, too, though the former are without sense.
tou= de/: from a)delfou/s, the generic idea, Socrates passes to tou= de/, having in mind the special case of Chaerecrates.

bohqei/as:
the care and attention needed by crops and live-stock.
zhmi/an: a detriment.
e)ntau=qa: here, “in this case.”
du/nantai: the subj. is an indef. pl. implied in ti\s above. Cf. i.2.62.
krei=tton: sc. e)sti/.
e)pi/: in the case of.
a)gnoou=si: fail to recognize.
w(/sper gignome/nous fi/lous: “just as though friends were made from.” For the acc. abs. of the pers. verb, see GMT. 853; H. 974: and, for the comparison with an assumed case, GMT. 867.
kai\ mh\n ... fu=nai: and yet it is a great inducement to friendship to be born of the same parents.
po/qos tis: a sort of yearning. po/qos is instinctive, fili/a rational.
tou\s sunade/lfous: those who have brothers (to defend them).
tou/tois: i.e. toi=s sunade/lfois, the prominent obj. of thought.
to\ dia/foron: the cause of dissension. Cf. tou=to/ ge dh\ *xeiriso/fw| kai\ *cenofw=nti mo/non dia/foron e)n th=| porei/a| e)ge/neto An. iv.6.3
feu/gein: to avoid.

a)gaqo/n: see on
xrhsimw/teron 1.
o(po/te ... e)nde/oi: “but suppose he should be wanting in every brotherly quality.”
e)pixeiroi/h: for the potential opt. in apod., cf. ii.2.3.
w(/sper ou)de/: what was said of kai/ in the note on i. 1. 6 is true also of ou)de/ in neg. sentences.
e)/stin oi(=s: see on e)/stin ou(/stinas i. 4. 2.
kai\ pa/nu: vel maxime.
dia\ tou=to ga\r ... au)to/n: why, just for that reason have I good ground to hate him. For ga/r in an answer, see on i.4.9.
e)/rgw|: see on lo/gw|, e)/rgw| 8.
xrh=sqai: belongs to both a)nepisth/moni and e)gxeirou=nti.
lo/gw|, e)/rgw|: the usual order. Cf. 15, 17; iv. 5. 11. Here, too, it corresponds to eu)= le/gein, eu)= poiei=n. In 6, e)/rgw| was placed first, prob. to emphasize its importance.
a)ll' ou)de/: “and neither.” For a)lla/ in this sense, see Kr. Spr. 69. 4. 2.
ei) ku/na me\n a)\n e)peirw= ktl.: that while you would try etc. For me/n in logically subord. clauses, see on i.4.17.
ei) h)=n, h)spa/zeto, e)xale/painen: all in prot. to a)\n e)peirw=.

tou= o)rgi/zesqai: for the articular
inf. with a)mele/w, see GMT. 793.

au)to/n: i.e. to
 ku/na. For the use of this pron. to recall the main subst., cf. e)gw\ me
 ou)=n basile/a ... ou)k oi)=da o(/ ti dei= au)to
 o)mo/sai An. ii.4.7
fh\|s me/n: correlative to ou)k e)pixeirei=s, but de/ follows e)pi/stasqai because this is placed first in the sentence.
e)/xw: for the ind. with verbs of fearing, see G. 1380; H. 888.
sofi/an: here practical wisdom, as distinguished from e)pisth/mh, theoretical knowledge.
kai\ mh/n: as in 4.
poiki/lon: intricate, lit. variegated. Cf. ou)de\n poiki/lon, a)ll' w(/sper oi( polloi\ (nomi/zousi) Plato Gorg. 491 D.
oi(=s: equivalent to tou/tois a(/, of which a(/ is obj. of e)pi/stasai and tou/tois modifies a(lo/nta.
ou)k a)\n fqa/nois le/gwn: you could not be too quick in telling me, i.e. “pray tell me at once.” Cf. iii.11.1. For the supplementary participle with fqa/nw, see G. 1586; H. 984.
fi/ltron: a love charm, (properly fi/lhtron, from file/w).
ei)dw/s: see on fqa/nois above.
katerga/sasqai: bring about, hence, induce.
o(po/te qu/oi: see on o(po/te bou/loito ii. 1. 18.
e)pi\ dei=pnon: to the usual feast held after sacrifices, to which kinsmen and friends were invited. Cf. ii.9.4.
kata/rxoimi a)\n tou= kalei=n au)to/n: I should take the lead in inviting him.
au)to/s: for the nom. agreeing with omitted subj. of inf., cf. kekthme/nos i. 2. 1.
protre/yasqai: to persuade. Cf. i. 2. 64.
ce/non poih=sai u(pode/xesqai seauto/n: for the unusual order of words, see on i.5.1.
ei)s th\n e)kei/nou: sc. po/lin.
au)to/n (in line 69): myself. For the omission of the pers. pron., see G. 990; H. 680, 3.
e)kei/nw|: dat. of advantage. Cf. h)\n tau=ta/ moi poih/sh|s Cyr. vii. 2. 27. The usual const. is poiei=n tina/ ti.
fi/ltra: with somewhat contemptuous reference to fi/ltron in 11.
a)pekru/ptou: have been keeping (this knowledge) to yourself. Cf. ii. 6. 29; iii. 6. 3.
h)\ o)knei=s: the conj. like the Lat. an, when a previous declarative sent. implies a question.
ai)sxro\s fanh=|s: “appear to lower yourself.”
*xairefw=n: described by Plato (Apol. 21A) as sfodro\s e)f) o(/ ti o(rmh/seie.
h(gemonikw/teros: better fitted to take the first step. Cf. h(gemonikoi\ pro\s ta\ ponhra/ Cyr. ii. 2. 25.
tw=| poiei=sqai: for the articular inf. after verbs and adjs., cf. 11; i. 2. 3.
h(gou/menos: cond., if you take the lead.
tou=to: belongs in meaning to th\n fili/an tau/thn, equivalent to “good terms again.”
pro\s sou= (sc. o)/nta, cf. on ii. 1. 32): “like yourself.”
o(\s keleu/eis: for the causal rel., see G. 1461; H. 910.
nomi/zetai: see on nomi/zwn i. 1. 1.
to\n presbu/teron h(gei=sqai: explanatory appos. to ta)nanti/a.
ou) ga/r: as in i. 3. 10.
o(dou=: for the gen. of separation with verbs of withdrawing, see G. 1117; H. 748.

koi/th| malakh=| timh=sai: cf. eu)nh=| e)ni\ malakh=| Hom. I 619 and pukino\n le/xos 659. Recognition of superiority in age was characteristic of the Greeks. Cf. pa=s h(mi=n ai)dei/sqw to\n e(autou= presbu/teron e)/rgw| te kai\ e)/pei Plato Laws 879 C.
e)/fh: he continued.
to\n a)/ndra: more emphatic than au)to/n.

e)gxei/rei, kai\ u(pakou/setai: try, and he will hearken. For the same use of an ind. after an imv. implying a cond., see ii. 7. 10; iii. 6. 17. Cf. ‘Ask, and it shall be given you: seek, and ye shall find.’
ou)x o(ra=|s: the omission of h)/ (‘asyndeton’) adds vivacity to the question.
ta\ me\n ga/r: the ga/r is to be explained by an omitted sent. like “I say this to you (that he is filo/timos and e)leuqe/rios).” For me/n equivalent to while, see on 9.
katerga/saio: win over.
e)a\n gi/gnhtai: with an omitted apod. like ti/ le/geis or ti/ e)/stai.

ti/ ga\r a)/llo h)\ kinduneu/seis: see on ii.1.17. Cf. su\ ou)de\n a)/llo [poiei=s] h)\ au)to\s a)porei=s kai\ tou\s a)/llous poiei=s a)porei=n Plato Meno 80 A; and classis ad insulam se recepit, nihil aliud quam depopulato hostium agro Livy xxvii. 21. kinduneu/seis has an adv. force with the following verb, “you very likely will.” So often in Plato.
e)pidei=cai: here with the inf. equivalent to show that you are.
e)kei=nos de/: sc. kinduneu/sei e)pidei=cai ei)=nai.
tw\ xei=re, a(\s: for the change in number, see on i.2.14.
e)pi\ tw=| sullamba/nein: so e)pi\ w)felei/a| in 19. See on i. 3. 11.
ou)k a)\n ei)/h: so often in animated discourse, where the opt. expresses a modest claim, without ou)=n. Cf. iii.11.1; Cyr. i. 4. 13; iii. 1. 43.
kai\ mh/n ge: see on i.4.12.
a)delfa/: adj., in pairs.
o)rguia=s: a fathom, from o)re/gein to reach, hence the outspread arms' reach.
a(/ma poih=sai: to act together on.
fi/lw o)/nte: conditional.
diestw=te: concessive.
a(/ma pra/tteton: conveys the idea of “with united efforts,” while a(/ma kai/ in the preceding clause is equivalent to simul ac.

div2.p: Although everybody praises friendship, yet most men strive zealously after almost any other possession rather than a true friend; nevertheless, no other blessing is so well fitted as this to help and delight us in every situation of life.

div3.p: dialegome/nou: see on i.1.11.
e)c w(=n: its antec. is the omitted obj. of dialegome/nou.

e)do/kei tis: best rendered impers., it seemed that
any one.
tou=to, dh/: hoc certe.
pollw=n: gen. of source.
w(s kra/tiston ei)/h: in explanatory appos. with tou=to.
panto\s ma=llon: for everything rather. Cf. pa/nta ma=llon iv. 8. 4.

With this section, cf. quid autem stultius, quam, cum plurimum copiis, facultatibus, opibus possint cetera parare, quae parantur pecunia, equos, famulos, vestem egregiam, vasa pretiosa; amicos non parare, optimam et pulcherrimam vitae, ut ita dicam, supellectilem? Cic. de Am. xv. 55.
ktwme/nous: striving to acquire.
fi/lon de/, o(/: the rel. in the gender of the pred. as in the Lat. amicum, quod bonum esse dicunt. G. 1022; H. 631.
kth/swntai, sw/|zwntai: for the subjv. in obj. clauses, see G. 1374; H. 885 b.
au)toi=s: belongs to oi( o)/ntes (sc. fi/loi, to be supplied from fi/lon) as well as to sw/|zwntai.
a)lla\ kai/: quin etiam.
kamno/ntwn fi/lwn te kai\ oi)ketw=n: “in the case of sick friends and sick servants.”
ta)=lla ta\ pro\s u(gi/eian: “the other means of restoration to health.”
zhmi/an: sc. to\n qa/naton.
e)lattou=sqai: are the worse off.
ou)de\n a)qera/peuton: the double neg. (‘litotes’) adds force.
kai\ pollw=n o)/ntwn: concessive, as is also o)li/gwn o)/ntwn.

to\ plh=qos ei)do/tas: cf. querebatur (Scipio) quod omnibus in rebus homines diligentiores essent: capras et oves quot quisque haberet dicere posse, amicos quot haberet non posse dicere Cic. de Am. xvii. 62.
ou(\s ... e)/qesan: explanatory of tou/tous.

pa/lin a)nati/qesqai: pa/lin is often added to verbs compounded with a)na/, as we say ‘to take back again.’ Cf. pa/lin a)nerasqh=nai iii. 5. 7. For the meaning of the verb, see on i.2.44. The inf. is used here where we might expect the participle (after o(ra=n), because the influence of e)/fh is still felt.
tosou=ton: only so much, i.e. so little. Similarly, du/namin is equivalent to weakness in An. i.6.7
xrh/simon, xrhsto/s: for the ‘parechesis,’ see on xrh/mata ii. 3. 1.

e(auto
 ta/ttei: devotes himself. Cf. w(s ga xrhma/twn e(w/ra th
 po/lin deome/nhn, e)pi\ to\ pori/zein tau=ta e(auto
 e)/tace Ages. ii. 25.
pro\s pa=n to\ e)llei=pon, kai/: against loss of every kind, whether etc.
kataskeuh=s: gen. of want, with e)llei=pon.
tw=n koinw=n pra/cewn: ‘brachylogy’ for th=s tw=n koinw=n pra/cewn kataskeuh=s.
sunanali/skwn: this and the succeeding five participles well summarize the ways in which a friend in need shows himself a friend indeed.
plei=sta: frequently.
ta\ w)=ta proakou/ousi: pl. with neut. subj., on account of the preceding and following pls., to preserve ‘concinnity.’
tou/twn: refers back with emphasis to the omitted antec. of a(/. See G. 1030; H. 996 b.
eu)ergetw=n ou)deno\s lei/petai: is behindhand in none with his good offices. For the supplementary participle with lei/petai, see G. 1580; H. 981. Cf. e)llei/pesqai poiw=n ii. 6. 5.
polla/kis a(/: with conj. omitted, as often in an explanatory clause (‘explicative asyndeton’). Kr. Spr. 59. 1. 5.
pro\ tou= fi/lou: sc. e)cergazo/menos, i)dw/n, a)kou/sas, dianu/sas.
me/n, de/: as in i. 4. 17.

div2.p: Friends are of various values. Men would not abandon a friend so readily as they do, if he strove more earnestly to be a valuable friend.

div3.p: e)do/kei moi ktl.: seemed to me suited.
e(auto\n: for the ‘prolepsis,’ see on sunousi/an i. 2. 13.

*)antisqe/nh: of Athens, an inseparable friend of Socrates. See on i. 6. 10. After his master's death, he founded the Cynic school of philosophy, which defined the highest virtue as complete independence of material wants. Cf. iii.11.17; Sym. viii. 4. This form of the acc. is exceptional with Xenophon, who usually writes *)antisqe/nhn, *swkra/thn, etc. G. 230; H. 193.
au)tou=: himself.
a)ci/ai: prices.

duoi=n mnai=n: nominally equivalent to about thirtysix dollars, but in purchasing power equal to six or eight times that amount to-day. Ten minae ($180) is here indicated as a good price for a good slave, which would about
correspond to the $1000 or $1200 often paid for a ‘likely’ house-servant in our own ante-bellum slavery days. See on i. 2. 1.

*niki/as: the well-known Athenian general, who with his whole army was destroyed in the fatal Sicilian expedition (413 B.C.). He had a profitable lease of silver mines at Laurium, in the southern part of Attica, and is said to have employed a thousand slaves. Cf. Thuc. vii. 86.
tala/ntou: see on i.2.1.
skopou=mai dh/: quaero igitur, resuming the thread of the conversation, as in i. 2. 24.
ei) a)/ra: whether possibly. So a)/ra after po/sou in 4.
to\n me/n tina: a certain man.
to\n de/, to\n de/: while another, and a third etc.
pro\ pa/ntwn xrhma/twn: it seems better to const. this phrase with e(loi/mhn, leaving po/nwn as gen. of price with priai/mhn. Others join both gens. with priai/mhn.
po/nwn: cf. tw=n po/nwn pwlou=sin h(mi=n pa/nta ta)ga/q' oi( qeoi/ ii. 1. 20.
fi/lon moi ei)=nai: i.e. w(/ste fi/lon moi ei)=nai.
ei)/ e)sti, kalw=s a)\n e)/xoi: for the ‘mixed’ form of cond. sent., cf. i.2.45; iv. 2. 31.
e(auto/n: see on 1.
a)/ra: as in 2.
a)/cios ei)=nai: instead of the regular a)/cion ei)=nai, as if after a pers. const., with subj. in the nom. case, prob. by assimilation to the preceding a)/cios w)/n.
e(autou=: for the indirect refl., see on i.2.32.

ta\ toiau=ta pa/nta skopw=, mh/: I am pondering all such matters, namely, whether. The clause beginning with mh/ completes epexegetically
ta\ toiau=ta pa/nta. Cf. ei) toi/nun to\n no/mon to\n kaqesthko/ta de/doikas, mh\ o)/neido/s soi ge/nhtai Plato Phaedr. 231 E.
pwlh=|: wants to sell.
tou= eu(ro/ntos: for what he will bring. Cf. po/son a)\n oi)/ei eu(rei=n ta\ sa\ kth/mata pwlou/mena Oec. ii. 3, and tou= eu(ri/skontos Aesch. contra Timarch. 96.
e)pagwgo/n: a temptation.
pa/nu ti: at all, when joined with a negation.

div2.p: Before choosing a man as friend, we should find out what he is, and how he treated his former associates: and if we still desire his friendship, the approval of the gods should be sought. He is then to be won by kind words and deeds; and only good men, who can add something to friendship, win friends. And although jealousy and strife arise even among such, still the virtue common to them all helps to reconcile and re-unite them. Sensual motives should have no place in forming a friendship. Its best motive is found in our wish to further the noble aims of another, and to rejoice with him in their attainment. All pretense is of course to be eschewed; and we should strive to be just what we wish to seem to our friends.

div3.p: ei)s to\ dokima/zein: with regard to judging, to be connected with frenou=n.
a)/cion: sc. e)sti/.
frenou=n (sc. tou\s sunousiasta/s): to give good advice to.
*krito/boule: see on i.3.8.

a)=ra: like the Lat. ne, leaves it to the person addressed to determine the nature of the answer. Evidently Socrates expects an affirmative answer: and his use of a)=ra instead of a)=ra ou) (nonne) is simply courtesy of expression. So in iii. 2. 1. See G. 1603; H. 1015.
ou) dh=ta: the neg. assents to the statement in the preceding sent., as if that had been a question.

ti/ ga/r: “well, then,” used in lively transition. Less animated is
the ti/ de/ in 4.

tw=n plhsi/on dei=tai: “is borrowing” from his neighbors. For de/omai with the gen. alone instead of gen. of pers. and acc. of thing, see Kr. Spr. 47. 16. 7. The ellipsis is common in Eng., e.g., ‘Give to him that asketh thee, and from him that would borrow of thee turn not thou away.’
me/ntoi: vero.
dussu/mbolos: hard to get on with. Cf. Plato Rep. 486 B.
lamba/nwn h(/detai: is glad to get.
e)moi\ me\n dokei=: like e)moi\ me\n e)do/kei i. 2. 62.
sxolh\n poiei=tai: finds leisure.
h)\ o(po/qen kerdanei=: than the occupation from which he hopes to gain.
pare/xein: to raise up.
kakw=n: bad qualities.

ei) e)/xoi, a)ne/xetai: the opt. supposes a case, the indic. then assumes it as real. So ei)/h, tugxa/nei in 5. Cf. ei) de/ tis to\ parauti/ka me\n mh\ e)qe/loi cumplei=n, mete/xein de\ bou/letai th=s a)poiki/as but suppose a man should not care to sail at once (with the expedition) and yet desires a share in the colony Thuc. i. 27. For the indic. in first place, cf. ei) diabe/blhntai, ei) fo/bointo Plato Phaedo 67 E.
eu)= pa/sxwn a)ne/xetai: lets himself receive favors. See on lamba/nwn 3. a)ne/xetai (lit. endures) is ironical. Cf. a)neco/meqa u(po\ sou= eu)ergetou/menoi Cyr. v. 1. 26.
oi)=mai me/n: for me/n, see on i.1.1.
ta)nanti/a tou/twn: as in i. 2. 60.

tw=n dia\ tou= sw/matos h(donw=n: cf. tw=n dia\ sto/matos h(de/wn i. 4. 5. Plato also (Rep. 328 D) has the expression ai( kata\ to\ sw=ma h(donai/, which Aristotle (Eth. Nic. vii. 8. 4) condenses into swmatikai\ h(donai/. Cf. also tw=n peri\ to\ sw=ma h(donw=n Hell. vi.1.16
eu)/nous: the appropriate contrast to the quality described in 2 (o(/stis ... misei=).
e)llei/pesqai: middle.
poiw=n: supplementary participle, as in ii. 4. 7.
toi=s xrwme/nois: his friends.
tau=ta: the qualities mentioned in 5.
pro\ tou= xrh=sqai: “before we have tested them by experience.”

tou/tw| pisteu/omen poih/sein: for the omission of the subj. of the inf. when it is the same as the obj. of the main verb, see G. 895, 2; H. 941, and cf. ti/ ou)=n *(omh/rw| ou) pisteu/eis kalw=s le/gein Plato Charm. 161 A.
kai\ dh/: so also.
a)/ndra dh=lon ei)=nai eu)ergeth/sonta: for the pers. const. with dh=lo/s ei)mi, see on i.1.2.
i(/ppois: emphatic position.
o(rw=: equivalent to oi)=da.

xrw/menon: represents an impf. indic. in direct discourse. Cf. oi)=da de\ ka)kei/nw swfronou=nte e)/ste *swkra/tei sunh/sthn i. 2. 18. The context must determine whether the participle is pres. or imperfect. See GMT. 140, 119; H. 982.
ka)/n: equivalent to kai\ a)/n.
ei)=en: very well, introduces a transition.
ta\ para\ tw=n qew=n: the advice of the gods, to be obtained through divination. See on i. 1. 3.
ei) sumbouleu/ousin: indir. question, explaining ta\ para\ tw=n qew=n. See on i. 5. 1.
