o(\n a)\n h(mi=n te dokh=|: sc. fi/lon poiei=sqai.
o(/pws: how.
ma\ *di/a: introduces a neg. statement, but does not answer e)/xeis negatively.
kata\ po/das: cursu, by chasing them. Cf. iii. 11. 8; Cyr. i. 6. 40; Cyn. v. 29.

w(/sper oi( e)xqroi/: we might expect another animal in the third place, as ka/proi (suggested by Ernesti). Perhaps oi( e)xqroi/ has strayed back from the following sentence. e)xqro/s and pole/mios are properly distinguished, like inimicus and hostis in Latin; but occasionally confused, as here. Cf. oi( pate/res h(mw=n to\n *mh=don e)xqro\n e)/xontes Thuc. vi. 17.
e)pw|da/s, fi/ltra: spells, charms. Cf. iii. 2. 6; Plato Charm. 157 A.
e)pa/|dontes: cf. xrh\ ta\ toiau=ta w(/sper e)pa/|dein e(autw=| Plato Phaedo 114 D.
oi(=s a)/n: for tou/tois, oi(=s a)/n.
filou=ntai u(p) au)tw=n: “gain their affection.”

a(\ me\n ai( *seirh=nes e)ph=|don: Cf. ‘what songs the Syrens sang, or what name Achilles assumed when he hid himself among the women, though puzzling questions, are not beyond conjecture.’ Sir Thomas Browne, Urn Burial, c. iv. Acc. to Homer, there were two Sirens, whose song is given, m 184-191. Later writers name three, Ligeia, Leucosia, Parthenope (or Aglaopheme, Molpe, Thelxiepeia). For a fuller account, see Seyffert, Dict. Class. Antiq., s.v. Sirens.
toia/de tis: as in i. 1. 1.— deu=r) a)/ge dh\ ktl.: cf. Hom. m 184, where the verse begins deu=r' a)/g) i)w/n.
ou)/k: for the accent, see G. 138, 1; H. 112 a.
toi=s e)p' a)reth=| filotimoume/nois: those who prided themselves on their calor.

sxedo/n ti toiau=ta: talia fere.—oi(=a mh\ nomiei= ktl.: quae si audiat, a laudatore irridendi causa dici non existimabit. For mh/ with the fut. indic. in clauses of result, see G. 1447; H. 1021 b. For the ‘Attic’ fut. (nomiei=), see on ii.1.24.
e)xqi/wn: hated rather (than a friend). The subj. of ei)/h is, of course, the person who seeks to make friends.
a)pelau/noi: sc. a)/n.
ei) e)painoi/h: explains ou(/tw.
ou)/k: see on 11.
me/n: followed by no correlative; cf. prw=ton me/n in 8, and a(\ me/n in 11. In this usage, it is a weak form of mh/n indeed, truly. Kr. Spr. 69. 35. 1.

*periklh=s: the most illustrious of Athenian statesmen, to whose wise and consistent policy Athens owed her growth to imperial power in the penthkontaeti/a or half-century between the Persian and the Peloponnesian wars. Cf. Thuc. i. 89-118.
e)poi/ei: for dependent secondary tenses of the indic. in indirect discourse, see G. 1497, 2; H. 931.

*qemistoklh=s: the famous leader of the Greeks at the battle of Salamis (480 B.C.). For an account of his brilliant and successful leadership on that occasion, see Hdt. viii. 56 ff., and, for later events in his checkered career, Thuc. i. 136-138. Pericles owed his fame and influence chiefly to the magic of his eloquence, while Themistocles became the popular favorite by his deeds. Cf. iv.2.2. That the Xenophontic Socrates had no intention of detracting from the glory of Pericles's services may be seen from Sym. viii. 39, skepte/on me/n soi poi=a e)pista/menos *qemistoklh=s i(kano\s e)ge/neto th\n *(ella/da e)leuqerou=n, skepte/on de\ poi=a/ pote ei)dw\s *periklh=s kra/tistos e)do/kei th=| patri/di su/mboulos ei)=nai, a)qrhte/on de\ kai\ pw=s pote *so/lwn filosofh/sas no/mous krati/stous th=| po/lei kate/qhke—
where the thought is, that Themistocles was great in action, Pericles in counsel, Solon in legislation. Here, Socrates is emphasizing the necessity of supplementing words with deeds. Both are essential to the winning of a worthy man's friendship.

ei) me/lloimen, dei= gene/sqai: if we would succeed, we must become. The apod. to such a prot. as ei) me/lloimi generally contains an idea of obligation, expressed by dei=n or dei=sqai, as here, or by a verbal in -te/on. Cf. An. iii. 3. 16, Hell. iv.8.5
le/gein te kai\ pra/ttein: these words may, as some editors think, refer to the eloquence of Pericles and the deeds of Themistocles; but the phrase is a common one, and serves to round the period.
su\ d' w)/|ou: see on tou\s de\ kalou/s i. 3. 13.
kai/: even.
e(w/rwn ga/r: for ga/r, see on i.4.9.
kai/: also, belongs to oi)=sqa/ tinas.

peri\ ou(= dialego/meqa: which is the point under discussion. “Poor speakers and good ones may indeed find friends etc.; it does not therefore follow that men who are wholly worthless can win friends: and that is the point at issue.”
fi/lous (after a)gaqou/s): pred. acc., for friends.
e)kei=no: that point, like Lat. illud, refers with emphasis to what follows.
ei) e)/stin: whether it is possible.
e)c e(toi/mou: readily. Cf. ex facili Tacitus Agric. 15.

o(\ tara/ttei se (sc. tou=to/ e)stin), o(/ti: what puzzles you is the fact that.
Cf. o(\ me\n pa/ntwn qaumasto/taton a)kou=sai, o(/ti w(=n e)ph|ne/samen Plato Rep. 491 b.
xalepw/teron xrwme/nous: sc. a)llh/lois.
i)diw=tai: individuals.

prosie/menai: admitting to themselves. Cf. e)gw\ ga kako
 ou)de
 ou)d' ai)sxro
 prosh/somai Cyr. vii. 1. 13.
polemikw=s: hostiliter.

ou)/te ga/r: not followed by a correlative ou)/te, an irregularity easily explained by the vivacity of the conversation. Instead of a second ou)/te, we have (in 20) a)lla\ mh\n ou)d' a)/n, and, instead of a third ou)/te, the clauses beginning ei) de\ dh/.
pefuke/nai: to be by nature.
ei) de\ ... stasia/zousi, kai\ misou=sin: the third and strongest ground for Critobulus's discouragement. The cond. is assumed as real, if, as you say.
e(autoi=s: for a)llh/lois, the refl. for the reciprocal. G. 996; H. 686 b. So in iii. 5. 16, where, as here, a)llh/lois immediately follows.
ti/nes e)/ti: who then.
e)/stai: will abide.

e)/xei me\n poiki/lws pws tau=ta: these things (love and hate) have
somewhat complicated relations.
ta\ filika/: dispositions toward friendship.
polemiko/n: see on xrhsimw/teron ii. 3. 1.
dusmene/s: an element of discord.
mishto\n de\ o( fqo/nos: and envy leads to hate. The verbal in -to/s, usually passive, has here an active meaning.
a)ll' o(/mws: corresponds to me/n in 21.
diaduome/nh: slipping through. Cf. serpit enim nescio quo modo per omnium vitas amicitia Cic. de Am. xxiii. 87.
dia\ th\n a)reth/n: contrasted with fu/sei 21. On the one hand, love and hate work as natural powers in men; on the other, the acquired and cultivated virtue in men controls their lives as it will.
ai(rou=ntai me/n: followed by kai\ du/nantai instead of du/nantai de/, the kai/ strengthening the statement somewhat.
toi=s tw=n w(rai/wn a)frodisi/ois: see on i.3.8, 10.
h(do/menoi: concessive.
e)gkarterei=n: to control their desires, not to be joined with h(do/menoi.
du/nantai de\ kai/: see on a)dikei= de\ kai/ i. 1. 1.
xrhma/twn: gen. with koinwnei=n.
nomi/mws: equivalent to dikai/ws, keeping within the law. Cf. di/kaios, w(/ste bla/ptein me\n mhde\ mikro\n mhde/na ktl., the closing words of the Memorabilia, iv. 8. 11.
diati/qesqai: to adjust.
ei)s to\ metamelhso/menon: to an extent which they would regret.

proi+e/nai:
for the inf. with verbs of preventing, cf. i.6.6; ii. 1. 16.
a)fairou=si: exclude.
ta\ twn fi/lwn: their friends' interests.
e(autw=n: possessive gen. as predicate. G. 1095; H. 732 b.
timw=n: depends on koinwnou/s.
w)feli/mous a)llh/lois: mutually serviceable.
a)\n ei)=en: potential optative.
toi=s fi/lois ta\ di/kaia bohqei=n: to assist his friends in what is right.
a)/rcas: having become archon. See on bouleu/sas i. 1. 18.
h(=tton dunh/setai, a)dunatw/teros e)/stai: rhetorical variation in expression.
a)lla\ kai/: nay, even.
sunqeme/nous: to agree and, i.e. with united powers. For the acc., see G. 928, 2; H. 941.
a)gw=nas e)ni/kwn: for the cognate acc., see G. 1052; H. 716 a.
e)kei=: i.e. e)n toi=s gumnikoi=s a)gw=si.
politikoi=s: sc. a)gw=si.
th\n po/lin eu)ergetei=n: sc. meta\ tou/tou.
lusitelei=: iuvat.

kthsa/menon:
see on a(pto/menon i. 3. 8.
koinwnoi=s: for the const., see on dou/lois ii. 1. 12.
a)lla\ mh/n: but further. See on i. 1. 6.
ka)kei=no: see on 16.
kai\ mh/n: strong transition, and again.—oi( summaxei=n e)qe/lontes ktl.: i.e. you must win not merely their willingness, but also their readiness. Cf. i.4.18.
krei=tton (sc. e)sti/): better, i.e. more advantageous.
e)la/ttonas: sc. o)/ntas, concessive.
a)lla/: breaks off the argument.
e)/fh: he continued.
qhra=n: cf. i.2.24.
dia\ to\ e)rwtiko\s ei)=nai: by being inclined to love.
w(=n a)/n: equivalent to e)a/n tinwn.
o(/los w(/rmhmai: I strice with all my being.
filw=n: diligendo.

kai\ a)ntepiqumei=sqai th=s sunousi/as: and to have my companionship sought also in return, the obj. of the act. being retained with the passive. This unusual const. is prob. due to the desire to continue the parallelism of the preceding clauses.
tou/twn: sc. tou= filei=n, tou= poqei=n, tou= e)piqumei=n sunei=nai. Critobulus also must win love by showing love.
deh=son: for the participle as a special form of antec. for a cond. rel. clause, see GMT. 552.

a)pokru/ptou: for the double acc. with verbs of concealing, see G. 1069;
H. 724.
ou)k a)pei/rws e)/xein: I have some experience.
pa/lai e)piqumw=: for the pres. with pa/lai, see G. 1258; H. 826.
a)/llws te kai/: see on a)/llws te i. 2. 59.
e)carke/sei: see on a)ciw/seis ii. 1. 12.
yuxa/s, sw/mata: accs. of specification.
to\ ta\s xei=ras ktl.: const. to\ poiei=n tou\s kalou\s u(pome/nein tina\ prosfe/ronta ta\s xei=ras. Socrates asserts that his art (e)pisth/mh) does not include submitting to physical caresses.
*sku/llhs: cf. Homer's description of this monster (m 85 ff.).
*seirh=nas: see on 11.
u(pome/nein (after fasi/n): equivalent to non fugere. This and the other infs. (feu/gein, khlei=sqai) represent the impf. of direct discourse.
w(s ou) prosoi/sontos: sc. mou=, which is added to filh/sontos in 33. For w(s with the gen. abs., see on w(s shmai/nontos i. 1. 4; GMT. 864; H. 978.
qa/rrei: never fear.— eu)qu/s, su/ ge ktl.: En, statim tu, Critobule, dixisti ea, quae inutilia tibi fore praedico (Schneider).

kaloi/, ai)sxroi/: Critobulus has been using the word kalo/s
of outward beauty; Socrates now shifts its meaning to beauty of character, while retaining ai)sxroi/ (ugly) in its physical sense. Critobulus then, by distinguishing between kalou/s and a)gaqou/s, removes the ambiguity, and the conversation proceeds.
kai\ h(de/ws: and that with pleasure.
kalei=sqai: we expect u(polamba/nesqai or dokei=n ei)=nai.
tw=n fi/lwn ta\ qhratika/: the arts for winning friends.
kateipei=n sou: to say in disparagement of you, humorously used of a favorable utterance. Critobulus, appreciating the pleasantry, replies kathgo/rei go on with your accusation.

a)/gasai/ te au)tou=: the gen. of the person with a)/gamai is very rare when the quality which occasions the admiration is omitted. Usually, when the gen. is used, the quality admired is expressed in an explanatory sent., as in iv. 2. 9, or by a participle added to the genitive. Cf. a)/gamai tou= katametrh/santo/s (who has measured off) soi kai\ diata/cantos e(/kasta tou/twn Oec. iv. 21.
tou\s e)painou=ntas: the idea of praising is contained in a)/gasai and e)piqumei=s fi/los au)tou= ei)=nai.

diaba/llesqai: to be taken humorously, like kateipei=n and proskathgorh/sw. The entire passage is a good example of one form of the Socratic method. Cf. e)/paizen a(/ma spouda/zwn i. 3. 8. Its true meaning is “It is plain that the plan which I propose is the simplest and surest way to secure for yourself the friendship of others.” diaba/llesqai is perhaps a heightening of kateipei=n, and eu)noi+kw=s e)/xein of a)/gasai.
a)lla\ kai/: nay, even, in spirited retort.
pro\s ou(/s: with omission of tou/tous. So in the next section.

e)pimelh\s tw=n fi/lwn: obs. the gradation of feelings which help to establish friendship. First we have admiration (a)/gasai), next good will (eu)noi+kw=s e)/xein), next desire to serve (e)pimelh/s) (Weiske).
ou)deni\ ou(/tw xai/reis w(s fi/lois a)gaqoi=s: Socrates takes this position for himself in i. 6. 14.
toi=s e(autou=: equivalent to toi=s seautou=. See on ii. 1. 31.
mhxanw/menos: for the supplementary participle, see on ii.1.24.
e)/gnwkas: you recognize.
a)ndro\s a)reth/n: a man's chief excellence.

tou\s d' e)xqrou\s kakw=s: the Socratic ethics here does not rise above the ordinary Greek standard. Cf. Xenophon's description of the character of Cyrus An. i.9.11 Cf. also iii. 9. 8, where Socrates explains what he understands by fqo/nos.
ei)=nai/ me: for the subj. of the principal verb expressed with the inf., see H. 940 b.
su/nqhron: see on qhrw/menos i. 2. 24. So qhratika/ 33, qhra=n 39.
w(/sper ou)k e)pi\ soi\ o)/n: as if it were not in your power. For the participle with w(/sper, expressing comparison, see G. 1576; H. 978 a.

*)aspasi/as: the celebrated mistress of Pericles, famed for her beauty and intellect. Socrates, too, admired her brilliant gifts, but when he speaks of her as of a teacher, in Xenophon and Plato, the term must be accepted as ironical. It is obvious that no Aspasia was needed to teach Socrates the lessons here inculcated.
promnhstri/das: matchmakers.
ou)k e)qe/lein: “it was not their way.”

e)painei=n:
join with yeudome/nas, to praise untruthfully.
a)lhqeu/w: say with truth.
oi(=os sullamba/nein: see on oi(/ous te/mnein i. 4. 6.
ei) de\ mh/: otherwise. For the use of this phrase in alternatives, see GMT. 478; H. 906.
ou)k a)\n e)qe/lois: instead of continuing with the inf. (after oi(=os), we have the opt., as a more independent construction.
po/tera d' a)/n: for de/, see on i.3.13.
ga/r: that is.
th\n nau=n: his ship.
tina\ e)lpi/da: any idea.
mh\ a)pole/sai: for mh/ with the inf. of indirect discourse, see on mhdeni/ i. 2. 39.

w(s a)\n ... politikw=|: sc. o)/nti. With w(s a)/n should be supplied the clause pei/saimi e(auth\n e)pitre/yai. Cf. iii.6.4. In the following w(s o)/nti (without a)/n), however, the meaning is on the ground that you are a man skilled etc.
seauto/n: see on ei)=nai/ me 35.

suntomwta/th ktl.: cf. quamquam praeclare Socrates hanc viam ad gloriam proximam et quasi compendiariam dicebat
esse, si quis id ageret, ut qualis haberi vellet talis esset Cic. de Off. ii. 12. Cf., also, i. 7. 1.
e)n a)nqrw/pois: see on iii.6.2.
a)retai/: excellencies, skill in different matters.
ou(/tws: i.e. in the manner described by me.

div2.p: Socrates gives good counsel to Aristarchus, who complains of the difficulty of supporting a large family of dependent female relatives. After advising him to give to them some useful employment, Socrates shows that honest work is not beneath the dignity of a freeman. By this, we gain for the home prosperity, mutual appreciation, and happiness.

div3.p: ta\s a)pori/as, ta\s me/n, ta\s de/: acc. of the whole, followed by its parts, in apposition. Cf. i.2.60.
gnw/mh|: “by counsel,” as shown in chaps. 7, 8, contrasted with dida/skein kata\ du/namin a)llh/lois e)parkei=n, in chaps. 9, 10.

a(\ su/noida au)tw=|: what I know of him. suneide/nai ti/ tini is to know anything with another, then to know anything of another. Cf. i(/na tou/tw| me\n tau=ta suneidw=men in order that we may know this of him Plato Prot. 348 B.
*)ari/starxon: otherwise unknown.
a)lla\ mh/n: yes indeed.

e)stasi/asen h( po/lis: for the revolution
in Athens at the close of the Peloponnesian war, cf. Hell. ii. 3. 4; Grote, Hist. of Greece, c. lxv.
a)delfidai=: brothers' or sisters' daughters, nieces.
tou\s e)leuqe/rous: masc., as including himself.
lamba/nomen: we are getting. Cf. i. 3. 5.
tw=| a)/stei: the city proper, as distinguished from the country.
pro/teron, h)/: with no temporal meaning, more likely, than. GMT. 654.
tou\s oi)kei/ous periora=n a)pollume/nous: to allow one's relatives to starve.
ti/ pote/ e)stin: how in the world does it happen?
*kera/mwn: otherwise unknown.

su\ de\ pollou/s: we might expect su\ de\ o)li/gous, for the fourteen e)leu/qeroi were very few in comparison with the immense number of slaves supported by rich men like Ceramon; but the phrase may be a simple repetition to maintain the parallelism with the pollou\s tre/fwn of the preceding clause.

para\ soi/: in your house. Cf. Lat. apud, Ger. bei, Fr. chez.—
nh\ *di/a: the affirmative formula here is perplexing; of the various explanations offered, that suggested by Kühner's paraphrase seems most reasonable, viz. “Aye, truly, it is a shame that we should live in such poverty; for I have to support gentlewomen, whose standard of living is, and ought to be, different from that of slaves.”
a)=r' ou)=n: introduces an apparently neutral question.
ti/ de\ a)/rtoi: well, how about bread?

i(ma/tia ktl.: the i(ma/tion (toga) was a square cloak covering the whole body. Under this was worn the tunic (xitw/n), of which xitwni/skos (tunicula) is a diminutive. The xlamu/s was a short military mantle; the e)cwmi/s, a sort of sleeveless short tunic worn by slaves and the lower classes generally. See Guhl and Koner, Life of the Greeks and Romans, p. 160 ff.
e)/peita: then. So ei)=ta in 6.

leitourgei=n: i.e. to perform those public services which the state required from its richer citizens, such as furnishing and training choruses for dramatic performances, and fitting out triremes for the use of the state. For an account of these and the less important ‘liturgies,’ see Schömann, Antiq. of Greece, p. 459 ff. For the derivation of the word, see Lex. s. v. leitourgo/s.

*kolluteu/s:
of the Attic deme Collytus.
w)nou/menoi e)/xousin: purchase and keep.
w(/st' a)nagka/zein: so that they can compel.
a(\ kalw=s e)/xei: “whatever is desirable,” sc. e)rga/zesqai.
e)gw\ de/ (sc. e)/xw): while I have with me.
e)/peita: well, then.
a)/llo: for its position, see on ii.1.17.
a(/, tou/twn: see on tou/twn ii. 4. 7.
th\n a)rgi/an, th\n a)me/leian, w)fe/lima o)/nta: for the neut. pred. after fem. or masc. substs., see on xrhsimw/teron ii. 3. 1.
e)/maqon: placed at the beginning for emphasis, and also in order to bring po/teron next to w(s.
w(s: belongs to both o)/nta and poih/sousai.
o)/nta, poih/sousai: for the participles in different cases, connected by ou)/te, ou)/te, see on ii.2.5.
w)felhso/menai: fut. mid. in pass. sense.
pote/rws: introducing the double question, but not part of it. See on i. 6. 15.
a)rgou=ntes (in line 66): conditional.—ei) a)rgou=ntes bouleu/ointo ktl.: “if they should listlessly plan for success.”
a)lla\ kai\ nu=n me/n: “nay, more, as things now are.”
ki/ndunos (sc. e)sti/) a)pe/xqeian gi/gnesqai: for the inf. with ki/ndunos (a less common const. than mh/ with the subjv.), see G. 1521; H. 952.
e)a\n prostath/sh|s o(/pws: if you will provide that. Cf. kai\ keleu/ousi prostath=sai labo/nta xrh/mata o(/pws e)kpleu/sh| h( stratia/ An. v.6.21
th\n a)p' e)kei/nwn: sc. eu)ergesiw=n.
au)ch/sete: pl., as xa/ris implies a mutual relation between the giver and the recipients.
ei) me\n toi/nun e)/mellon: if, to be sure, they were going.
proairete/on h)=n: without a)/n, like the impfs. e)/dei, e)xrh=n, and others denoting propriety or obligation. See on i. 3. 3.
w(s e)/oike: sc. from your account.
pa/ntes: everybody.
mh\ o)/knei, kai\ u(pakou/sontai: see on e)gxei/rei, kai\ u(pakou/setai ii. 3. 16.
a)lla/: “well, now,” a lively expression of assent.
pro/sqen me/n, nu=n de/: although formerly, now however. Only the second clause is introduced by w(/ste. For me/n equivalent to while, see on i.4.17.

ou) prosie/mhn danei/sasqai: I would have nothing to do with
borrowing.
o(\ a)\n la/bw, e(/cw. For the retention of the direct forms in indirect discourse, see on e)poi/ei ii. 6. 13.
ei)s e)/rgwn a)formh/n: to provide materials for their work.
u(pomenei=n: that I will bring myself.
au)to\ poih=sai: i.e. danei/zesqai.

e)rgazo/menai h)ri/stwn ktl.: the informal nature of the a)/riston enabled them to take it while at their work; the dei=pnon, as the chief meal of the day, was eaten at the close of the day's work. For an account of the Greek meals, see Becker, Charicles (Eng. transl.), p. 310 ff.
e(autou/s: for the gender, see on e)leuqe/rous 2.
e)fi/loun, h)ga/pa: sc. respectively au)to/n and au)ta/s.
a)rgo\n e)sqi/ein: “ate the bread of idleness.”
ei)=ta: as in i. 2. 26.
o)/i+n: the Ionic form, generally used by Xenophon instead of the Attic contracted oi)=n. Cf. iii.2.1; iv. 3. 10.
qaumasto\n poiei=s, o(/s: you are acting strangely, to. For the causal rel., see on o(\s keleu/eis ii. 3. 15.
o(/ ti a)\n mh\ la/bwmen: unless we get it.
nai\ ma\ *di/a, “yes, of course he does.”
kai\ u(ma=s au)ta/s: i.e. you too, as well as my master's other possessions.

e)pei/: for.—
mh\ a)po/lhsqe: subjv. retained, to express vividly the object of fear. Cf. o)knoi/hn me\n a)/n, mh\ h(ma=s katadu/sh| An. i.3.17
a)nti\ kuno/s: in place of (“as good as”) a dog. Cf. e)gw\ ga\r a)nti\ tou= le/onto/s ei)mi/ soi Ar. Knights 1043.

div2.p: Euthērus, who has seen better days, is trying to support himself by the labor of his hands. Socrates advises him to seek a position as overseer of some estate, so as to secure a provision for his old age; and overrules his objections to assuming the position of a subordinate.

div3.p: dia\ xro/nou: interiecto aliquo tempore.
po/qen fai/nh|: cf. po/qen, w)= *sw/krates, fai/nh| Plato Prot. init.
*eu)/qhre: not otherwise known.
u(po\ ... pole/mou: the end of the Peloponnesian war (404 B.C.) is meant. By the terms of the treaty of peace, the Athenians lost all their possessions outside of Attica.
nuni\ me/ntoi au)to/qen: just at present, however, from the city itself.
a)fh|re/qhmen: pl., refers to the community as the sufferers.
e)n th=| u(perori/a|: i.e. in territories outside of Attica.
kth/mata: for the acc. of the obj. retained with the pass., see G. 1239; H. 724 a.
tw=| sw/mati e)rgazo/menos: by the labor of my hands.
dei=sqai: to beg a loan, as the next clause shows.
e)/xonta: for the acc., see on maqo/ntas poiei=n i. 1. 9.
e)f' o(/tw|: on which, as security.
misqou=: gen. of price.

ta\ e)pith/deia e)rga/zesqai: see on o)li/ga
e)rga/zesqai i. 3. 5.
dapa/nhs: money to spend, on yourself. Socrates here lays stress on the needs of the aged; other disadvantages of old age are mentioned iv. 8. 8, Apol. 6
au)to/qen: from this very point, immediately.
tw|, tw=| deome/nw|: to some one, who needs.
tou= sunepimelhsome/nou: a man who will assist in taking charge. The art. is generic. Cf. i.1.13.
e)pistatou=nta: equivalent to e)pista/thn o)/nta, hence used with the genitive. Cf. w(=n a)\n e)pistatw=si zw/|wn Cyr. i. 1. 2. With the verb the dat. is more common.
kai\ mh/n: as in 2 and 5.
to\ u(pai/tion ei)=nai: the idea of being answerable. The adj. is acc., as referring to a general subject; otherwise we might have u(pai/tios.
mh\ a)gnw/moni: for mh/ with adjs., see on i.1.14.
e)pei\ kai/: see on ii.7.14.
qauma/zw ei): see on i.1.13.

a)ne/gklhton diagi/gnesqai: without o)/nta, like diatelei=s in i. 6. 2. a)ne/gklhton is to be joined with oi(=s nu=n
e)rga/zesqai fh/|s without blame from those for whom, as you say, you are now working.
diw/kein: to seek. Cf. se\ me\n diw/contai kai\ filh/sousin Plato Theaet. 168 A.
u(pome/nein: bear patiently.
a)\n ei)=nai: the particle should be repeated with ma/lista eu(rei=n and r(a=|sta zh=n. See on i. 3. 15.

div2.p: Socrates recommends Crito, who complains of being pestered by sycophants, to secure against them the assistance of the poor but worthy Archedēmus. By his efficient services Archedēmus gains the gratitude and friendship, not only of Crito, but also of other prominent citizens.

div3.p: *kri/twnos: a wealthy Athenian, and one of Socrates's best friends. After the philosopher's condemnation, Crito vainly tried to induce him to escape from prison (cf. Plato Crito). Like other rich citizens, he suffered from the vexatious calumnies and lawsuits fastened on him by malicious accusers (sukofa/ntai). This species of blackmail seems to have been viewed indulgently by the community, as affording a wholesome check to the rapacity of ‘capital,’ and as conducing to the success of the democracy. See Becker, Charicles, pp. 55, 56, and the passages there cited.
xalepo\n o( bi/os: for the neut., see on xrhsimw/teron ii. 3. 1.
ta\ e(autou=: his own affairs.
pra/gmata e)/xein: have trouble, occasioned by lawsuits.
ku/nas de/: for de/, see on i.3.13.

a)peru/kwsi: Ionic and poetic.
Cf. An. iii. 1. 25.
ou)k a)\n ou)=n qre/yais: should you not, then, keep?
o(/stis e)qe/loi: for the opt. by assimilation, see on ai)sqanoi/meqa i. 5. 1.
h(de/ws g' a)/n: sc. qre/yaimi.
o(/pws mh/: instead of the more usual simple mh/. G. 1379; H. 887 a.
e)p' au)to/n me: stronger than e)p) e)mauto/n.
tra/poito: see on e)qe/loi above.

oi(/w| soi a)ndri/: equivalent to toiou/tw| a)ndri\ oi(=os su\ ei)=. For the peculiar assimilation of oi(/w| soi, see G. 1036; H. 1002. Cf. toi=s oi(/ois h(mi=n te kai\ u(mi=n to such persons as we and you, Hell. ii. 3. 25.
ei)si\n tw=n toiou/twn: there are some among such persons.
pa/nu a)\n filotimhqei=en: would feel greatly honored.
fi/lw|: for the pred. dat. with xra/omai, see H. 777 a.
e)k tou/twn (sc. lo/gwn): as a result of this conversation.

*)arxe/dhmon: prob. the same man that afterward attained considerable power in Athens. Cf. *)arxe/dhmos o( tou= dh/mou to/te proesthkw/s Hell. i.7.2, where he is mentioned as having charge of the distribution of the diwbeli/a or theater fund. As a popular orator, he was ridiculed by Aristophanes Frogs v. 417 ff.
oi(=os kerdai/nein: for the inf., see on oi(/ous i. 4. 6.
a)po\ panto/s: “from any and every occupation,” good or bad. Cf. the adj. panou=rgos ready to do anything, hence unscrupulous.

a)po\ tw=n sukofantw=n: a)po/ with the gen., instead of para/, as implying an unwilling surrender on the part of the sukofa/ntai, while lamba/nein para/ tinos is equivalent to accipere ab aliquo. Archedēmus knew how to make the accusers disgorge their ill-gotten gains.
a)\n e)/dwke: for the iterative aor. with a)/n, see G. 1296; H. 835 a.

e)ka/lei: sc. to the sacrificial feast. See on ii. 3. 11.—
ta\ toiau=ta e)pemelei=to (sc. au)tou=): paid him similar attentions. For the cognate acc., see on fronti/zontas ta\ toiau=ta i. 1. 11. Cf. ta\ a)/lla Hell. iv.1.40
oi(=: sibi. For the indir. refl., see on i.2.32.
ma/la periei=pen (impf.) au)to/n: treated him (Crito) with great respect. Cf. kai/ min *)/amasis eu)= periei=pe Hdt. ii. 169.
prosekalei=to ei)s di/khn dhmosi/an: began public proceedings against.
e)/dei kriqh=nai: he would have had to submit to decision. For e)/dei without a)/n, see on proairete/on h)=n ii. 7. 10.

o(/ ti dei= paqei=n h)\ a)potei=sai: a judicial formula, meaning corporal punishment or fine. Cf. Plato Apol. 36B, and polla/kis e)kri/qhn o(/ ti xrh\ paqei=n h)\ a)potei=sai Oec. xi. 25. The passage thus implies that the fellows would not have got off without punishment.
suneidw\s au(tw=| polla\ kai\ ponhra/: conscious of many rascalities.
a)pallagh=nai: liberari.
a)fh=ke: released, withdrew the suit against him.
au)tw=|: i.e. Archedemus.
h)/dh to/te: for the more usual to/t' h)/dh. Cf. iv.8.1. For h)/dh, see on ii.1.5.
e)xri/zeto: sc. tou=to, i.e. to serve Crito's friends.
kai\ ou)x o(/ti: and not only, condensed expression for ou) le/gw o(/ti I do not say that, “it is not enough to say that.” G. 1504; H. 1035. Cf. mh\ o(/ti i. 6. 11.
ei) o)neidi/zoi, e)/fh: like o(po/te qu/oi, e)ka/lei in 4.
diafe/resqai: to be at variance with.
h)/: sc. ai)sxro/n e)stin.
peira=sqai fi/lous poiei=sqai: Xenophon seems to imply that true friendship among rascals is impossible.

div2.p: Socrates persuades Diodōrus to extend aid to Hermogenes, a poor but worthy acquaintance, and thereby to win his friendship; and points out that it is well worth while to gain friends so easily.

div3.p: *diodw/rw|: otherwise unknown.
soi\ a)podra=|: for the dat. of disadvantage, see G. 1170; H. 767 a. Cf. a)pofeu/gein moi Oec. ii. 14. For the acc. with a)podra=|, cf. h)/n tis a)podra=| se tw=n oi)ketw=n Cyr. i. 4. 13.
kai/, ge/: “yes, indeed, and.”
tou/tou: i.e. the runaway.
ti/ ga/r: see on ii.6.2.
kinduneu/ei: indic., anticipating the special case of Hermogenes.
kai\ mh/n: as in i. 6. 3.

*(ermoge/nhs: a loyal follower of
Socrates. He was a son of the rich Hipponīcus, but lived in great poverty, the father's immense wealth having passed to Callias, a son by another wife. Cf. Sym. iii. 14; iv. 46-50; Plato Crat. 384 C, 391 C.
to\ u(phre/thn e)/xein, oi)=mai a)nta/cion ei)=nai: the possession of an assistant is, in my judgment, an equivalent.
paramo/nimon: lit. remaining with, loyal, in contrast with the runaway slave. Cf. ii.4.5.
dia\ ta\ pra/gmata: by reason of the hard times. Cf. ii. 7. 2 fin. On the thought, cf. vilis amicorum est annona, bonis ubi quid deest Horace Epist. i. 12. 24.
a)lla/: see on ii.7.11.
au)to/n: yourself.
to\ praxqh=nai tau=ta: for this (the friendship between you) to be brought about.
ou) polu\ tele/sas: without much outlay. Cf. a)rgu/rion tele/sai ii. 9. 1.
e)/rgon ei)=xe: made it his task. Cf. a)ei\ de\ tiqei\s ta\ tw=n fi/lwn a)sfalw=s a)ei\ a)maurou=n (to impair) ta\ tw=n polemi/wn e)/rgon ei)=xe Ages. xi. 12.
o(/ ti: const. with both participles.

div2.p: The man who aspires to the commandership of an army must understand the art of war, if he would not bring disaster upon the state which he serves. Good generalship necessarily includes other qualifications besides an acquaintance with tactics. A good commander must above all know how to secure the best disposition of his forces. In order to do this, he should be able accurately to estimate the good or bad qualities of his troops, so as to make the best use of each division when occasion demands.

div3.p: o(/ti: instead of the more usual w(s how. So e)ntequ/mhsai o(/ti iii. 3. 11. Cf. o(/ti de\ e)pemelei=to, nu=n tou=to le/cw iv. 7. 1.
tw=n kalw=n: public honors, such as the kaloi\ ka)gaqoi/ should aspire to; a phrase borrowed from the Spartans, cf. De Rep. Lac. iii. 3; iv. 4; Cyr. vii. 3. 16.
e)pimelei=s: studious of.
o)re/gointo: for the opt., see on i.2.57.
*dionuso/dwron: a Sophist from Chios, who, with his brother Euthydemus (not the one mentioned in iv. 2), taught rhetoric and the art of war in Athens. Cf. Plato Euthyd. 271 C.
e)paggello/menon: professing.
e)n th=| po/lei: “among his fellow-citizens,” i.e. not as a mercenary from abroad.
me/ntoi: really.

strathgei=n: the Athenians divided the military command among ten generals, chosen annually. As late as the first Persian war (490 B.C.), they held the supreme command in rotation (cf. the well-known story of Miltiades and his colleagues, Hdt. vi. 110). In later wars, it rarely happened that the entire board of strategi took the field. For an account of their military and civil functions, see Schömann, Antiq. of Greece, p. 420 ff.
au)tou=: i.e. tou= maqei=n.
o(/lhs th=s po/lews: the state's whole interests. For the position of o(/lhs, see G. 979; H. 672 and c.
mega/la: pred. with gi/gnesqai.
e)lqo/nta manqa/nein: to go and learn. Cf. e)lqo/ntas *ku=ron ai)tei=n ploi=a An. i.3.14

memaqhkw/s: “after finishing his course.”—*(/omhros ktl.: the passage is in *g 169, 170, where Priam says of Agamemnon kalo\n d' ou(/tw e)gw\n ou)/pw i)/don o)fqalmoi=sin | ou)d) ou(/tw geraro/n: basilh=i ga\r a)ndri\ e)/oiken.
geraro/n: stately.
ou)/te strathgo/s: before these words ou)/te kiqaristh/s might be expected; prob. omitted as inappropriate to ou)d' e)a\n ai(reqh|.
soi/: under you. For the dat. with verbs of serving, see G. 1159; H. 764, 2.
po/qen: at what point.
ta\ taktika/: tactics, i.e. military drill.
a)lla\ mh/n: atqui.

pollosto\n me/ros: a very small part. Cf.
mikro/n ti me/ros ei)/h strathgi/as ta\ taktika/ Cyr. i. 6. 14.
tw=n ei)s to\n po/lemon: the material of war. For the gen., see G. 1142; H. 754 b.
mhxaniko/n: fertile in device.
fulaktiko/n, kle/pthn: on his guard (against plunderers), ready to seize (another's property by stealth).
a)sfalh=: safe (i.e. cautious), in movement.
fu/sei kai\ e)pisth/mh|: by nature and science.
ke/ramos: tile, in collective sense. The same comparison of a well-built house with an army occurs in Cyr. vi. 3. 25.
a)ta/ktws e)rrimme/na: thrown together in confusion.
e)pipolh=s: on top, refers to the roof of tile (ke/ramos). Similarly, li/qos belongs to ka/tw.
sunti/qetai: sing., agreeing with the nearest substantive (ta\ cu/la), or having as subj. the entire mass of material, thought of as neuter.

pa/nu o(/moion: rem plane similem, a very apt comparison.— prw/tous tou\s a)ri/stous ktl.: cf. the arrangement of Nestor's forces, i(pph=as me\n prw=ta su\n i(/ppoisin kai\ o)/xesfin | pe/zous d' e)co/piqe sth=sen pole/as te kai\ e)sqlou/s, | e(/rkos e)/men pole/moio: kakou\s d' e)s me/sson e)/lassen, | o)/fra kai\ ou)k e)qe/lwn tis a)nagkai/h| polemi/zoi Hom. *d 297300.
u(po\ me\n tw=n, u(po\ de\ tw=n: for u(po\ tw=n me/n, u(po\ tw=n de/, not uncommon in Attic. Cf. ii.2.2.

ei) me
 ktl.: with apod. omitted, a not unusual ellipsis. See G. 1416; H. 904 a, and cf. ei) me
 dw/sousi ge/ras if they shall give me a prize (sc. well and good) Hom. *a 135, kai\ nu=n, a)
 me
 o( *ku=ros bou/lhtai (sc. pare/stw su
 u(mi=n), ei) de\ mh/, u(mei=s th
 taxi/sthn pa/reste Cyr. iv. 5. 10.

to/ te kalo\n kai\ to\ ki/bdhlon: the correlatives te/, kai/, are sometimes used to connect two objects which are to be distinguished or compared, where the Eng. usage would employ a simple ‘and.’ So tou/s te a)gaqou\s kai\ tou\s kakou/s below. Cf. diafe/rei o( turanniko/s te kai\ o( i)diwtiko\s bi/os Hiero i. 2.
ti/ ou)=n ou) skopou=men: equivalent to skopw=men let us consider.
pw=s a)\n au)tw=n mh\ diamarta/noimen: how we can avoid mistaking them. For mh/ with the potential opt. in questions, see GMT. 292, 2.
ti/ de\ tou\s kinduneu/ein me/llontas: sc. poih/somen what shall we do with those about to engage in a hazardous enterprise?
oi( e(/neka e)pai/nou kinduneu/ein e)qe/lontes: cf. ‘Seeking the bubble reputation | Even in the cannon's mouth’ Shak. As You Like It ii. 7.
ou) pa/nu: not at all, answers the last half of the previous question.
kai\ mh/n: see on i.4.12.

polla/
pro\s a(/: “many occasions, where.”
w(sau/tws: in the same way, sc. as on others.
e)ndea=: the missing gen. can readily be supplied.
a)pope/myasqai: for the inf. with ai)sxu/nomai, instead of the supplementary participle, see G. 1581; H. 986.

p.title: A general should make it his chief care to secure the welfare of his troops.

div3.p: *(/omhron: in *b 243.
a)=ra: the connection shows that an affirmative answer is expected. See on ii. 6. 1.
o)/i+es: see on ii.7.13, and, for the thought, cf. Cyr. viii. 2. 14.
kai\ ou(= e(/neka tre/fontai, tou=to e)/stai: and that the purpose for which they are reared shall be attained.

ti/ dh/pote: see on ti/si pote/ i. 1. 1.—a)mfo/teron ktl.: Hom. *g 179. For the gender, see on xrhsimw/teron ii. 3. 1. Plutarch tells us that this was the favorite verse of Alexander the Great, who always carried a copy of the Iliad with him on his campaigns.
a)=ra/ ge: sc. e)ph/|nesen au)to/n.
ou)k ei): not in case that.

kai\ basileu\s a)gaqo/s: i.e. kai\ o(/ti
basileu\s a)gaqo\s a)\n ei)/h.
proesth/koi: should conduct.

e(autou=: it is not necessary to supply mo/nou, as the sole aim in choosing him was the welfare of the people. As he would naturally, however, care for his own interest, i(/na kai/ appropriately follows.
kai/, de/: and also. Cf. i. 1. 3.
strathgo/n: is not redundant, but refers with emphasis to to\n strathgou=nta.
ka/llion, ai)/sxion: const. with a)/llo, the obj. of eu(rei=n.

ta\ me
 a)/lla perih/|rei ktl.: “dismissing consideration of all other qualities, he emphasized only this, that a general must provide for the welfare of those under him.” On perih/|rei, kate/lipe, cf. tw=n polemikw=n perielw
 kai\ to\ to/cw| meleta=n kai\ a)konti/w| kate/lipe tou=to mo/non au)toi=s to\ su
 maxai/ra| ma/xesqai Cyr. ii. 1. 21.

div2.p: The commander of cavalry must himself see that his horses are in good condition. His men must be trained in riding and in prompt obedience. The leader must above all be able to do anything he requires of his men; and must know how to stimulate by words the ambition of his subordinates.

div3.p: i(pparxei=n: in Athens, two commanders of cavalry (i(/pparxoi) were chosen in addition to the ten generals of infantry. Xenophon has left us a special treatise (*(ipparxiko/s) on the duties of the hipparchs.
ou) ga\r dh/: for surely not.
tou= e)lau/nein: sc. e(/neka. For the articular inf., see on i.1.12.

i(ppotoco/tai:
a body of mounted archers, 200 in number, thrown out as light skirmishers in advance of the main army.
tou= gnwsqh=nai: for the sake of becoming known.
e)pei\ kai/: cf. ii.8.5.
a)ll' a)=ra: sc. i(pparxei=n e)pequ/mhsas.
a)\n paradou=nai: sc. ei) i(pparxoi/hs.
pou/: I suppose, with a touch of irony. Cf. o(/ti me\n ga\r e)k th=s xeiro\s dei= r(i/ptesqai to\ spe/rma kai\ su/ pou oi)=sqa Oec. xvii. 7.
a)mbatw=n: by ‘apocope’ from a)nabatw=n. So a)na/mbatos Cyr. iv. 5. 46. See G. 53; H. 84 D.
ga\r ou)=n: yes, of course. For ga/r, see on i.4.9.
tou=to (after a)lla/): connect with to\ e)/rgon.
i)di/a|: “for himself.”
oi( me/n, oi( de/: the well-to-do citizens of Athens were expected to serve in the cavalry, and to furnish their own horses. See Gow, Companion to School Classics, p. 123.

kalw=s te le/geis, kai\ peira/somai:
cf. a)lla\ de/xomai/ te kai\ tou=to e)/stw An. i.8.17
a)nabatikwte/rous: cf. prw=ton me\n tou\s i(ppe/as a)skhte/on, o(/pws e)pi\ tou\s i(/ppous a)naphda=n (to leap on) du/nwntai Hipp. i. 5.

katape/soi: the Greek rider sat without stirrups, on the horse's bare back; and hence had to reckon with the danger of falling off, in case of attack. In the encouraging speech which Xenophon makes to his men (An. iii.2.19), he emphasizes this danger as a weak point of the enemy's cavalry.
th\n a)/mmon: sandy ground, the race-track.
h)\ peira/sh| ... gi/gnontai: cf. deu/teron de/, o(/pws e)n pantoi/ois xwri/ois i(ppa/zesqai dunh/sontai. kai\ ga\r oi( pole/mioi a)/llote e)n a)lloi/ois to/pois gi/gnontai (appear) Hipp. i. 5.
be/ltion: refers to the second of the two suggestions.
tou= ba/llein: obj. gen. with e)pime/leian.
w(s plei/stous: subj. of ba/llein. Cf. Hipp. i. 6.
a)lla\ nu=n ge: like at in Lat., a)lla/ sometimes follows a cond. sent. in the sense of yet at any rate. G. 1422; H. 1046, 2 (a).
pei/qwntai: cf. e)k tou/twn paraskeuaste/on, o(/pws eu)peiqei=s oi( a)/ndres wsin Hipp. i. 7.
On the passage, cf. Hipp. iv. 4.
e)kei=no: see on ii.4.1.
ei)s to\ pei/qesqai au)tou\s e)moi/: to secure me their obedience.
e)a/n ge: yes, if.

dida/cw: for the interr. subjv., see on i.2.36.—On the passage, cf. ei)/s ge mh
 to\ eu)peiqei=s ei)=nai tou\s a)rxome/nous me/ga me
 kai\ to\ lo/gw| dida/skein o(/sa a)gaqa\ e)/ni e)n tw=| peiqarxei=n, me/ga de\ kai\ to\ e)/rgw| [kata\ to
 no/mon] pleonektei=n me
 poiei=n tou\s eu)ta/ktous, meionektei=n de\ e)n pa=si tou\s a)taktou=ntas Hipp. i. 24.
e)pimelei=sqai dei=n kai\ tou= le/gein du/nasqai: should cultivate also the ability to speak. For the articular inf. with e)pimelei=sqai, see GMT. 793, 798.
o(/sa te: correlative with kai\ ei)/ ti a)/llo.
no/mw|: more, “as laid down by law and custom.”
zh=n: “to order our lives,” in the best sense.
dia\ lo/gou: cf. e(rmhnei/an, di) h(=s iv. 3. 12.
ma/qhma: i.e. what one is impelled by his own taste to learn.
a)/rista: adverb.
ta\ spoudaio/tata: matters of greatest importance.

xoro\s ei(=s: contrasted with ou)dei\s a)/lloqen ou)damo/qen. “None of the numerous choruses sent by the various states can compete with the one sent from Athens.” Every four years festival delegations, including choruses, were sent to Delos from the different states of Hellas, in honor of Apollo and Artemis.

eu)andri/a: “a collection of finelooking men.” The handsomest men were chosen to head the procession. So, also, at the Panathenaic festival, the qallofo/roi (bearers of the sacred olive branch) were chosen from among the finest-looking old men. Cf. qallofo/rous ga\r th=| *)aqhna=| tou\s kalou\s ge/rontas e)kle/gontai Sym. iv. 17.

a)lla\ mh\n ktl.: the thought of the passage is, that the Athenians excel all other Greeks in sweetness of voice (eu)fwni/a|, referring back to xoro/s) and in physical beauty (swma/twn mege/qei kai\ r(w/mh|, referring to eu)andri/a), and, above all, in ambition (filotimi/a|), the motive to all noble action. Cf. iii.5.3.
w(s: uncommon after oi)=mai, o(/ti being the usual conjunction. Cf. Hell. vi. 3. 12.
tou/tw|: anticipative, referring to o(/plwn te kai\ i(/ppwn paraskeuh=| ktl. See G. 1005; H. 696 a.
diene/gkoien: sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi.
o)/knei: delay.
w)felh/sh|: fut. mid. for passive. Cf. ii.7.8.
a)lla\ nh\ *di/a: see on ii.7.11.

div2.p: Nicomachides complains that in the election of generals the Athenians have ignored him, an experienced officer, and have chosen a man who has no knowledge of war. But Socrates urges that a man who can successfully equip and train a chorus, and especially a man who can successfully manage his own house, must possess qualities which will render him a useful general; for the demands on ability are essentially the same in all these positions.

div3.p: strathgoi/: predicate.
ou) ga\r toiou=toi/ ei)sin *)aqhnai=oi: “now is not that just like the Athenians?”

e)k katalo/gou strateuo/menos: “in serving the State as a private soldier on the list.” The kata/logos was the roll which contained the name of every Athenian capable of bearing arms. It will be noticed that Nicomachides bases his claim to be chosen general simply on his long service as private, captain, and colonel.
katate/trimmai: I have worn myself out. Cf. the Lat. detritus.
loxagw=n, taciarxw=n: circumstantial participles with katate/trimmai.
u(po/: takes the gen. of agent, as trau/mata e)/xw is equivalent to tetrauma/tismai.
a(/ma ... e)pedei/knuen: cf. nudasse deinde se dicitur et quo quaeque bello vulnera accepta essent, retulisse Livy xlv. 39.
*)antisqe/nhn: like Nicomachides, unknown.
e)n i(ppeu=sin: the i(ppei=s or knights were the second of the four property classes established by Solon. See Schömann, Antiq. of Greece, p. 329.
peri/blepton: cf. the Lat. respectabilis.
te/: correlative with ou)/te, as in i. 2. 47.
ou)/koun: as in i. 4. 5.
e)/mporoi: traders, i.e. importers, not retailers.
o(/: a quality which, refers to filo/nikos. Cf. 5. 3.

kexorh/ghke: it was the duty of the xorhgo/s to equip and train a chorus to represent his tribe (fulh/) at public festivals. This was one of the regular public services (leitourgi/ai) imposed on wealthy citizens. See on ii. 7. 6.
ma\ *di/a: see on i.4.9.

te\ kai/: the Eng. idiom uses a simple and. Cf. iii. 7. 4; iv. 4. 12. So Cicero (Tusc. Disp. v. 3. 9) similem sibi videri vitam hominum et mercatum eum qui haberetur maximo ludorum apparatu totius Graeciae celebritate.
kai\ mh/n: see on i.4.12.
w)|dh=s: song, i.e. music in general.
e)ge/neto i(kano/s: proved himself competent.
tou\s krati/stous tau=ta: those who were most skilled in these matters, sc. w)|dh/n and didaskali/an.
kai/, ou)=n: and so, also.
a)/llous me/n, tou\s ta/contas: some who will draw up (the troops).
e)a/n ge: provided that.
e)a\n e)ceuri/skh|, a)\n nikhfo/ros ei)/h: for the form of cond. sent., see on ii.5.4.
tou/tou: instead of the preceding toi=s polemikoi=s, a generic word of similar meaning is to be supplied as the antec. of the demonstrative. So in ii. 2. 4.
kai/, de/: see on i.1.3.
su\n th=| fulh=|: see on 3. Attica was then divided into ten tribes, named after legendary national heroes.
tou= au)tou= a)ndro/s e)sti: it is in the nature of the same man. For the pred. gen. of characteristic, see on tw=n a)skou/ntwn i. 2. 10.
e)a\n gignw/skh|, a)gaqo\s a)\n ei)/h: see on 5.
ou)k a)\n w)/|mhn: for the potential indic., see GMT. 243, 244. Cf. qa=tton h)\ ws tis a)\n w)/|eto An. i.5.8
a)kou=sai: since w)/|mhn is here a verb of expecting, the inf. is not in indirect discourse. For its tense, see G. 1286; H. 948 a.
tou\s a)rxome/nous: their subordinates.
e(/kasta: every duty.
pra/ttein: for the inf. of purpose, see on paideu=sai i. 5. 2.
oi)=mai: affirmative, instead of the usual Socratic question.
prosa/gesqai: to attach to themselves.
fulaktikou\s tw=n o)/ntwn: watchful of their property. Cf. iii. 1. 6.

a)mfote/rous ei)=nai prosh/kei: the impers. prosh/kei here takes the
acc. and inf., in 8 the dative. For a similar use of the two consts. near each other, cf. prosh/kei de\ toi=s me\n a)/llois ste/rgein, se\ de\ nomi/zein Isoc. v. 127.
ou)ke/ti: no longer, i.e. the comparison cannot hold, when fighting is in question. For a similar use of ou)ke/ti, cf. An. i. 10. 12.
e)xqroi/ ge/ toi: enemies surely, at any rate.
tou=to/ ge: sc. a)lhqe/s e)stin.
h( oi)konomikh/ (sc. te/xnh) the art of domestic management.
e)ntau=qa: in that case.
plei=ston (sc. w)felh/sei): will be of the greatest service.
w(s: as, in a comparison.
maxo/menon: acc. sing. masc., agreeing with omitted subj. of nika=n.
ou)d) ou(/tws: sc. ti\ from the preceding ou)de/n.

ou)x h(/kista de\ tou/twn: “and what is of most importance among all these,” i.e. “when he has made preparations for victory and is resolved on battle under favorable conditions, he will yet” etc. For the ‘litotes,’ cf. i.2.23.
fula/cetai suna/ptein: for the inf., see on proie/nai ii. 6. 23.
to\ de\ me/giston: the fact of greatest significance. For neuter words in apposition with a sent., see H. 626 b.

ou)dete/ra: neither sphere of action. The whole section shows that Socrates regarded a wellmanaged household as differing only in degree from a well-managed state.
Xenophon elaborated his own views on household management (putting them into the mouth of Socrates) in a special treatise, the Oeconomicus.

div2.p: Socrates sets before the younger Pericles the best way to recall the Athenians to their pristine courage and energy. The successive reverses which the Athenians have suffered at the hands of the Thebans have demoralized their public spirit and obscured the undoubted fact of their natural superiority. Delium and Lebadēa (Coronēa) were severe lessons, but should be made profitable. The citizens should, above all, be reminded of the lofty fame of their ancestors; and if that is not enough, they should be urged to imitate the steady and effective discipline of the Lacedaemonians. Then, too, their generals should be chosen with greater care than at present. Finally, Socrates expresses the hope that Pericles, who has been elected as one of the generals, has qualified himself for the position; and suggests that it would be well to employ the younger citizen soldiery in an effective defense of the Attic frontier.

div3.p: *periklei=: third son of the great Pericles. His mother was of foreign birth, the beautiful and accomplished Aspasia of Miletus, and he was consequently not entitled to Athenian citizenship; but after the death of his two brothers he was legitimated by the Athenians and accepted as a citizen, for his father's sake. He was one of the six generals who were executed for their failure to rescue the shipwrecked crews after the battle of the Arginusae. See on i. 1. 18, and cf. Plutarch Pericles 37.
tou= pa/nu *perikle/ous: the celebrated Pericles. So oi( pa/nu tw=n stratiwtw=n Thuc. viii. 1. 1.
strathgh/santos: see on bouleu/sas i. 1. 18.

bou/lei, e)piskopw=men:
as in ii. 1. 1.
o(/pou h)/dh to\ dunato/n e)sti: wherein now the possibility lies.

ou)kou=n: see on ii.1.2.—o(/ti plh/qei ktl.: the population of Attica (including slaves) was prob. not more than half a million; that of the Boeotian confederacy considerably less. As every free citizen of Attica was a citizen of Athens, the comparison of *)aqhnai=oi with *boiwtw=n is a proper one. Athens and Attica were politically identical; not so Thebes and Boeotia.
sw/mata a)gaqa\ kai\ kala/: “sturdy, fine-looking men.”
a)\n e)klexqh=nai: could be picked out. For the inf. with a)/n, see G. 1308; H. 964. The 2 aor. pass. -legh=nai is more common in Attic.
tau/th|: in this respect. For the dat., see G. 1182; H. 780.
dokou=si lei/pesqai: sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi tw=n *boiwtw=n.
e(autoi=s: inter se among themselves. Cf. fqonou=sin e(autoi=s 16, and see on ii.6.20.
*)aqh/nhsi: for the locative, see G. 296; H. 220.
ei)si/n: sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi.
a(/per: cf. o(/ 4. 3.
e)/stin oi(=s: see on i.4.2. Cf. kai\ mh\n e)pi/ ge toi=s progo/nois ou) mei=on *)aqhnai=oi h)\ *boiwtoi\ fronou=sin (pride themselves) Hipp. vii. 3, where the claim is more modest.
protre/pontai/ te: for the position of the encl., cf. a(/ te e)no/mizen iv. 2. 40.
a)lhqh=: for the pred. adj., see G. 919; H. 614.

a)f' ou(=: i.e.
a)po\ tou= xro/nou, e)n w(=|.

e)n *lebadei/a|: by the victory of Oenoph&ybreve;ta (456 B.C.), the Athenians gained complete ascendency over the Boeotian towns, and established in them democratic forms of government. Many of the banished oligarchs banded together, raised an army, and, in 447 B.C., inflicted an overwhelming defeat on the Athenian army under Tolmides, who lost his life in the battle. The conflict took place between Lebadēa and Coronēa in Boeotia, and is usually known as the battle of Coronēa. Cf. Thuc. i. 108, 113, and see Grote, Hist. of Greece, c. xlv.

e)pi\ *dhli/w|: not e)n *dhli/w|, as at that time (424 B.C.) Delium was only an enclosure and temple sacred to Apollo, near Orōpus on the Boeotian frontier. Cf. Plato Apol. 28E. In this battle the Athenian general was defeated and slain. Socrates is said to have shown great gallantry in the retreat which ensued. See Introd. 2, 61.
e)k tou/twn: since these events, repeats a)f) ou(=.
pro\s tou\s *boiwtou/s: see on pro\s e(auto/n i. 2. 52.
e)n th=| e(autw=n: sc. xw/ra|.
oi( tolmw=ntes: rel., who ventured. The participle is ‘imperfect.’ See G. 1289; H. 856 a. So porqou=ntes below.
eu)arestote/rws diakei=sqai: “is more favorably disposed.”
qa/rsos: over-confidence.
e)mba/llei: begets.
tw=n e)n tai=s nausi/n: i.e. tw=n nautw=n.

e)/st) a)/n: quamdiu. For
temporal clauses with a)/n and the subjv., see G. 1465; H. 923.
karadokou=ntes: eagerly expecting, lit. with outstretched head, an Ionic expression. Cf. *pa/rioi de\ u(poleifqe/ntes e)n *ku/qnw|, e)karado/keon to\n po/lemon kh= a)pobh/setai Hdt. viii. 67.
w(/sper xoreutai/: like members of a chorus, who keep their eyes on the leader during the whole performance.
w(/ra: the proper time. For the inf. with substs., see G. 1521; H. 952.
a)nerasqh=nai: to yearn anew for.
ou)kou=n: well, then.
ei) e)boulo/meqa: see on ei) prosete/qhsan i. 4. 5.
ei)=xon: see on a(\ e)bou/leto i. 4. 14.
e)cormw=|men: for the potential opt. in apod. after the ind. in prot., see on a)\n ei)/h i. 2. 45.
tou= met' a)reth=s prwteu/ein: “preëminence in valor.”
tou=to: sc. to\ met) a)reth=s prwteu/ein.
deikte/on: impers. const.; it takes as objs. both tou=to ... au)toi=s and w(s ... kra/tistoi.

oi)=mai me/n: as in ii. 6. 5.—ei) tou/s ge palaiota/tous ktl.: the Eng. order of thought seems to be ei) a)namimnh/|skoimen au)tou\s a)khkoo/tas tou/s ge palaiota/tous w(=n (equivalent to tou/twn, ou(/s) a)kou/omen progo/nous au)tw=n a)ri/stous gegone/nai. “We have only to remind them of the fact, which they have heard often enough (at school and elsewhere), that their ancestors, as far back as we have any record, were men of highest valor.” The omitted apod. is, of course, dida/skoimen a)/n, to be const. (with w(s or o(/ti) as obj. of oi)=mai.

th\n tw=n qew=n kri/sin: the decision between the deities. qew=n is objective genitive. The reference is to the contest between Athena and Poseidon for the sovereignty of Attica, which was decided by Cecrops, legendary king of Athens. Cf. Apollodorus iii. 14. The legend formed the subject of the sculptures in the west pediment of the Parthenon.
oi( peri\ *ke/kropa: seems to indicate Cecrops himself and the tribunal over which he presided. Cf. tou\s a)mfi\ *qra/sullon i. 1. 18.
*)erexqe/ws: another legendary hero and king of Attica, who shared with Athena the honor of a temple (the Erechtheum) on the Acropolis.

trofh\n kai\ ge/nesin: for the ‘hysteron proteron,’ by which the more important or obvious action is mentioned before another which preceded it in order of time, cf. a(/ma tra/fen h)de\ ge/nonto Hom. A 251, ‘For I was bred and born | not three hours' travel from this very place.’ Shak. Twelfth Night i. 2, and moriamur, et in media arma ruamus, Virgil Aen. ii. 353.
e)p' e)kei/nou: in his reign.
pro\s tou\s ... pa/shs: in very early times the Thracians were said to have occupied the country as far as the borders of Attica, and to have been repulsed from Athens by Erechtheus.
to\n e)f' *(hrakleidw=n: the sons of Heracles sought and obtained aid from Athens against Eurystheus.
tou\s e)pi\ *qhse/ws polemhqe/ntas (sc. pole/mous): i.e. the wars against the Amazons and Thracians. For these legendary events, cf. Isoc. iv. 65, 68; Hdt. ix. 27; Thuc. ii. 15.
tw=n kaq' e(autou/s: the men of their day. Cf. the eulogy on Athenian achievements in Plato Menex. 239 B ff.
ei) de\ bou/lei: polite formula, marks a transition to another phase of the subject.

au)toi\ kaq' au(tou/s: contrasted with kai\ meta\ *peloponnhsi/wn below. The battle of Marathon (490 B.C.) is meant. Although the Athenians had on that occasion the assistance of 1,000 Plataeans, the phrase au)toi\ ktl. may pass, as a rhetorical exaggeration.— tou\s kurieu/ontas ktl.: i.e. the Persians. See Grote, Hist. of Greece,
cc. xxxii-xxxiv.
plei/sthn tw=n progegono/twn: equivalent to plei/ona th=s tw=n progegono/twn. See on kaino/teron tw=n a)/llwn i. 1. 3.
me/gista e)/rga: i.e. the achievements of Cyrus and Darius in establishing the Persian empire.
oi(\ dh\ kai/: who also, we see, refers to oi( e)kei/nwn a)po/gonoi, and hence does not include the Peloponnesians, whom the argument does not touch.
le/gontai ga/r: they are indeed. Cf. oi)=da ga/r 2.
pollw=n metanasta/sewn: e.g., those which followed the inroads of the Dorians.

die/meinan: held their ground. The Attic Greeks were proud of being au)to/xqones and ghgenei=s. Cf. tau/thn (th\n po/lin) ga\r oi)kou=men ou)x e(te/rous e)kbalo/ntes (by dispossessing) ou)de\ e)rh/mhn katalabo/ntes ou)de\ e)k pollw=n e)qnw=n miga/des sullege/ntes (as mingled immigrants) a)ll' ou(/tw kalw=s kai\ gnhsi/ws gego/namen, w(/ste e)c h(=sper (gh=s) e)/fumen, tau/thn e)/xontes a(/panta to\n xro/non diatelou=men, au)to/xqones o)/ntes Isoc. iv. 24. Cf. also Thuc. i. 2.
e)pe/trepon: entrusted their cause (ta\ di/kaia).
kai\ qauma/zw ge: yes, and I marvel.
e)gw\ me/n, e)/fh, oi)=mai, o( *swkra/ths: for a similar order of words, cf. kai\ ti/ de/, e)/fh, o(ra=|s, h( gunh/ Oec. vii. 16, quid igitur, inquit, est causae, Brutus Cic. Brut. 91.
w(/sper kai/, ou(/tw kai/: see on i.1.6. On the comparison with athletes, cf. i.2.24.
tw=n a)ntipa/lwn: for the gen. with verbs of comparison, see G. 1120; H. 749. Cf. o(rw=n u(steri/zousan th\n po/lin tw=n kairw=n seeing the city falling behind its opportunities Dem. xviii. 102.
ou)de\n a)po/krufon: no secret.

a)\n xei/rous gene/sqai: depends on dokei= moi understood after a)lla/, or dokou=sin may be supplied, making the const. personal. For an example of both consts. in the same sent., cf. e)/docen au)tw=| bronth=s genome/nhs skhpto\s pesei=n ei)s th\n patrw/|an oi)ki/an, kai\ e)k tou/tou la/mpesqai pa=san An. iii.1.11 See G. 1522, 2; H. 944 a.
ei) de\ mh/: and if not (that).
tou\s prwteu/ontas: i.e. the Lacedaemonians. Xenophon never omits an opportunity to praise Spartan institutions.
tou/tois ta\ au)ta/: the same things that they do. For the abridged comparison, see on tw=n a)/llwn i. 1. 3.
ei) d' e)pimele/steron: sc. xrw=|nto.
kai/: even.

“You are then, I take it, of the opinion that the Athenians have fallen far away from their pristine virtue, and you wish them to take for their model the Lacedaemonians, who certainly could give them many a good lesson.”
pou/: see on iii.3.2.
w(/sper *lakedaimo/nioi: cf. De Rep. Lac. X. 2, and Cic. de Sen. xviii. 63, where Lysander boasts Lacedaemona esse honestissimum domicilium senectutis.
oi(/: so o(/s i. 2. 64.—a)po\ tw=n pate/rwn ktl.: starting with their fathers, look down on.

e(autoi=s: const. with ta\ sumfe/ronta. This and the two other refl. prons. (e(autoi=s, au(tou/s) in this section are equivalent to the reciprocal.
Cf. 2.

a)llh/lois dika/zontai: the verb, as indicating strife, takes the dat., like fqonou=sin above. The fondness of the Athenians for litigation is evidenced by their numerous courts, and the large body of their extant forensic literature. Aristophanes lashed this love of lawsuits in his Wasps.
sunwfelou=ntes: for the circumstantial participle of means, see on i.1.9.
au)=: item, with reference to diafe/rontai and dika/zontai.
tai=s ... xai/rousin: “they delight especially in having their faculties trained for such strife.”

e)c w(=n: i.e. because they neglect physical training and despise discipline; hence arise a)thri/a and kaki/a, while e)/xqra and mi=sos are an immediate result of the continual strife with one another.
h)\ w(/ste: see on i.4.10.
ponhri/a| nosei=n: a common metaphor with the Greeks, as with us. Cf. ta\ *)odrusw=n pra/gmata e)no/shsen An. vii.2.32 For the causal dative, see G. 1181; H. 776.
toi=s e)pista/tais: i.e. the trainers.
ou)de/nwn katadee/steron: in a manner unsurpassed by any. Cf. i. 5. 6.
tou=to ga/r toi kai\ qaumasto/n e)sti: that is just what is so strange. tou=to serves as energetic introduction to to\ peiqa/rxein, ei)=nai. Cf. ii.4.1.

toiou/tous: i.e. sailors, gymnasts, dancers, etc., who were
generally of the lower classes; while hoplites and cavalry were composed of the free and well-to-do citizens.
kaloka)gaqi/a|: dat. of respect.

h( de\ e)n *)arei/w| pa/gw| boulh/: this ancient court derived its name from the sacred hill of Ares (west of the Acropolis, and separated from it only by a narrow and shallow valley), where its sittings were held. It was composed of ex-archons who had ‘clean records,’ as established by the dokimasi/a (official investigation); and it had jurisdiction over cases of intentional homicide, poisoning, and arson. See Schömann, Antiq. of Greece, passim.
ou) me/mfomai: I have no fault to find.
tou/tois: i.e. toi=s *)areiopagi/tais. For another example of ‘synesis,’ cf. oi(\ ne/oi after qia/sou ii. 1. 31. See H. 633.
w(s, o)/ntwn: see on i.1.4.
kai\ mh/n: and yet. See on i. 4. 12.
tou/twn: i.e. swfronei=n, eu)taktei=n, peiqarxei=n.
prose/xousin: they give heed to.
e)n tou/tois: i.e. toi=s stratiwtikoi=s.
ou)de\ ei(=s: see on i.6.2.
e)/xousi: are able.
au)tosxedia/zousin: “hold command without preparation.” Cf. the conversation with Euthydemus in iv. 2, where Socrates scores the presumption of would-be impromptu statesmen.
ou)de\n h(=tton: connect with h)/ after strathgei=n.
tw=n patrw/|wn strathghma/twn: your father's principles of generalship.
polla\ merimna=n: see on i.1.11.
la/qh|s seauto\n a)gnow=n: see on i.2.34.
mh\ ei)do/ta: instead of ou)k ei)do/ta, because of the force of the preceding e)a/n, making the participle part of the condition. G. 1614; H. 1027.
ou) lanqa/neis me, o(/ti: you do not elude me, “I fully understand that,” with pers. for impers. construction. Cf. o(/ti ponhro/tatoi/ ge/ ei)sin, ou)de\ se\ lanqa/nousin Oec. i. 19.
ou)d' oi)o/menos: in 22 and 23, Socrates used the word oi)=mai. Pericles perceives the underlying irony, and says, “You do not even believe it (to say nothing of knowing it).”
o)/rh: Cithaeron and others.
me/sh: sc. h( xw=ra.
o)/resin e)rumnoi=s: Parnes, Pentelicus, and Hymettus.

*musoi\ kai\ *pisi/dai: cf. oi)=da ga\r u(mi=n *musou\s luphrou\s (troublesome) o)/ntas, oi)=da de\ kai\ *pisi/das An. ii.5.13 Cyrus the Younger made a defensive campaign against the Pisidians the pretext for mustering one of his armies.

basile/ws,
without the art., the Great King, the king of Persia; so freq. in the Anabasis.
pa/nu: follows its adj. for emphasis.
w(plisme/noi: circumstantial participle of cause, rather than of concession.
polla/ (sc. kaka/): cognate acc. with kakopoiei=n. For the double acc., see on th\n po/lin i. 2. 12.

me/xri th=s e)lafra=s h(liki/as: so long as they are of the active age, i.e. from 18 to 20. The Athenian youth of this age served in the army as peri/poloi, a kind of home guard, or constabulary force, to serve only in Attica.

w(plisme/nous, kate/xontas: equivalent to ei) w(plisme/noi ei)=en, ei) kate/xoien, serving as prots. to a)\n (before oi)/ei) ei)=nai, kateskeua/sqai. For the circumstantial participle of cond., see on pisteu/wn i. 1. 5.
probolh\n kateskeua/sqai: form a rampart.
o(/ ti me\n a)/n, e)a\n de/ ti: for a similar change of const., cf. i.7.5.

div2.p: Glauco, a brother of Plato, a youth of less than twenty years, is eager to take a leading part in public affairs. Socrates shows him that he is unacquainted with any of the details of government, and earnestly warns him against taking up, for public speech or action, matters on which he has not first informed himself thoroughly.

In this and the succeeding chapter, we have a pair of contrasted pictures: first, of the conceited stripling, whose zeal is without knowledge; and second, of the modest man of abilities, who withholds his valuable services from the state. Socrates performs a public duty in showing each of these men his mistake.

div3.p: *glau/kwna: a brother of Plato. The Glauco mentioned just below was the father of Perictione, Aristo's wife, and of Charmides, uncle of Plato and Glauco.

ou)de/pw ei)/kosin e)/th: at eighteen an Athenian youth attained the rights of citizenship, but from eighteen to twenty military service claimed most of his time. To some offices, like the senatorship and the judgeship (cf. i.1.1), he was not eligible before the age of thirty.

e(lko/menon a)po\ tou= bh/matos: unpopular or intolerable speakers were occasionally hooted from the bema, or led away by the police (toco/tai). Cf. Aristophanes Knights 665; Acharnians 45 ff.; Plato Prot. 319 c. For the supplementary participle with pau=sai, see G. 1580; H. 981. Cf. tou\s barba/rous e)/pausen u(bri/zontas Isocrates xii. 83.
katage/laston o)/nta: being a laughing-stock.
*xarmi/dhn: see on iii.7.1.
*pla/twna: the only mention of Plato in Xenophon's writings. In the Republic, Plato gives a very different representation of his brother Glauco.
prw=ton me/n: corresponds to meta\ de\ tau=ta 3.
ei)s to\ e)qelh=sai a)kou/ein: “in order to make him willing to hear,” the purpose of le/cas. For ei)s with the articular inf., cf. ei)s to\ fobei=sqai An. vii.8.20
kate/sxen (sc. au)to/n): he checked him.
h(mi=n: ethical dative. G. 1171; H. 770.
ei)/per ti kai\ a)/llo (sc. e)sti/n): so in iv. 3. 14. Cf. also Cyr. iii. 3. 42.

e)n a)nqrw/pois: in the world. Cf. eu)= i)/sqi, pa/ntwn tw=n e)n a)nqrw/pois ka/lliston kai\ makariw/taton kth=ma
kekth/sh| Hiero xi. 15.
*qemistoklh=s: see on ii.6.13; iv. 2. 2.
peri/bleptos: ‘the observed of all observers.’
e)megalu/neto: was greatly elated.
w)felhte/a: for the pers. const. of the verbal in -te/os, see G. 1595; H. 989.

a)pokru/yh|: for the aor. subjv. in prohibitions, see G. 1346; H. 874. On the use of the mid., Kühner remarks, a)pokru/ptein ti refertur ad res extra nos positas (occulere aliquid); a)pokru/ptesqai contra ad id, quod in nobis est (celare aliquid).
ei)=pon: first aor. imv. active. See on ii. 2. 8.
diesiw/phsen: lapsed into silence.

w(s a)
 to/te skopw=n: sc. diasiwph/seie. to/te is equivalent to tum demum then for the first time. Cf. kai\ to
 *ku=ron e)pere/sqai propetw=s, w(s a)
 pai=s mhde/pw u(popth/sswn and Cyrus asked eagerly, as a child (would) who had not yet learned to be shy Cyr. i. 3. 8.
au)to/n: i.e. to\n oi)=kon.
peira/sh|: fut. indic. middle.
ou)kou=n: see on ii.1.2.
ei)ko/s: sc. e)sti/.
po/sai tine/s: see on i.1.1.
au)tw=n: depends on tine/s.
e)ndew=s e)/xousin: are insufficient.
paralei/pontai: are being neglected.
a)fairei=n: retrench.
e)sxo/lasa: found time.
a)nabalou/meqa: we will postpone.
mh\ ei)do/ta: see on pisteu/wn i. 1. 5.
sfo/dra: sc. plouti/zein.
kai\ ta\ o)/nta: even what he had, to say nothing of what he had hoped to win from the enemy.
h(/ttwn: sc. h( th=s po/lews du/namis th=s tw=n e)nanti/wn. For a similar instance of ‘brachylogy,’ cf. iii.5.4.
a)po\ sto/matos: by word of mouth, i.e. from memory. Cf. e)/xois a)\n dihgh/sasqai (repeat them); *ou) ma\ to\n *di/a ou)/koun ou(/tw ge a)po\ sto/matos Plato Theaet. 142 D.
ei) ge/graptai/ soi: if you have it written down.
th/n ge prw/thn (sc. w(/ran or o(do/n): for the present. For the omission of the noun, see G. 932, 2; H. 621 c; and, for the adv. acc., G. 1060; H. 719.

au)tw=n: i.e. tw=n
tou= pole/mou implied in pole/mou.
e)ch/takas: from e)ceta/zw.
oi)=d) o(/ti: a formula of assurance, here (as in 13) ironical.
o(po/sai fulakai\ e)pi/kairoi/ ei)si: how many outposts are advantageously placed.
frouroi/: garrisons.
a(pa/sas: sc. a)fairei=n sumbouleu/sw.
ta\ e)k th=s xw/ras: condensed form of ta\ e)n th=| xw/ra| e)c au)th=s. H. 788 a. Cf. a(rpaso/menoi ta\ e)k tw=n oi)kiw=n Cyr. vii. 2. 5.
a(rpa/zein: to rob openly, contrasted with kle/ptein to steal.
e)/fh: he continued.— e)lqw\n au)to\s ktl.: have you gone in person and investigated this?
ei)ka/zwmen, ei)dw=men: the use of the first pers. pl., and perhaps the assonance of the verbs, serve to heighten the playful irony of the passage.
be/ltion: sc. a)\n ei)/h.
ta)rgu/reia: the silver mines, at Laurium. See on ii. 5. 2.
ou) ga\r ou)=n: certainly not. For ou)=n adding emphasis to an affirmative, see on iii.3.2.
kai\ ga/r: and with good reason, for.
le/getai baru\ to\ xwri/on ei)=nai: the district is said to be unhealthy.
au(/th soi h( pro/fasis a)rke/sei: this will serve you as an excuse.

skw/ptomai: you are mocking me. Cf. oi)/moi gelw=mai Soph. Ant.
832, u(brizo/meqa Aristophanes Peace 1264. Glauco is as earnest as he is foolish, and Socrates now adopts a more serious tone.
prosdei=tai (sc. h( po/lis): requires in addition, i.e. by importation.
i(/na mh\ tou=to/ ge ... genome/nh: “in order that the city may never run short of grain through your oversight.”
ei)dw\s e)/xh|s sumbouleu/wn: you may be able, by giving advice based on knowledge.
pamme/geqes pra=gma: an enormous task.
ou)d' a)\n oi)kh/seien, ei) mh\ ei)/setai: for the ‘mixed form’ of cond. sent., see on i.2.45.
muri/wn: a similar approximate estimate of the number of houses in Athens is given by Ischomachus, Oec. viii. 22.
oi)kiw=n, oi)/kwn, houses, households.
tou= qei/ou: mother'sbrother, uncle. Charmides is meant. The Greek was much more exact in terms of relationship than the English.
dei=tai de/: for the use of de/ where the Eng. would employ a conj. of cause or reason, cf. h)=rxon de/ An. vi.6.9 It is freq. in Homer, cf. bi/hfi de\ fe/rteroi h)=san z 6.
e(\n ta/lanton: about 57 lbs. For Greek weights, see Gow, Companion to School Classics, p. 88.
meta\ tou= qei/ou: uncle and all.
dunh/sesqai poih=sai pei/qesqai: an accumulation of infs. contrasting awkwardly with Xenophon's usual well-balanced arrangement.
o(/pws mh\ e)/lqh|s: for obj. clauses after fula/ttomai, see GMT. 370; H. 885 b.
a(\ mh\ oi)=de/ tis: for the rel. cond. assumed as real, see G. 1430; H. 914 A.

e)nqumou= de\ tw=n a)/llwn: const. with po/tera/ soi dokou=sin. See on au)tw=n e)sko/pei, po/tera i. 1. 12. Socrates says tw=n a)/llwn, reckoning Glauco among those who would seem to know what they do not know.

e)nqumou=, kai\ eu(rh/seis: see on e)gxei/rei, kai\ u(pakou/setai ii. 3. 16. The obj. of eu(rh/seis (the fact that everywhere the well-informed are respected, and the ignorant are despised) is felt also, as obj., with e)nqumou=.
e)k, o)/ntas: consist of.
tw=n a)/llwn: i.e. your fellowcitizens.
ou)k a)\n qauma/saimi: apod. to ei) tu/xois.
ei) tu/xois: a true fut. cond. of the ‘less vivid’ form, not (as freq. after qauma/zw) causal.

div2.p: Charmides, a man who is thoroughly acquainted with public affairs, but has yet, by reason of excessive modesty, never ventured to speak in public, is urged by Socrates no longer to withhold his services from the state. As he has not hesitated in private to give advice which was accepted by the most experienced statesmen, he will be able to speak in the presence of the less intelligent multitude in a manner which will redound to his own credit and the welfare of the commonwealth.

div3.p: *xarmi/dhn: brother-in-law of Aristo, who had married his sister Perictione, and hence uncle of Plato and the younger Glauco. (See on iii. 6. 1.) His kinsman and guardian Critias had introduced him to Socrates after the siege of Potidaea (432 B.C.); cf. Plato Charm. 154. Together with Critias he fought on the side of the oligarchy, and fell in the fight at the Piraeus (403 B.C.). Cf. Hell. ii. 4. 19.
dunatw/teron: sc. pra/ttein ta\ politika/.
prosie/nai tw=| dh/mw|: to come forward as speaker in the popular assembly.

tou\s stefani/tas a)gw=nas nika=n: for the acc. with nika=n, see on ii.6.26. The a)gw=nes were of two kinds, xrhmati=tai and stefani=tai, the former offering a prize of money value, the latter (and more distinguished) the coveted wreath of olive, bay, or parsley.
poi=o/n tina: see on toia/de tis i. 1. 1.
dh=lon o(/ti: was generally regarded as one word, hence the position of e)/fh after o(/ti, as in iv. 2. 14, 4. 23. Cf. iv.2.39.
e)pimelo/menos: by giving attention, modifies au)/cein.
o)knoi/h dh/: should then hesitate. dh/ glances back to the words dunato\s w)\n ktl.

kai\ tau=ta: and that too, sc. tou/twn
e)pimelei=sqai. G. 1573; H. 612 a.
poli/th| ge o)/nti: as a citizen.
tau=ta/ mou katagignw/skeis: do you pass this criticism on me. Cf. i. 3. 10.
ai(=s: equivalent to e)n ai(=s. See on ii. 1. 32.
a)nakoinw=ntai/ soi: consult with you. So Xenophon (An. iii.1.5) referred (a)nakoinou=tai) the invitation of Proxenus to Socrates, for his advice.
o)rqw=s e)pitimw=nta: rightly assigning the blame.
te/, kai/: as in iii. 4. 3.
kata\ mo/nas (sc. moi/ras or duna/meis): “by themselves.” Cf. au)toi\ kata\ mo/nas a)pewsa/meqa *korinqi/ous we by ourselves repulsed the Corinthians Thuc. i. 32.
kratisteu/ousi: excel. For a different meaning, cf. i.4.14; ii. 6. 26.

e)n toi=s o)/xlois: i.e. in public meetings, but with a depreciatory added meaning. Cf. e)n dikasthri/ois te kai\ a)/llois o)/xlois Plato Gorg. 454 E. —kai\ se/ ge dida/cwn ktl.: Charmides has just said that bashfulness in speaking before a public audience has a rational ground in the nature of man. Socrates retorts, “Not so; for you, who do not hesitate to speak before the most intelligent individuals, yet shrink from addressing the unintelligent populace,”—which is not nature, but perversity.
dida/cwn w(/rmhmai: I desire to show, lit. I have set out with the intention of showing. For the fut. participle of intention, see G. 1563, 4; H. 969 c.
ai)sxu/nh| le/gein: see on iii.1.11.

tou\s metaballome/nous (sc. ta\ w)/nia): shopkeepers, opposed to e)mpo/rous merchants (i.e. importers). See on e)/mporoi iii. 4. 2. Cf. the distinction made in England (but not in America) between ‘tradesmen’ and ‘merchants.’ For this and the other accs. with ai)sxu/nh|, see G. 1049; H. 712.

ti/ de\ oi)/ei diafe/rein ktl.: and how do you suppose your behavior is any wiser than that of the athlete who, when proved superior to trained opponents, yet fears the untrained? Cf. a)skhtai\ o)/ntes tw=n kalw=n ka)gaqw=n e)/rgwn i)/wmen e)pi\ tou\s polemi/ous, i)diw/tas o)/ntas Cyr. i. 5. 11. The Olympic victors are contrasted with i)diw=tai in iii. 12. 1.
e)n th=| po/lei: “in public life.”
fronti/sasi, mhde\ katefronhko/si: note the difference between the aor. and the pf. participle, men who never gave a thought, and have conceived no contempt for you.
oi( e(/teroi: the others, sc. in private circles, mentioned in 3.
qauma/zw sou ei): see on e)qau/maze ei) i. 1. 13.
e)kei/nous: refers to oi( e(/teroi, nearest mentioned, but farther from the speaker's thought.
tou/tois: i.e. the people in the public assembly.
prosenexqh=nai: “to face.”

mh\ a)gno/ei seauto/n: do not underestimate your own powers. Cf. cessator esse noli (mh\ a)porra|qu/mei) et illud gnw=qi seauto/n noli putare ad arrogantiam minuendam solum esse dictum, verum etiam, ut bona nostra norimus Cic. Ep. ad Quint. iii. 6.
tou/tou: gen. of separation with a)porra|qu/mei.
w)felh/sh|: middle as passive, as in i. 6. 14; iii. 3. 15.

div2.p: ‘Good’ and ‘beautiful’ are relative terms. The same thing can be good or bad, beautiful or ugly, according as it answers its purpose. Houses, temples, and altars are most beautiful when they best serve the end for which they were constructed.

div3.p: *)aristi/ppou: see on i.2.60, and ii. 1. 1.

h)le/gxeto: the impf. may mean that Xenophon here had in mind other conversations than the one recorded in ii. 1.—ou)x w(/sper ktl.: not like those who are on their guard lest their words be perverted.

w(s a)\n pepeisme/noi (sc. a)pokri/nainto) ktl.: as they would answer if persuaded that they are above all things doing what is right. Cf. o( ta\ de/onta pra/ttwn ou) swfronei=; Plato Charm. 164 B. Socrates's method of discussion, which aimed at the discovery of truth, is contrasted with the ways of the Sophists, who were chiefly concerned with wresting the victory from an opponent by rhetorical artifice.

deiknu/oi dh/: for dh/, see on iii.7.2.—e)a/n ti e)noxlh=| h(ma=s ktl.: Socrates, knowing well that if anything annoys us, we seek the remedy, felt that the word a)gaqo/n could best be explained as a relative term by applying it to special cases, as, e.g., ‘good for a fever,’ ‘good
for hunger,’ etc. It should be remembered that the Platonic Socrates held a very different view. Cf. Plato Alc. I, 116 A ff. See Introd. § 20 ff.
tou= pau/sontos (sc. to\ e)noxlou=n): something to check it.
poiei=n: i.e. a)pokri/nesqai. Like facere in Lat. and ‘do’ in Eng., poiei=n is often made to do duty for another verb, to avoid repetition.
kra/tiston: sc. h)=n.
e)rwta=|s: do you mean to ask.
puretou=: for a fever, obj. genitive.
a)lla\ mh/n: at vero, introduces the conclusive statement.
de/omai: sc. ei)de/nai.
kai\ polla/: aye, many things. w(s oi(=o/n te (sc. e)sti/) a)nomoio/tata: as unlike as it is possible to be.
w(s e)/ni (equivalent to e)/nesti): like w(s oi(=o/n te above.
e)/sti: for the accent, see G. 144, 5; H. 480. For the thought of the passage, cf. iv.6.9.
h)\ o(/te: than (you did) when.
pro\s tau)ta/: with reference to the same objects.

to\ au)to/: in the same
way.—pro\s a(/per ktl.: added in explanation of pro\s tau)ta/, “with reference to their usefulness.”
kai/, ge: and even.
ta\ e(autw=n e)/rga: “their respective uses.”
ta\ au)ta/: subj., with kala/ and ai)sxra/ for preds. in this sent., and a)gaqa/ and kaka/ in the next.
limou=, puretou=: as in 3. Food is good for hunger, but we must ‘starve a fever.’
to\ pro\s dro/mon kalo/n: what is admirable for running.
eu)= e)/xh|: are well adapted.
paideu/ein: to be giving us a lesson.
oi(/as xrh\ oi)kodomei=sqai: obj. of paideu/ein, what kind of houses we ought to build.
tou=to: see on ii.4.1.
h(di/sth e)ndiaita=sqai: for the inf. act. or mid. with adjs., see GMT. 763; H. 952, and a.

e)peidh\ sumfai=en: see on e)pei\ diomologh/saito i. 2. 57. The subj. is the persons who on each occasion were conversing with Socrates. This sent. shows, too, that tou/tou o(mologoume/nou above is equivalent to
o(po/te o(mologoi=en (sc. oi( paro/ntes).

pro\s meshmbri/an blepou/sais: so we say ‘looking toward the south.’ Cf. Oec. ix. 4. The house should be built high and open toward the south, so that the slanting rays of the sun in winter may enter the portico (pasta/s) at the front of the open court in the center of the dwelling. Toward the north it should be low and protected against storms.
w(s sunelo/nti ei)pei=n: to sum it up in a word. For the dat., see G. 1172, 2; H. 771 b, and, for the abs. inf., G. 1534; H. 956.
au)to/s: the owner, in distinction from his property (ta\ o)/nta).
a)\n katafeu/goi: potential opt. in cond. rel. clause. See GMT. 557.

grafai\ kai\ poikili/ai: paintings and walldecorations. It is not clear whether Socrates objects to these because so much money is ‘locked up’ in them, or on the ground that they ‘are more trouble than they are worth.’
naoi=s: instead of the ‘Attic’ form new/|s. So nao/n An. v.3.9
xw/ran: a situation.
e)mfanesta/th: most conspicuous, being on high ground.
ou)=sa: concessive.
a)stibesta/th: lit. most untrodden, ‘far from the madding crowd.’
i)do/ntas: sc. from a distance.
a(gnw=s e)/xontas prosie/nai: helps to explain a)stibesta/th, “to approach it unsullied” sc. by contact with the throng.

div2.p: Socrates discusses and defines the terms a)ndrei/a (courage), sofi/a (wisdom), fqo/nos (envy), sxolh/ (leisure), basileu/s and a)/rxwn (king and commander), eu)praci/a (good conduct), and eu)tuxi/a (good fortune). See Introd. §§ 20, 22.

div3.p: h( a)ndrei/a po/teron: for the same order, see ii. 7. 8. Cf. iv.6.10, 11, and i. 1. 16, where Xenophon speaks of Socrates as discussing just such themes as these in this chapter.
didakto\n h)\ fusiko/n: capable of being taught, or a gift of nature. For the gender, see on xrhsimw/teron ii. 3. 1.
oi)=mai me/n: corresponds to nomi/zw me/ntoi in 2. Cf. ii.1.12, and An. ii.1.13
i)sxuro/teron fu/etai: is by nature stronger.
ta\ deina/: as in i. 1. 14.
gi/gnesqai: grows.
maqh/sei kai\ mele/th|: cf. ii.6.39.
pro\s a)ndrei/an: as regards courage.

*sku/qai kai\ *qra=|kes: races often cited by Greek writers as examples of half-savage daring. “Yet even these, brave as they are, would scarce venture to fight with shield and spear against the veteran infantry of Lacedaemon.” Cf. the story of David in Saul's armor, 1 Sam. xvii. 39.
tolmh/seian: for the potential opt., see G. 1328; H. 872.
diama/xesqai: to fight it out.
ou)/t' a)/n, e)qe/loien a)/n: for the repetition of the particle, see on i.4.14.
pe/ltais: Thracian peltasts formed a considerable part of the army of Cyrus the Younger. Cf. An. i. 2. 9.
e)pi\ tw=n a)/llwn pa/ntwn o(moi/ws: similarly in all other matters.
e)pidido/ntas: intr., improving. Cf. Lat. proficere.
eu)fueste/rous: more highly endowed by nature.

sofi/an kai\ swfrosu/nhn: prudence and temperance. *sofi/a (wisdom or prudence) is right judgment about what ought to be done; swfrosu/nh is temperance, self-control or self-regulation, in acting. Cf. Socrates primus philosophiam devocavit a caelo et in urbibus collocavit et in domos etiam introduxit, et coëgit de vita et moribus rebusque bonis et malis quaerere Cic. Tusc. Disp. v. 4. 41.—a)lla\ tw=| ta\ me\n kala\ ktl.: “but by a man's knowing and practicing the higher virtues, and recognizing and avoiding baseness, he judged him to be both wise and virtuous.” tw=| xrh=sqai is dat. of instrument, and as inf. has for its subj. a)/nqrwpon understood, with which gignw/skonta agrees. The condensed form of expression in this sent. seems to emphasize the identity of ‘knowing’ and ‘doing.’
dikaiosu/nhn: it is difficult to find an Eng. equivalent; perhaps righteousness is nearest it.

e)a\n e)gxeirw=sin: direct discourse const. retained for vividness.—e)pei\ ou)=n ta/ te di/kaia ktl.: the logical form which this argument takes may be condensed as follows: “righteousness is included in wisdom. For, (a) upright and virtuously-wrought
actions are kala\ ka)gaqa/, (b) the wise and they alone choose ta\ kala\ ka)gaqa/. Hence the wise and they alone choose righteousness; so wisdom includes righteousness.” See Introd. § 19 ff.
dikaiosu/nh: for the omission of the art., see on i.2.23.
h( a)/llh a)reth/: reliqua virtus. Cf. Plato Prot. 323 A.

mani/an: in accordance with the definition of Socrates, madness (mani/a, insania) is logically opposed to wisdom (sofi/a, sapientia), and hence is ignorance of one's own strength and weakness; wisdom being distinguished by its knowledge of these. But people in general give the name of madness to the ignorance of other things. Cf. the vagaries of maino/menoi as described in i. 1. 14.
ge\ mh/n: as in iii. 8. 10.
oi)=de: the subj. (ti\s) is to be supplied from the subj. (tina/) of the infs. a)gnoei=n etc.
e)gguta/tw: for the adv. as pred., cf. i.6.10.
tou\s me/ntoi pollou/s: subj. of fa/skein and kalei=n.
a(\ ... a)gnoou=si: rel. clause preceding its grammatical antec. tou/twn.
me/gas: tall.
ou(/tws: placed with emphasis after me/gas. See on i. 2. 4.
a)/llw| tw| e)piqe/sqai: to attempt anything else.
