tw=n pa=si dh/lwn o(/ti a)du/nata/ e)sti: see on a)dh/lwn (o)/ntwn) i. 1. 6.
fa/skein: sc. tou\s pollou/s as subject.—w(/sper th\n ktl.: just as they call strong desire love, so they call great mental disorder madness.
fqo/non, o(/ ti ei)/h: for the ‘prolepsis,’ see on i.2.13. So sxolh/n, ti/ ei)/h in 9.
lu/phn tina/: a kind of pain.
ou)/te th\n e)p' e)xqrw=n eu)tuxi/ais gignome/nhn: for this feature of the Socratic ethics, see on ii.6.35.
ei)/ tis filw=n tina: that any one who really loved a friend. For ei) after verbs of wondering, cf. 7. 8.
bohqei=n: grammatically co-ord. with du/nasqai, but opposed in thought to periora=n.
a)tuxou=sin: “in their misfortune.”
froni/mw|: sensible.
pa/sxein au)to/: have this feeling. Cf., on this passage, Rochefoucauld's cynical maxim, that ‘there is something not wholly displeasing to us in the misfortunes of our best friends.’
ti/ ei)/h: for ti/ in indir. questions, see on i.1.1.

kai\ ga\r tou\s petteu/ontas: cf. i.2.57, where tou\s kubeu/ontas (dicers) is the term used for gamblers. The game of pettoi/ was something like our draughts and was played on a board of thirty-sixsquares.
gelwtopoiou=ntas: buffoons.

sxola/zein: were idlers. Idleness, thus, is a relative term; when we could be better employed than we are, we are idle.—e)cei=nai ga\r au)toi=s ktl.: for it was in their power to go and do better things than these.
ou)de/na sxola/zein: no one had leisure, in the better sense of the word.
a)sxoli/as au)tw=| ou)/shs: as he had no leisure (for such things).
kakw=s tou=to pra/ttein: acted badly in this respect.
u(po\ tw=n tuxo/ntwn: “by the multitude.” See on ta\ tuxo/nta i. 1. 14.
laxo/ntas: sc. to\ a)/rxein.
tou\s biasame/nous: those who have won it by violence.
o(mologh/seie: opt. in past general cond. rel. clause, like sumfai=en in iii. 8. 9. So ei)/ tis le/goi in 12.

to\n nau/klhron: the shipowner, here distinguished from tw=| e)pistame/nw|, i.e. the captain.—kai\ tou\s a)/llous pa/ntas ktl.: and so all others who have anything needing attention, if they think they know how to attend to it, (do so); otherwise, etc. The ellipsis after e)pi/stasqai e)pimelei=sqai may be filled with e)pimelome/nous, supplementary participle with e)pedei/knuen, which governs also the participles peiqome/nous and metapempome/nous.
dh/pou: opinor, credo.
a(marta/nwn: circumstantial participle of condition.
kai/: even.
h)\ w(s e)/tuxe zhmiou=sqai: “or gets off with a light punishment.”
a)\n ma=llon sw/|zesqai: would be more secure.
h)\ ... a)pole/sqai: or in this way, and speedily, would perish.
kra/tiston e)pith/deuma: the best pursuit.

eu)praci/an: good conduct. The questioner of Socrates understands eu)praci/a and eu) pra/ttein in their usual sense of success and succeed, synonymous with eu)tuxi/a and eu)tuxei=n (so used in 8); and naturally asks if Socrates considers this a pursuit.
to\ e)pituxei=n: sc. tina/ as subj., easily supplied from zhtou=nta.
eu)= poiei=n: to do well.
qeofilesta/tous: most beloved by the gods. Distinguish this compound from filo/qeos loving the gods.

div2.p:
The subject of the painter's art is whatever falls under his eye. He attains his ideal form by combining the best features of the actual, and can even represent mental characteristics, so far as these express themselves outwardly. In like manner, sculpture expresses not only the outward form of the body, but also the varying moods of the soul. The artisan, on the other hand, has only the actual and material to keep in mind: his work must fulfill its
design. Every coat of mail that fits, finds in that its true harmony.

div3.p: e)xo/ntwn: devoted to. See on e)/xh| i. 6. 13.
e)rgasi/as e(/neka: as a profession.
tini/, tou/tois: as in i. 2. 62.
ei)selqw\n me/n: corresponds to pro\s de\ *klei/twna ei)selqw/n in 6.

*parra/sion: a famous painter from Ephesus, who resided at Athens, and at this time was a young man, perhaps thirty years the junior of Zeuxis (i. 4. 3). Pliny says of him primus symmetriam picturae dedit, primus argutias vultus, elegantiam capilli, venustatem oris, confessione artificum in lineis extremis palmam adeptus Hist. Nat. xxxv. 10.
grafikh/: without the art., as swfrosu/nh i. 2. 23. The pred. ei)kasi/a, as containing the definition, takes the article.
e)kmimei=sqe: you reproduce to the life.
ta\ kala\ ei)/dh: beautiful figures.
a)fomoiou=ntes: circumstantial participle of time.
a)/mempta: faultless.
e)c e(ka/stou: in each. See on ta\ e)k th=s xw/ras iii. 6. 11.
o(/la: as a whole. For its predicate position, see G. 979; H. 672 c.
ti/ ga/r: see on ii.6.2.
poqeino/taton: most provocative of desire.
h)=qos: character.

w(=n su\
ei)=pas: i.e. in 1, ta\ koi=la etc.
o(/lws: “in a word.”
gi/gnetai e)n a)nqrw/pw| ktl.: “does it ever happen among men that friendship or hatred for any one is shown by a look?”
o(moi/ws e)/xein: equivalent to o(/moioi ei)=nai.
pro/swpa: acc. of specification.
oi( fronti/zontes: “those who sympathize.” Const. with e)pi\ toi=s a)gaqoi=s kai\ toi=s kakoi=s.
to\ megaloprepe\s ktl.: the adjs. are contrasted pair with pair.
sxhma/twn: bearing.
diafai/nei: (intr.) shows through.
h(/dion (sc. ei)=nai) o(ra=n: is pleasanter to contemplate.
tou\s a)nqrw/pous: obj. of o(ra=n. The answer of Parrhasius, though not direct, is perfectly natural, and leaves no doubt as to his full assent to the views of Socrates.
*klei/twna: not mentioned elsewhere.

a)lloi/ous: “of various appearances and postures.”—dromei=s ktl.: for the Greek athletic contests,
see Smith's Dict. Antiq. s.v. Ludus.
yuxagwgei=: allures.

to\ zwtiko\n fai/nesqai: the lifelike appearance. It is interesting to remember that Socrates himself was trained as a sculptor by his father Sophroniscus; and that a marble group of the Graces (ai( *xa/rites), said to have been executed by him, was seen by Pausanias near the entrance to the Acropolis. See Introd. § 1.
taxu/: immediately.
a)peika/zwn to\ e)/rgon: by assimilating the work (before you).
u(po\ tw=n sxhma/twn: in consequence of the (various) positions.
sumpiezo/mena: compressed.
piqanw/tera: “more impressive.”

ta\ pa/qh: the emotions. Obs. the gradual increase in the demands made upon the artist: first, the various classes are distinguished,— runners, wrestlers, etc.; then, the various sxh/mata in each class; and lastly, the various emotions expressed by these. Cf. the lines of Schiller which were on the wall of the old Gewandhaus in Leipzig: ‘Leben athmet die bildende Kunst, Geist fordr' ich vom Dichter, | Aber die Seele spricht nur Polyhymnia aus,’ where the lyric Muse alone is allowed to express the soul's deepest emotions.
ta\ o)/mmata a)peikaste/on, h( o)/yis mimhte/a: obs. the use of both the pers. and impers. constructions.
a)peilhtika/: pred. adj., with menacing glance.

eu)frainome/nwn: joined with tw=n nenikhko/twn instead of with o)/yis (as a)peilhtika/ with o)/mmata) because eu)frai/nesqai is more appropriately attributed to the person
than to th=| o)/yei.
ta\ th=s yuxh=s e)/rga: the workings of the soul.
kalo\n to\ eu(/rhma, to\ skepa/zein to\n qw/raka: it is an excellent invention, that the corselet should cover. The to/ belongs to both infs. (skepa/zein and kwlu/ein).
e)/fh: he continued.
plei/onos: sc. tw=n a)/llwn. For the gen. of price, see G. 1134; H. 746.
eu)ruqmote/rous: better proportioned.
to\n de\ r(uqmo\n ... plei/onos tima=|: do you show this proportion in the measurement or weight (of your corselets), and so get a better price for them?
ei)/ ge: at least, if.
poiw=: I do make (them to fit).
w(/sper kai\ a(rmo/ttonta (sc. poiw=): precisely as I make it fit, i.e., a good ‘fit’ is good proportion. For kai/, see on i.1.6.
kaq' e(auto/: per se, in and for itself.
pro/s: with reference to.

w(/sper a)\n ei) fai/hs: i.e. w(/sper a)\n
fai/hs, ei) fai/hs, our common Eng. just as if you should say.
tw=| sw=| lo/gw|: according to what you say. Cf. kata/ ge tou=ton to\n lo/gon iv. 2. 32.
e)/xeis: as in i. 6. 13.
pie/zousin: oppress.

to
 au)to
 staqmo
 e)/xontes: although having the same weight.
dieilhmme/noi to\ ba/ros: by distributing their weight.
u(po/: sc. some partic. like fero/menon.
o)li/gou dei=n: almost. For the abs. inf., see on iii.8.10.
prosqh/mati: “a natural appendage.”
au)to/: the very quality.
kako/n poiki/lon te kai\ e)pi/xruson: a decorated and gilded nuisance.
e)/fh: he added.
mh\ me/nontos: does not remain (long in one position).
a)kribei=s: accurately fitted.
au)to\s le/geis: ita est. Cf. the emphatic su\ ei)=pas of Matt. xxvi. 25.
pa/nu o)rqw=s a)pode/xh|: you have the idea exactly.

div2.p: Socrates holds a conversation with Theodota, a courtesan famed for her beauty, on the best method of winning and keeping friends. Beauty alone cannot accomplish this: there must be added good nature and moderation in the bestowal of favors. Theodota expresses a willingness to learn from Socratesthe art of winning lovers.

div3.p: *qeodo/th: afterward the mistress of Alcibiades, whom she is said to have buried after he was slain in Phrygia. Cf. Cornelius Nep. Alc. 10. 6. Plutarch (Alc. 39) says it was Timandra who buried him.
oi(/as: ready. See on i. 4. 6.
tw=| pei/qonti: sc. by solicitation or gifts.

krei=tton ei)/h lo/gou: equivalent to krei=tton h)\ w(/ste le/gein “was beyond the power of description.” Cf. (with the adj. in unfavorable sense) krei=sson lo/gou to\ ei)=dos th=s no/sou Thuc. ii. 50.
e)pideiknu/ein: for the inf., see on w(=n ei)=nai i. 1. 8.
e(auth=s: of her person.
o(/sa kalw=s e)/xoi: “as much as decorum permitted.”
qeasome/nous: acc., since i)te/on a)\n ei)=nai is equivalent to de/oi a)\n i)e/nai. See GMT. 923; H. 991 a.
ou) ga\r ... katamaqei=n: for it is impossible to judge by hearsay of that which passes description.
o( dihghsa/menos: i.e. the first speaker, introduced above by the words mnhsqe/ntos tino/s.
ou)k a)\n fqa/noit) a)kolouqou=ntes: see on ii.3.11.
paresthkui=an: posing, as model. The pf. marks the ‘pose’ as already assumed.
tau/thn (with e(kte/on): acc. like qeasame/nous in 1.
qe/a: sight.
w)felh/setai: in pass. sense. Cf. iii.3.15, 7. 9.
u(poknizo/menoi: with a sting in us.
qerapeu/esqai: “receive our homage.”
ei) e)/xei, a)\n de/oi: for the ‘mixed’ form of cond., see on i.2.45.
qerapei/a| ou) th=| tuxou/sh|: ornaments of no ordinary kind. Cf. ta\ tuxo/nta i. 1. 14. For the costume of Greek women, see Becker, Charicles, p. 247.
ou)de\ tau/tas h)melhme/nws e)/xousas: cf. Terence's description of a meretrix, ancillas adduxit plus decem, oneratas veste atque auro Heaut. iii. 1. 40.
toi=s a)/llois: in all other respects.
a)fqo/nws kateskeuasme/nhn: lavishly furnished.
a)ll' a)/ra: well, then.
xeirote/xnai: skilled slaves, by the sale of whose labor their mistress might profit.
ou(=to/s moi bi/os e)sti/: he constitutes my livelihood.
nh\ th\n *(/hran: see on i.5.5.
o)i+/wn, bow=n: sc. a)ge/lhn with h)/ before o)i+/wn. For the condensed comparison, see on tw=n a)/llwn i. 1. 3, and, for the form of o)i+/wn, on ii. 7. 13.
e)pitre/peis: do you leave it to.
e)a/n: whether.
tou/tou: for this purpose.
proshko/ntws: fitly.
trofh=|: for food. See on dou/lois ii. 1. 12.
ou(/tws ge a)te/xnws: so, without any artifice.
a)/greuma: game.
ne/montai: sc. oi( lagw/|.
ku/nas nuktereutika/s: dogs which hunt by night. For the gender, see on iv.1.3.
meq' h(me/ran: after day has dawned.
h(=|: sc. o(dw=|. The clause is obj. of ai)sqano/menai.
eu)nh/n: the hare's lair or ‘form.’
e)k tou= fanerou=: “in full view.”
kata\ po/das: as in ii. 6. 9.
kth/sh|: sc. fi/lon. The omitted apod. is readily supplied.
w(s e)mble/pousa: with what kind of looks.
to\n e)pimelo/menon: the attentive lover, opposed to to\n trufw=nta the self-conceited, insolent one.
u(pode/xesqai, a)poklei/ein: pres., denoting customary action; the aor. infs. in the next sent. indicate special cases.
kexari/sqai: to be devoted.
ge\ mh/n: see on i.4.5.
eu)= oi(=d' o(/ti: see on iii.6.10.
kai\ mh/n: and yet.
polu\ diafe/rei: multum interest, it is of great importance. So in iii. 12. 5.
qhri/on: creature, appropriately used of man, after the illustrations in 6 and 7.
toiau=ta: sc. poiei=n.
oi(=a poiou=sin au)toi=s ktl.: “as will least trouble them to perform.”
au)th/n: you yourself.
to\n au)to\n tro/pon: i.e. as freely as they oblige you.
me/gista: for the neut. adj. representing a cognate acc., see on i.1.11.
deome/nois: only when they request them.
ta\ para\ seauth=s: “your favors.”—o(ra=s ga\r o(/ti ktl.: cf. the contrast between the followers of Vice and those of Virtue ii. 1. 30, 33.
bdelugmi/an: loathing.
tw=n par' e)moi/: const. with limo/n.
ei) prosfe/rois: sc. ta\ para\ seauth=s. The omitted apod. is easily supplied from the preceding sentence. So with e)a\n pei/qh|s 15.
e)/peita: without de/, as often in Xenophon. See on i. 2. 1.
w(s kosmiwta/th| o(mili/a|: by the most modest demeanor.

tw=| fai/nesqai boulome/nh, kai\ diafeu/gousa: by showing yourself desirous (to please), and yet drawing back. Socrates is ‘giving points’ to a professional coquette. For the nom. of the participles, see on tw=| fanero\s ei)=nai toiou=tos w)/n i. 2. 3.
polu\ diafe/rei: it is far better.

ti/ ou)=n ou) su\ e)ge/nou: why then do you not become. The aor. implies surprise that the action has not taken place, and hence conveys a more emphatic invitation than the pres. would. GMT. 62; H. 839. Cf. iv.6.14.
ei)/siqi: sc. ei)s th\n e)mh\n oi)ki/an.
dhmo/sia: said in jest, as Socrates took no part in public affairs. Cf. i.6.15.
fi/lai: he playfully uses the fem. in speaking of his friends.
fi/ltra, e)pw|da/s: cf. ii.6.10 ff. On the real meaning of e)pw|da/s, cf. ta\s d' e)pw|da\s tau/tas tou\s lo/gous ei)=nai tou\s kalou/s Plato Charm. 157 A, also Phaedo 114 D.

*)apollo/dwron: one of the most devoted companions of Socrates, mentioned by Plato as present both at the trial (Apol. 34A) and at the death scene in the cell (Phaedo 117 D), where his almost hysterical grief was rebuked by the philosopher.
*)antisqe/nhn: see on ii.5.1.
*ke/bhta kai\ *simmi/an: see on i.2.48. These, as well as Antisthenes and Apollodorus, were present at the death of Socrates.

i)u/ggwn: magic wheels. The i)/ugc was a small bird (Lat. torquilla, Fr. torcou, Ger. Wendehals, Eng. ‘wryneck’), which, when bound to a revolving wheel, was supposed by its motions to influence the affections; hence its name was applied to the wheel.
xrh=so/n moi: lend me.
e)pi\ soi\ e(/lkw: set it spinning for you, the usual phrase for putting the i)/ugc in motion. For e)pi\ soi/, see on e)f' oi(=s spouda/seien i. 3. 11.
filwte/ra: see on fi/lai 16. For various forms of the comp. of fi/los, see L. & S. s.v.

e)a\n ... e)/ndon h)=|: wittily said, for the usual excuse of the e(tai=rai in shutting out a would-be visitor was e)/ndon e(/teros. Cf. a)pe/kleisa e)lqo/nta, ‘*)/endon e(/teros’ ei)pou=sa Lucian Dial. Meretr. xii. 310. The whole conversation is inconceivable from a modern standpoint, remembering who and what the speakers were; but it throws a strong side light on one phase of Greek society.

div2.p: Physical exercise strengthens the body, and renders a man not only fit for the pursuits of war, but also better equipped for any line of work. Best of all, it assists mental action.

div3.p: *)epige/nhn: son of Antiphon, of the deme Cephisia. Cf. Plato Apol. 33E, Phaedo 59 B.
i)diwtikw=s: i.e. unlike an athlete.

i)diw/ths: lit. a private citizen, here non-professional, so far as concerns athletics. “I have no object in training, not being an athlete (a)skhth/s).” To which Socrates retorts, “You need training fully as much as those who are to contend in the Olympian games.” See on iii. 7. 7.
qh/sousin: will make, certamina decernent.
o(/tan tu/xwsi: sc. a)gw=na qe/n)tes.
a)poqnh/|skousi/ te, kai\ ai)sxrw=s sw/|zontai: vel pereunt, vel turpiter servantur.
di) au)to\ tou=to: i.e. dia\ to\ kakw=s e)/xein ta\ sw/mata.
e)a\n ou(/tw tu/xwsi: “if this (i.e. slavery) should happen to them.”
e)ktei/santes: paying out, for their ransom.
plei/w tw=n u(parxo/ntwn: more than their property amounted to.
dokou=ntes a)podeilia=n: having the reputation of being cowards.
e)pitimi/wn: penalties, i.e. disadvantages.
tou/twn: agrees with e)pitimi/wn.
kai\ mh/n: see on i.6.3.
pollw=| r(a/|w ... a(\ dei=: const., tou/twn (tw=n e)pitimi/wn) pollw=| r(a/|w kai\ h(di/w (tau=ta) ei)=nai, a(\ dei= ktl.
u(gieino/teron, xrhsimw/teron: for the gender, see on ii.3.1.
dia\ tou=to: by virtue of this quality.
a)forma/s: see on ii.7.11.
o(/ti ou)k a)skei= ktl.: Xenophon, in recording this fact, may be praising the Lacedaemonians tacitly, as he openly does in iii. 5. 15.
a)lla\ mhde\n h(=tton: sc. xrh/.
e)n a)/llw| ou)deni\ a)gw=ni ktl.: war is contrasted with any other contest, and then with any occupation.
mei=on e(/ceis: equivalent to mei/wn e)/sh|.
polu\ diafe/rei: as in iii. 11. 11.
e)pei/: for.
dokei=s: you think.
e)n tw=| dianoei=sqai: in pure thinking.

ti/s ou)k oi)=den: the sent. begins
with e)pei/, as if pa/ntes i)/sasin were to follow, but the transition to the interr. is natural and lively.
polloi=s: in the case of many, dat. of interest.
ta\s e)pisth/mas: “all that they know.”
e)kba/llein: for the inf. of result which a previous action tends to produce, see GMT. 587, 1; H. 953.
ki/ndunos: sc. e)sti/.
ge/: added, because toiou=to/n ti paqei=n is possible from other causes than kaxeci/a tou= sw/matos.
ei)ko\s de\ ma=llon: it is far more likely.
pro\s ta\ e)nanti/a: to results the reverse.
e(/neka: const. with e)nanti/wn.
nou=n e)/xwn: with any sense.
i)dei=n e(auto/n, poi=os: for the ‘prolepsis,’ see on i.2.13.
tau=ta: these qualities.
e)qe/lei: are wont. Cf. o(/sa h( gh= fu/ein qe/lei Oec. 4. 13.

p.gloss: Several brief sayings of Socrates, giving sensible advice on various matters of everyday life.

div3.p: o(/ti: because.
proseipw/n tina xai/rein: the usual form of describing a greeting; cf. the Lat. salve. For the dat. in this formula, cf. a)llh/lois xai/rein prosei=pon Hell. iv.1.31
geloi=on: odd, cf. the Ger. komisch, and our colloquial use of ‘funny.’
to\ mh\ a)\n o)rgi/zesqai: for the articular inf. with modifiers as a noun, see G. 1555; H. 959, and for the inf. with a)/n, see on a)\n e)klexqh=nai iii. 5. 2.
diakeime/nw|: disposed.
a)hdw=s: without appetite. Cf. h(de/ws ii. 1. 30.
*)akoumeno/s: a physician, and friend of Socrates. Cf. Plato Phaedr. 227 A, 268 A, B.
tou/tou fa/rmakon: see on iii.8.3.
dida/skei: prescribes.

pau/sasqai e)sqi/onta: to stop eating. For the supplementary participle, see on ii.1.24. The ‘appetite cure’ has been known to physicians and philosophers from Acumenus and Galen down to Abernethy and Mark Twain.
kai/, dia/cein (sc. fhsi/): see on kai\ u(pakou/setai ii. 3. 16.
pausa/menon: circumstantial participle of condition.
par' e(autw=|: see on ii.7.4.
o(\ pi/noi: which he had to drink.

yuxro/n, w(/ste lou/sasqai: for the inf. with w(s or w(/ste and a positive adj. (instead of comp. with h)/), see GMT. 588. So we say ‘cold for bathing.’ Cf. o)li/goi e)sme/n, w(/ste e)gkratei=s ei)=nai au)tw=n Cyr. iv. 5. 15.
ma\ to\n *di/a: see on i.4.11.
a)lla\ kai/: “indeed, on the contrary.”
to\ e)n *)asklhpiou= (sc. new/|): on the south side of the Acropolis at Athens. Pausanias refers to this spring, and modern travelers speak of the water as not noticeably warm.
lou/sasqai: for the inf. with adjs., see GMT. 763; H. 952, and a.
e)n *)amfiara/ou (sc. new/|): the temple of Amphiarāus (one of the ‘Seven against Thebes’) was at Orōpus in Boeotia; it, too, had a sacred fountain. Cf. Paus. i. 34. 3.
a)ko/louqon: an attendant, the slave whose duty it was to accompany his master when he went out. Cf. 6.
foboume/nou: expressing apprehension of.
oi)/koi: for the accent, see on i.1.2.
poreuo/menos: while on the journey.
peripath/sas a)risth/seis, peripath/sas deipnh/seis: you will simply take a walk and eat your luncheon, take another and eat dinner.
ei) e)ktei/nais: if you should stretch out, in one line.
ou(\s peripatei=s: sc. in Athens. ou(/s is cognate accusative.
*)aqh/nhqen ei)s *)olumpi/an: a distance of about 130 miles.
h(me/ra| mia=|: dat. of degree of difference.
ma=llon: rather, belongs to e)corma=n.
plei/onas (sc. o(dou/s): i.e. the days' journeys.
pareta/qh: worn out, lit. stretched out.
kai/: besides.
a)lla/: “nothing except.”
keno/s: empty-handed.
strw/mata: bedding
a)ph/llaxen e)k: come off from (i.e. stand) the trip.
a)\n diateqh=nai: would have fared.

tou= paido/s: the slave. Cf. the old Eng. use of ‘knave’ (Ger. Knabe) equivalent to ‘servant,’ and the former use of the word ‘boy’ for ‘slave’ in our Southern States. Slaves were excluded from the exercises of the palaestra, and hence were ou)k h)skhme/noi.
h)skhme/nou a)ndro/s: cf. iii.12.1, 5.

p.gloss: Some table talk of Socrates in praise of moderation in eating.

div3.p: sunio/ntwn e)pi\ dei=pnon: the feast seems to have been what was known as e)/ranos (a picnic or ‘basket party’), to which each guest brought his own share of the food.
o)/yon: meat, fish, or sauce, originally anything eaten with bread.
ei)s to\ koino\n tiqe/nai: to place on the table for common participation.
to/ te mh\ koinwnei=n kai/: both to refrain from sharing, and.
e)pei/: since.
e)pau/onto pollou= o)ywnou=ntes: they stopped buying meat at a high price. For the partic., see on e)sqi/onta 13. 2.
si/tou: equivalent to a)/rtou bread, as distinguished from o)/yon.
e)f) oi(/w| e)/rgw| e(/kaston ei)/h: for what action each was given.

poi/w| pote/:
see on i.1.1.
ga\r ou)=n: see on iii.6.12.
to\ o)/yon au)to/: his meat by itself.
a)skh/sews: of training, like that of the athletes, who ate a great deal of meat to strengthen them.
sxolh=|: hardly.
polukarpi/an, poluoyi/an: “a good year for crops, a good year for meat.”
katamaqw/n: observing.
tou=ton: note the ‘prolepsis.’
oi( plhsi/on (sc. o)/ntes): in appos. with the u(mei=s implied in parathrei=te.
o(po/tera: a rare substitute for po/tera.
tw=| si/tw| ... xrh/setai: “will make a relish of the staple, or a staple of the relish” (Dakyns). For the dats., see on dou/lois ii. 1. 12.
tw=| ywmw=|: sc. a)/rtou or si/tou. ywmo/s is a sop or morsel of bread, in N. T. ywmi/on, cf. John xii. 26, 30.
o)/ywn: here, dainty dishes.
lumainome/nh: calculated to spoil.
h)\ h(\n o)yopoiei=tai, o(: than that which he practices, who.

plei/w me/n ge tw=n o)yopoiw=n summeignu/wn: as he mingles
more ingredients even than the cooks. For the abridged comparison, see on koino/teron tw=n a)/llwn i. 1. 3.
a(\ de\ ... o( summeignu/wn: equivalent to tau=ta de/, a(\ e)kei=noi mh\ summeignu/ousin, summeignu/wn.
e)kei=noi: i.e. oi( o)yopoioi/.
katalu/ei: renders useless. Cf. katalu/ei to\n i(ppe/a Eq. xii. 5.
mhd' a)ntipoiou/menon th=s te/xnhs tau/ths: pretending to no skill in this art.
metatiqe/nai: to alter.
meionektei=n: to be stinted. Cf. mei=on e(/ceis 12. 5.—to\n e(/na ywmo\n ktl.: to accompany one piece of bread by one of meat.
o(/te mh\ parei/h: for o(/tan mh\ parh=|, by assimilation to the mode of the main sentence.
e)/lege: he used to remark.
to\ eu)wxei=sqai: the phrase ‘good cheer.’ For the neut. art. before any word or expression made the obj. of thought, see G. 955, 2; H. 125 e.
kaloi=to: signified.
to\eu)=: the adverb eu)=.
e)pi\ tw=| e)sqi/ein: “to express the eating.”
a)neti/qei: he used to apply. ‘Good cheer’ comes only when we eat wholesome viands and in moderation.

div2.p: Socrates loved the companionship of young men, but of those only in whom he discerned natural abilities and an enthusiasm for what was noble. These, he held, stood especially in need of instruction; for enthusiasm and force, when misdirected, may lead to the most disastrous consequences. On the other hand, those who thought themselves able to dispense with instruction because they were rich, he regarded as the greatest of fools.

div3.p: kai\ metri/ws ai)sqanome/nw|: concessive, even of moderate discernment. For ai)sqa/nomai in the sense of general intelligence, cf. ou)de\ pro\s a)nqrw/pwn tw=n ai)sqanome/nwn Thuc. i. 71.
o(pouou=n, o(tw|ou=n: see on o(pwstiou=n i. 6. 11.
a)podexome/nous e)kei=non: “receiving and accepting his teachings.” Cf. tou\s a)podecame/nous a(/per au)to\s e)doki/mazen i. 2. 8.

pai/zwn, spouda/zwn: cf. e)/paizen a(/ma spouda/zwn i. 3. 8. An instance of the playfulness is found in the e)ra=n of 2, a word usually directed toward physical attractions. Another is the amusing prooi/mion of 2. 4 and 5.
e)/fh, a)/n: sc. as often as occasion arose. For the iterative a)/n, see on a)\n e)/dwke ii. 9. 4, and cf. iv.6.13.
tw=n, tw=n: const. with eu)= pefuko/twn those who were well endowed by nature.
w(/ran, a)reth/n: without the art., see on i.2.23.
e)tekmai/reto: he used to infer.
tou= manqa/nein: sc. au)tou/s as subject.

oi(=s prose/xoien: for oi(=s a)\n prose/xwsi of direct discourse. G.
1431, 1497, 2; H. 914, 934.
oi)ki/an: we might expect oi)=kon, after the analogy of i. 1. 7, 2. 64; ii. 1. 19.
to\ o(/lon: omnino.
tou\s ga\r toiou/tous paideuqe/ntas: for such natures when trained. This sent. contains the reason for the preceding tw=n eu)= pefuko/twn e)fie/menos.
ou) to\n au)to\n tro/pon: like St. Paul, Socrates could be ‘all things to all men.’ This variety in his methods is ridiculed by Aristophanes Clouds 478-480.
tou\s me/n: corresponds to tou\s de/ in 5.
ei) damasqei=en: if they should be broken in.
ou)sw=n: when hounds are meant, kuw/n is generally grammatically feminine. Cf. iii.11.8.
e)piqetikw=n: eager to attack.
a)xqei/sas (a)/gw): the usual term for training hunting dogs.
gi/gnesqai: note the change from the participle (gignome/nous) to the inf., permissible from the fact that e)pideiknu/ein is a verbum declarandi.
a)nagw/gous de\ gignome/nas: but if they should remain untrained, a slight ‘anacoluthon,’ since ta\s me/n preceded.

o(moi/ws de\ kai\ tw=n a)nqrw/pwn ktl.: the thought that the very worst of characters are developed from the most richly endowed natures is frequent in Plato. Cf. Rep. 491; Gorg.
526A.

w(=n a)
 e)gxeirw=si: equivalent to tou/twn, a(\ a)
 e)gxeirw=sin e)cerga/zesqai. For the gen., see on tw=n ei)s to
 po/lemon iii. 1. 6.
e)rga/zesqai: for the inf., see on w(=n ou)de\n ei)=nai i. 1. 8.
e)fre/nou: he tried to bring to reason. Cf. ii. 6. 1.
ei)/h: the subj. is to be supplied from the following clause.
ei)/ tis oi)/etai: for the indic. in subord. clauses of indirect discourse, see G. 1497, 2; H. 933.
ta/ te, kai\ ta/, diagnw/sesqai: for te/ and kai/ with words of discrimination, see on iii.4.3.
pra/ttein eu)= te pra/ttein: for a similar play on words, cf. i.6.8.
eu)dokimh/sein: will win esteem.

div2.p:
1-20. How well Socrates knew how to bring to their senses young men who were filled with conceit of their fancied wisdom, is illustrated in his talks with Euthydēmus. This youth wished to become a statesman,
but had no idea of going through any preliminary course of study or training. Socrates shows him that he needs this, since he has no clear ideas even about what is just and unjust, which surely a statesman must understand.

div3.p: *eu)qu/dhmon: cf. i.2.29.

gra/mmata polla\ suneilegme/non: had collected many writings, as we should say, ‘had a good library.’ He may have had several dozen manuscripts. Cf. what Socrates says of himself, tou\s qhsaurou\s tw=n pa/lai sofw=n a)ndrw=n, ou(\s e)kei=noi kate/lipon e)n bibli/ois gra/yantes ktl. i. 6. 14.
sofistw=n: see on i.1.11.
e)k tou/twn: as a result of this.
prw=ton me/n: corresponds to e)pei\ de/ in 6.
dia\ neo/thta: perhaps he was not yet eighteen. See on iii. 6. 1.
h(niopoiei=o/n ti tw=n: equivalent to ti\ tw=n h(niopoiei/wn tw=n. On such shops as places of resort, see Becker, Charicles, p. 279.
h)/|ei: the main verb at last, preceded by the circumstantial participles katamaqw/n and ai)sqano/menos, and followed by e)/xwn.
tw=n meq) e(autou=: companions. In the Anabasis the phrase generally means attendants or retinue.
prw=ton me/n: corresponds to pa/lin de/ in 3.
punqanome/nou tino/s: on some one's raising the question.
*qemistoklh=s: see on ii.6.13.
dia\ sunousi/an tino\s tw=n sofw=n: cf. sofoi\ tu/rannoi tw=n sofw=n cunousi/a| Soph. Fr. 12.
kinei=n: to draw out, lit. to stir.

ta\s te/xnas: acc. of specification
with spoudai/ous skilled.

a)po\ tau)toma/tou: equivalent to fu/sei above. Cf. le/getai (o( *periklh=s) ... ou)k a)po\ tau)toma/tou sofo\s gegone/nai, a)lla\ polloi=s kai\ sofoi=s suggegone/nai Plato Alc. I, 118 C. So Demosthenes (xviii. 205) speaks of to\n tau)to/maton qa/naton, i.e. natural death.
a)poxwrou=nta: withdrawing from.
qauma/zein e)pi\ sofi/a|: cf. i.4.3.
*eu)qu/dhmos ou(tosi/: our friend Euthydemus here, with a gesture. For the ‘deictic’ form of prons., see G. 412; H. 274.
e)n h(liki/a| geno/menos: when he has reached the proper age.
protiqei/shs: sc. through the herald. Cf. h)rw/ta me\n o( kh=ruc: ti/s a)goreu/ein bou/letai; Dem. xviii. 170.
prooi/mion: the exordium, or introduction of an oration.
kai\ ta)nanti/a (sc. e)poi/hsa): precisely the reverse.
diatete/leka feu/gwn: I have constantly avoided. For the supplementary participle with diatele/w, see G. 1587; H. 981.
to\ do/cai: sc. memaqhke/nai ti para/ tinos. Cf. 5.
e)pi/h| moi: may occur to me. So soi\ e)ph=lqen e)nqumhqh=nai iv. 3. 3. Cf. e)sh=lqe/ me Hdt. vii. 46.
a(rmo/seie: would be appropriate for.

i)atriko\n e)/rgon: the office of city physician. Certain physicians were,
in Athens, elected by the popular assembly (e)kklhsi/a) and paid by the state, to care for the sick among the poorer citizens.
a)pokinduneu/wn: by trying experiments, at your risk.
ou)=n: so, naturally.
prose/xwn: as Euthydemus was represented in 3 as departing (a)poxwrou=nta), either he must have changed his mind, or the present discourse is to be referred to another occasion.
nomi/zwn periba/llesqai: the pres. inf. is especially appropriate here: “thinking that all the time he was wrapping himself in.”
qaumasto\n ga/r: now it is surprising.
ti/ pote: see on i.1.1. The irony is somewhat strengthened by pote/.
para\ toi=s a)ri/stois ktl.: “with teachers of the highest reputation.”
pa/nta: everything imaginable. See on ii. 2. 6.
e(/neka tou= poiei=n: that they may do.
w(s ou)k a)\n a)/llws geno/menoi: in the belief that otherwise they could not become.
tw=n de\ boulome/nwn: while of those who wish, part. gen. with tine/s. The argument is a fortiori, a favorite form with Socrates; cf. 2.

kai/toi ge tosou/tw| ... gi/gnontai: and yet success in these pursuits (collectively, statesmanship) is more difficult of attainment than in those (cithara playing etc.) just in proportion as, out of the larger number engaging in these, fewer achieve success. pleio/nwn may be either part. gen. or gen. abs. of concession although a larger number engage etc.
kat' a)rxa/s: at first.
a)kou/ontos *eu)qudh/mou: in the hearing of Euthydemus.
u(pome/nonta: staying behind.
mo/nos: contrasted with tw=n meq' e(autou= tinas e)/xwn of 1.
ei)pe/: for the accent, see on i.2.41.
tw=n legome/nwn sofw=n gegone/nai: for the pred. adj., see G. 931; H. 940 a.
e(/ws a)\n kth/swmai: for temporal clauses implying purpose, see G. 1467; H. 921, and Remark.
nh\ th\n *(/hran: see on i.5.5.
proei/lou ma=llon: cf. Lat. potius malle.
gnw/mas: precepts.
metie/nai: to be pursuing.
ti/: modifies a)gaqo/s.

a)=ra mh\ i)atro/s: sc. boulo/menos gene/sqai, in loose connection with the preceding ti/ de\ dh\ boulo/menos a)gaqo\s gene/sqai, after which something like a)=ra mh\ th\n i)atrikh/n might be expected.
gnwmonikou= a)ndro/s: with reference to the gnw/mas of 9.
ou)/koun: no indeed.
*qeo/dwros: of Cyrene, said to have been a teacher of Socrates.
a)strolo/gos: an astronomer. Cf. iv. 7. 4.

pa/nu h)liqi/ous: sufficiently represents the opinion of Socrates's time, that the professional rhapsodes declaimed the Homeric poems with little real understanding. Cf. Sym. iii. 6; Plato Ion 530 B ff.
ou) dh/pou: as in ii. 3. 1.

a)ta/r: a significant but, marking the second stage of the lesson.—
kai\ ma/la: sc. kataneno/hka.
ou)x oi(=o/n te/ ge: the ge/ adds emphasis to the answer, in which the words of the question are in part repeated.
tou=to: i.e. di/kaios gene/sqai.
ou)deno\s h(=tton di/kaios: as upright as any one. See on i. 5. 6.
e)/rga: characteristic works.
e)/xoien a)/n: doubly potential, in meaning and syntax.
mh\ ou)=n ou) du/nwmai: (do you fear) that I may be unable. G. 1350; H. 867.
kai/: nay.
bou/lei, gra/ywmen: see on bou/lei skopw=men ii. 1. 1.
de/lta, a)/lfa: to stand, of course, for dikaiosu/nh and a)diki/a.
tiqw=men: pres. as denoting repeated action (hence poi/ei in the answer); afterward, when a single action is spoken of, qw=men is used.
ei)=pen: “suggested.”

dh=lon, e)/fh, o(/ti: i.e. dh=lo/n e)sti, e)/fh, o(/ti. The condensed form dh=lon o(/ti, manifestly, occurs just below. With both
forms, sc. qete/on e)sti/n.
to\ kakourgei=n (sc. pote/rwse qw=men): doing mischief. Note the increasing brevity of questions and answers.
h(mi=n: in our opinion. For the dat. of relation, see G. 1172; H. 771.
strathgo/s: pred. with ai(reqei/s.
di/kaia (sc. e)/rga) poiei=n: sc. au)to/n as subj. of the infinitive.
polemw=n: in the course of the war.
au)toi=s: i.e. the citizens implied in po/lin above.
kle/pth| te kai\ a(rpa/zh|: an example of kakourgei=n.
u(pela/mbanon: I was assuming.
pro/s: with reference to.
pro\s th=| a)diki/a|: for prep. and dat. with verbs of motion, see H. 788. Little distinction seems to be made in the use of pro/s with the dat. and with the acc. in this and the preceding section.

e)qh/kamen. for the pl. forms of the 1 aor. with k, see on e)/dwkan i. 1. 9. Cf. An. iii. 2. 5; e)dw/kamen Hell. vi.3.6; paredw/kamen Oec. ix. 9. Both forms occur in a)ristei=a e)/dwkan, kai\ oi)kei=n a)te/leian e)/dosan tw=| boulome/nw| Hell. i.2.10
bou/lei: as in 13.
diorisw/meqa pa/lin: make a new distinction.
a)lla/: The Eng. idiom would permit and here, since this clause is not opposed in thought to the preceding one.
w(s a(plou/staton ei)=nai: to be perfectly straightforward.
a)qu/mws e)/xon: in a despondent condition.
pau/sh|: free.
ei)s to\ au)to/: on the same side.
mh\ diaxrh/shtai: lest he make away with himself. Cf. diaxra=sqai Hdt. i. 24. For a similar treatment of the ordinary view of dikaiosu/nh, cf. Plato Rep. 331 C ff.
a(/panta a(ploi+/zesqai: with reference to the w(s a(plou/staton ei)=nai of 16.
metati/qemai: much like a)nati/qemai in i. 2. 44. Cf. Hdt. vii. 18.
dei= e)cei=nai: sc. metati/qesqai.
e)capatw/ntwn e)pi\ bla/bh|: in 17 and 18 the argument dealt with justifiable violations of the moral law for a good purpose; we are now to consider malicious deceit towards friends.
e(kw/n: intentionally.
tw=n gramma/twn: lit. letters; here, the rudiments of learning, reading and writing.

o(po/te bou/loito: for the assimilation of mode, see on ai)sqanoi/meqa i. 5. 1.—dikaio/teron ktl.: the fallacy, of course, consists in the assumption that he who knows what is right will always do it; a confusing of knowledge with character. He who knows the right is not ‘righter,’ but only ‘more knowing’ than he who does not know it. While we recognize this argument as a weak place in Socrates's reasoning, it is not necessary to regard him as insincere in making use of it to convict the young man of ignorance. It is clear that to him the term ‘knowledge’ included more than we understand by it. See Introd. §§ 18-21.
fai/nomai (sc. tou=to le/gwn): “evidently I am saying this.”
ou)k oi)=d' o(/pws: somehow or other.

21-29. Euthydemus is made to confess that he does not know what he thought he knew. Socrates, having destroyed the young man's selfconfidence, impresses on him the importance of self-knowledge; and, by a series of searching questions, brings him to see and confess how sadly he needs this knowledge.
21. o(\s a)\n mhde/pote ta\ au)ta\ peri\ tw=n au)tw=n le/gh|: a fault frequently committed by Euthydemus in the preceding portion of the dialogue. Cf. Plato Gorg. 491 B, C.
fra/zwn: describing.

logismo\n to\n au)to/n: one and the same calculation.—
dh=los, o(/ti oi)=den: see on ou) lanqa/neis me, o(/ti iii. 5. 24.
a)ndrapodw/deis: servile. See on i. 1. 16.
a)ll' a)/ra: “at fortasse.” Cf. iii.11.4.
tou)nanti/on: adverbial. See on i. 2. 60.
ou)de\ di) e(\n tou/twn: more emphatic than di) ou)de\n tou/twn would be.
to\ o)/noma tou=t' e)sti/n: does this name belong.
a)ndra/poda: lit. slaves, here indicates the opposite of kaloi\ ka)gaqoi/, hence boors, the ignobile vulgus. See on kalou\s ka)gaqou/s i. 1. 16.
pa/nu w)/|mhn: I certainly supposed.
filosofei=n filosofi/an: “that I was following a plan of study.”
a)\n paideuqh=nai: for the inf. with a)/n in indirect discourse, see on iii.5.2.
ta\ prosh/konta: for one of two accs. retained in the pass. with verbs of teaching, see G. 1239; H. 724 a.
o)regome/nw|: for the attrib. participle, see G. 1559; H. 965.
pw=s: exclamatory rather than interr., belongs to a)qu/mws.
dia/: in view of the following neg., suggests the meaning “after,” “in spite of.” Similarly e(/neka iv. 3. 3.
u(pe\r w(=n: i.e. u(pe\r tou/twn, a(/. Const. with to\ e)rwtw/menon a question in regard to matters which.
h(\n poreuo/menos: by pursuing which.

ei)s *delfou\s de/: the de/ seems to oppose its sent. to the preceding: “You say you have no other road to travel; have you ever gone to Delphi?” Delphi was the home of Apollo's most celebrated oracle, on the slopes of Mt. Parnassus in Phocis. The modern village which occupied the site of the ancient Delphi has been purchased and removed; and extensive excavations have been made by French archaeologists.
naw=|: see on iii.8.10.

to\ ‘*gnw=qi sauto/n’: the famous ‘Know thyself.’ This celebrated saying, variously attributed to Bias, Chilo, and others of the Seven Wise Men, was a favorite one with Socrates, as embodying the essence of his philosophy. Cf. ou) du/namai/ pw kata\ to\ *delfiko\n gra/mma (inscription) gnw=nai e)mauto/n Plato Phaedr. 229 E. Cf. also Cic. Tusc. Disp. i. 22. 52.
sxolh=| a)\n h)/|dein: the neg. effect of sxolh=| (hardly) is well shown in this apod. of an unfulfilled condition. Cf. iii.14.3.
o(/n: i.e. to\n i(/ppon, o(/n.
ta)/lla pro\s th\n xrei/an, o(/pws e)/xei: how he is in the other points pertaining to the use.
ou(/tws o( e(auto\n e)piskeya/menos: after the long comparison beginning with w(/sper, the subj. o(/stis is renewed by the article.
dokei=: the personal construction.
a)/nqrwpoi: without the article, as often.
dia\ to\ e)yeu=sqai e(autw=n: for the gen. with verbs of failing, deceiving, etc., see G. 1099; H. 748.
diagignw/skousin a(/ te, kai\ a(/: see on iii.1.9.
kai\ tou\s a)/llous: sc. as well as themselves.
ei)do/tes: sc. e(autou/s.
dieyeusme/noi: the dia/ denotes completeness, thoroughly deceived.
o(moi/ws dia/keintai: are in the same condition, sc. of ignorance as to other men and other affairs.
oi(/ te o(/moioi: i.e. those who have similar knowledge.
kai/, ge/: and, even. Obs. the emphatic repetition of the dem. pron. ou(=tos.
e)/xousi: “they rest.”
kakw=s ai(rou/menoi: making unfortunate choices, in cases where they have to decide what is suited to their powers.
a)lla\ kai\ a)docou=si: but they also lose reputation. In addition to the concrete losses sustained by the failure of their plans, come chagrin and ill repute.
tw=n po/lewn o(/ti: emphatic position before o(/sai, to heighten the contrast of po/lewn with the individuals just mentioned.
e)c e)leuqe/rwn: from a condition of freedom. See on e)k pai/dwn ii. 1. 21.

30-39. Socrates shows Euthydemus that he still lacks the most necessary conditions of self-knowledge. His conception of good and evil is far from satisfactory; and, while professing an ambition to share in the leadership of a democratic state, he is at the same time unable to say what the dh=mos really is.

30. w(s pa/nu moi dokou=n, ou(/tws i)/sqi: “rest assured that I fully believe,” lit. in the belief that this seems so to me, understand accordingly. The participle is acc. absolute. For this use of the circumstantial participle, see GMT. 917; H. 973. Cf. a)ll' w(s fane/n ge tou)/pos w(=d) e)pi/staso Soph. Oed. Tyr. 848.
o(po/qen de/: but as to the point from which.
tou=to: emphatic position, obj. of e)chgh/sasqai.
ei) e)qelh/sais a)/n: (to see) whether you would be willing, an indirect question after a)poble/pw, and also a potential opt. with faintly conceived protasis. G. 1327, 1605; H. 872, 1016.
pou/: with irony, as in iii. 3. 2.

ei) mh\ oi)=da, a)\n ei)/hn: for the ‘mixed’ cond., see on ei)/ e)sti, kalw=s
a)\n e)/xoi ii. 5. 4.
au)to\ to\ u(giai/nein: health itself, contrasted with ta\ ai)/tia the causes.
e)/peita: without de/, as in i. 4. 11.
e)pithdeu/mata: occupations.
ta\ me/n, ta\ de/: see on ii.1.4.
o(/tan gi/gnhtai, a)\n ei)/h: see on 31, and cf. G. 1437; H. 918.
blabera=s: disastrous.
metasxo/ntes, a)poleifqe/ntes: both participles, indicating respectively sharing and separation, are const. with the preceding genitives.
ou)de/n: sc. ma=llon a)gaqa\ h)\ kaka/.
ti/ dai/: how so, expresses ironical surprise.

*dai/dalon: the famous artificer, who built the Labyrinth for Minos, king of Crete. The story of his escape by means of wings fastened with wax to his shoulders, and of the death of his son Icarus, was a favorite with the ancients. Cf. Ovid Met. viii. 157 ff.
*mi/nw: for the form, see on i(/lew| i. 1. 9.

e)kei/nw|:
i.e. Minos. See on i. 2. 3.

*palamh/dous: one of the wisest of the Greeks before Troy. The various legends about him (many of them later than Xenophon's time) generally agree in making him the object of Odysseus's envy and malice. Cf. Ovid Met. viii. 56-59.
a)po/llutai: pres. tense, citing an event well known in song and story.
a)naspa/stous gegone/nai: cf. a)na/statoi gi/gnontai 29.
basile/a: see on iii.5.26.
kinduneu/ei: is likely. Cf. ii. 3. 17; iii. 13. 3. Euthydemus begins abruptly, without acknowledging the justice of what has just been said.
ei)/ ge mh/ tis suntiqei/h: unless, indeed, we should compose it.
tw=n eu)daimonikw=n: the elements of happiness.
prosqh/somen: sc. tau=ta.
parakekinhko/twn: “beside themselves.”
ou) mikroi=s: ‘litotes.’
pepo/nqasin: for the rare ‘gnomic’ pf., see G. 1295; H. 824 b.
pro\s tou\s qeou/s: instead of the simple dative. Cf. eu)/xeto pro\s to\n h(/lion Hdt. vii. 54.
dhmokrati/an: ‘prolepsis.’ So dh=mon in line 309. See on i. 2. 13.
dunato/n: possible.
mh\ ei)do/ta: without knowing. See on a(pto/menon i. 3. 8.
ei)s a(\ dei= telei=n: to pay for the necessaries of life.
tau=ta: “that little.”
kai\ nh\ *di/a, oi)=da ga\r kai/: aye, by Zeus; why, I also know of.
a)nagka/zontai a)dikei=n: cf. kakourgei=n in 14. For the thought, cf. tw=| ou)=n tura/nnw| ta\ pollapla/sia h(=tton i(kana/ e)stin ei)s ta\ a)nagkai=a dapanh/mata h)\ tw=| i)diw/th| Hiero iv. 9.

tou\s me\n tura/nnous: as if Euthydemus had spoken, not of some princes, but of the princes as a
class.
dh=lon o(/ti: evidently. See on iii. 7. 1.
faulo/ths: lit. worthlessness, here “lack of insight.”
fronti/zw mh\ h)=|: for obj. clauses with verbs of fearing, see on i.2.18.
kinduneu/w ga\r a(plw=s ou)de\n ei)de/nai: for I seem to know absolutely nothing.
pa/nu a)qu/mws e)/xwn: in a very despondent frame of mind.
tw=| o)/nti a)ndra/podon: cf. a)ndrapodw/deis 22, and o(/pws mh\ a)ndra/poda w)=men 23.
tw=n ou(/tw diateqe/ntwn: of those thus treated.
o(/ti ma/lista: quam frequentissime.
dieta/ratten: sc. e)le/gxwn, as, e.g., in 20, 33, 39.
a(plou/stata: quite simply, without irony.

a(/ te e)no/mizen: we should expect the te/ after ei)de/nai. Its position is due to the condensed form of the sent., which, in full, would read e)chgei=to a(/ te e)no/mizen ei)de/nai dei=n kai\ a(\ e)no/mizen e)pithdeu/ein kra/tista ei)=nai.

div2.p: Socrates impresses on his followers the necessity of swfrosu/nh in our relations with the gods as well as with men. He convinces Euthydemus that the gods, who have given to mortals all that they have, exercise over them a constant providential care. All other creatures are subject to man, who enjoys the immense advantages of reason and speech. The gods are visible, not in their persons but in their works. Moreover, man can ascertain from the gods what is best for him, if he will only reverence, honor, and trust them. See Introd. § 20.
This chapter forms the sequel to i. 4, and serves to refute a charge against Socrates which was only touched in i. 2. 17 (ou)k a)ntile/gw).

div3.p: lektikou/s, praktikou/s, mhxanikou/s: the development of these three qualities will be discussed in chaps. 6, 5, and 7 respectively.
pro/teron, e)ggene/sqai: see on i.2.17.
swfrosu/nhn: lit. soundness of soul; in this chapter, a right attitude of mind. See Introd. § 20.
tau=ta duname/nous: sc. le/gein kai\ pra/ttein, briefly indicated in ta\ politika/ in i. 2. 17.
a)dikwte/rous, dunatwte/rous: sc. than they were before acquiring the above-mentioned qualities (tau=ta).
prw=ton, peri\ qeou\s: cf. ‘the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom.’
ou(/tws o(milou=nti: when conversing in this manner, i.e. preaching swfrosu/nh.
e)gw\ de/: Xenophon gives to this conversation the authority of an earwitness.
soi\ e)ph=lqen: tibi in mentem venit. Cf. iv.2.4.
w(s: how.
w(=n: i.e. tau=ta, w(=n.
kai\ o(/s: see on i.4.3.
o(/ g' ei) mh\ ei)/xomen: the rel. o(/ repeats with force the rel. of the previous sentence.

e(/neka/ ge tw=n h(mete/rwn o)fqalmw=n: so far as it depends on our eyes, i.e. in spite of having eyes. Cf. a)ll' e)ce/stai h(mi=n, e)kei/nou e(/neka, pro\s to\ h(me/teron sumfe/ron pa/nta ti/qesqai but it will be in our power, for anything that he can do, to arrange everything to our own advantage Cyr. iii. 2. 30.
e)peidh/: inasmuch as.

o( me\n h(/lios, h( de\ nu/c: while the sum, yet the night. Both clauses are grammatically equivalent parts of the general reason introduced by e)peidh/, but the weight of the reason lies in h( de\ nu\c ktl.
ta/s te w(/ras th=s h(me/ras: for the divisions of the day, see on i.1.10.
dia\ to\ skoteinh\ ei)=nai: change in form of expression from fwteino\s w)/n above. For the case of skoteinh/, see on au)to/s ii. 3. 11.
a)ne/fhnan: caused to shine.
th=s nukto\s ta\s w(/ras: the Greeks divided the night into three watches (fulakai/), the Romans into four (vigiliae).
dia\ tou=to: by means of this, refers to a)/stra ... a)ne/fhnan.
polla\ pra/ttomen: sc. which we could not do but for the help of moonlight and starlight.

tou= mhno\s ta\ me/rh: the month had three divisions, the first and last of which were called i(stame/nou and fqi/nontos (mhno/s), the days of the middle division being reckoned as prw/th e)pi\ de/ka etc. The average length of a lunar month is a little over twenty-nine and a half days; the Greeks took it at exactly twentynine and a half days, and avoided the fraction by making one month of twenty-nine days and the next of thirty. See Gow, Companion to School Classics, p. 79.
to\ d' a)nadido/nai: sc. as subj. tou\s qeou/s. The unexpressed question may be translated “what say you of that?” Cf. i.4.7.
w(/ras: seasons, of the year.
to\ u(/dwr: obj. of pare/xein.

sumfu/ein ktl.: unites with the earth and the seasons in causing to spring up and grow. kai/ before sumfu/ein corresponds to kai/ before meignu/menon, and kai/ before e)peidh/ connects a)fqone/staton pare/xein with kai\ u(/dwr
pare/xein at the beginning of the sentence.
pa=si toi=s tre/fousin: neuter.
eu)katergasto/tera: easier of digestion.
au)ta/: i.e. pa/nta ta\ tre/fonta.
a)fqone/staton: pred., in the greatest profusion.
e)pi/kouron yu/xous: a protection against cold. Cf. e)pikou/rhma th=s xio/nos An. iv.5.13
w(s sunelo/nti ei)pei=n: see on iii.8.10.
tw=n xrhsi/mwn: depends on ou)de/n.
u(perba/llei: intr., is preëminent.
filanqrwpi/a|: dat. of respect.
e)peida\n e)n xeimw=ni tra/phtai: sc. at the winter solstice, when the sun begins to move northward, or ‘toward us.’
a(dru/nonta: ripening.
w(=n kairo\s dielh/luqen: whose time of maturity has passed; e.g., hay or grain left standing in the fields.
a)potre/pesqai: sc. at the summer solstice.
ge/nhtai e)/nqa: reaches that point, where.

ei) a)/peisin: most vivid form of protasis. G. 1405; H. 899. This has the ‘minatory’ force suggested by Gildersleeve; see Trans. Am. Philol. Assn., vii. p. 13. For the pres. of ei)=mi in fut. sense, see G. 1257; H. 828 a.
a)popaghso/meqa: for the second fut. pass., see G. 715; H. 474.

kai\ e)ntau=qa: refers to the position of the sun in both winter and summer. Xenophon's knowledge of astronomy was,
of course, that of his time; but his description is fairly correct. Even modern astronomers conform to popular usage in speaking of the sun's ‘rising and setting,’ ‘approaching’ and ‘receding from’ the earth.
a)nastre/fesqai: versari, stays, in its apparent daily circuit round the earth.
e)/oike gignome/nois: “looks like something taking place.”
to\ de/: const. with prosie/nai to\n h(/lion.
ei) gi/gnoito: if it should come upon us.

ou(/tw kata\ mikro/n: thus, gradually. For the thought, cf. dida/skei de\ kai\ o( qeo/s, a)pa/gwn h(ma=s kata\ mikro
 e)k tou= xeimw=nos ei)s to\ a)ne/xesqai i)sxura\ qa/lph (intense heat) e)/k te tou= qa/lpous ei)s to
 i)sxuro
 xeimw=na Cyr. vi. 2. 29.
lanqa/nein: i.e. imperceptibly. For lanqa/nw with supplementary participle, see on i.2.34.
ei) a)/ra: see on ii.5.2.
ti/ e)sti toi=s qeoi=s e)/rgon: “the gods have any (other) occupation.”
qerapeu/ein: to care for, as in i. 4. 10.
tou/twn: these benefits.
a)gaqa/: advantages.
dokei=: sc. a)polau/ein tou\s a)nqrw/pous, i.e. that men derive more advantage from animals than from plants.

tou/twn: i.e. animals. The dem. ou(=tos is used to denote the more important of two objects, as that which is nearer to the speaker's thought. See on i. 3.
13.
ge/nos, zw=si: for the pl. verb with sing. collective subj., see on w(s pau/santes ii. 2. 3.
sunergoi=s xrw=ntai(sc.au)toi=s): use them ashelpers. For the pred. dat., see H. 777 a.
o(/ ti: in whatever way, sc. xrh=sqai. See on au)th=| xrh=sqai/ ti i. 4. 6.
prosqei=nai: sc. as subj. tou\s qeou/s.
a)polau/omen: the subj. h(mei=s is readily supplied from a)nqrw/pois.
logismo/n: reason.
polla/: cognate accusative.
a)leco/meqa: avert. On this and the next section, cf. i.4.5-14.
e(rmhnei/an: faculty of speech. Hermes was messenger and interpreter for the gods; hence e(rmhneu/s interpreter.
dida/skontes: by imparting.
pronoei=sqai u(pe/r: instead of pronoei=sqai peri/, the verb being one of caring for.
h(=|: in what way.

gi/gnointo: pl. with neut. subj., either, as Kühner suggests, because ta\ a)pobhso/mena is somewhat remote, or because Xenophon wished to emphasize the idea of separate actions. Cf. e)ntau=qa h)=san ta\ *bele/suos basi/leia
An. i.4.10, where the idea of a multitude of apartments in the palace is helped by the pl.; also kai\ ta\ u(podh/mata perieph/gnunto An. iv.5.14, where the shoes of many individuals are meant.
ei)/ ge proshmai/nousi: cf. i.4.15, where Aristodemus makes the same remark.

o(/ti de/ ge a)lhqh= le/gw: sc. that the daimo/nion (i. 1. 2) really gives me advice as to what I should and should not do, a point on which the preceding words of Euthydemus seem to cast doubt. The sense of the following passage is “I do not mean to say that the gods appear to me in bodily form. If you observe what they accomplish you will revere and honor them. The gods themselves give the hint that we must not expect to see them, but must be assured of their existence by the blessings which they bestow: they create and control,—that we see; but how they do it, we do not see.”

oi(/ te a)/lloi: sc. qeoi/. Socrates and those who followed him, Plato, the Stoics, Cicero, and others, supported the idea that besides one supreme God, there were other beings, far inferior to him, but immortal and endowed with great power. Cf., in i. 4., §§ 5 and 7 with 11, 16 and 18. The task of controlling the universe, here assigned to the supreme Deity, is elsewhere assigned toi=s qeoi=s. Cf. tou\s a)ei\ o)/ntas kai\ pa/nta duname/nous, oi(\ kai\ th/nde tw=n o(/lwn ta/cin sune/xousin a)tribh= kai\ a)gh/raton kai\ a)nama/rthton (free from wear or age or error) Cyr. viii. 7. 22.
u(phretou=nta: doing his will.
ta\ me/gista pra/ttwn o(ra=tai: is perceived to be performing his mightiest works. For the supplementary participle with verbs of perceiving, see on zw=nta i. 2. 16.
ta/de: them, i.e. ta\ me/gista, as present before the eyes of the speaker. H. 696 a.
oi)konomw=n: circumstantial participle of time.
a)kribw=s: sharply.
kai/, de/: see on i.1.3.
u(phre/tas: ministers. Cf. ‘ye ministers of his, that do his pleasure’ Ps. ciii. 21.
kerauno/s te: corresponds to kai\ a)/nemos below.
e)piw/n: see on oi)konomw=n 13.
a(\ poiou=si: “their effects.”
a)lla\ mh/n: iam vero.
ei)/per ti kai\ a)/llo: as in iii. 6. 2.
o(ra=tai ou)d' au)th/: for the thought, cf. i.4.9; Cyr. viii. 7. 17, 20.
a(\ xrh/: see on tou\s ta\ toiau=ta i. 1. 9.
tw=n a)ora/twn: neuter.
to\ daimo/nion: here not the daemonium of i. 1. 2, but that which proceeds from the dai/mwn. So in the following section. See on i. 1. 2.
ou)de\ mikro/n: not even in the slightest degree.
e)kei=no a)qumw=: I am discouraged at this. e)kei=no is cognate accusative. See on fronti/zontas ta\ toiau=ta i. 1. 11.
ou)d' a)\n ei(=s: see on i.6.2.
a)\n a)mei/besqai: could requite.
no/mw| po/lews: cf. i.3.1.

a)re/skesqai: to propitiate, usually
intr. except in Homer.—pw=s ou)=n a)/n tis ktl.: cf. ‘behold, to obey is better than sacrifice, and to hearken than the fat of rams’ 1 Sam. xv. 22.

th=s me\n duna/mews u(fi/esqai: for me/n, see on i.1.1. The implied opposite is “we may well, however, fall behind the offerings of our richer neighbors.”—xrh\ ou)=n mhde\n e)llei/ponta ktl.: the sense of the passage is simply “fear and honor God with all your might, and then be of good courage.”
ou) ga\r a)\n e)lpi/zwn (equivalent to ei)/ tis e)lpi/zoi) swfronoi/h: “for no one could reasonably expect.”
ou)d' a)\n a)/llws ma=llon: sc. e)lpi/zwn swfronoi/h.

div2.p: What Socrates thought of integrity (swfrosu/nh peri\ a)nqrw/pous) was sufficiently shown in his life, both private and public. We are here, however, more immediately concerned with his treatment of the subject in his discourses: and this may be learned from a conversation which he once held with the sophist Hippias. He there defines uprightness as obedience: on the one hand, to the laws of the state, on which rest all good order, all prosperity, and all security; on the other, to the unwritten divine laws, which are everywhere a necessary condition of man's social life, and whose violation nature herself punishes.

div3.p: ou)k a)pekru/pteto gnw/mhn: directed at the criticism uttered by Hippias in 9. For the attraction of the antec. into the rel. clause, see on i.2.22.
h(\n ei)=xe: here equivalent to the art. th/n in the unemphatic possessive use.
kai\ e)/rgw|: “in his very actions,” contrasted with kai\ e)/lege de/ in 5.

a)/rxousi/ te peiqo/menos:
corresponds to kai\ o(/te ou)k e)pe/treye in 2. Strict adherence to ‘concinnity’ would require kai\ ou)k e)pitre/pwn, but this would have occasioned an accumulation of participles.
a(\ oi( no/moi prosta/ttoien: in regard to matters which the laws enjoined. For the opt., see on nomi/zoien i. 1. 6.
w(/ste ei)=nai: for the inf., see on w(/ste e)/xein i. 2. 1.
para\ tou\s a)/llous: beyond all others. See on i. 4. 14.

e)n tai=s e)kklhsi/ais ktl.: for the events alluded to, see on i.1.18. e)kklhsi/ais should strictly be sing., as Socrates was e)pista/ths in only one of the two sessions mentioned in Hell. i. 7: but Xenophon is speaking loosely of an affair well known and already described.
para\ tou\s no/mous: cf. i.1.18.
o(rmh=| tou= dh/mou: “a tide of popular feeling.”
h(/n: instead of the more usual oi(/an after toiau/th|.
toi=s te ga\r ne/ois ktl.: cf. i.2.35. Note the difference between the impf. a)pagoreuo/ntwn (cf. mhde\ diale/gou i. 2. 35) and the aor. prostaca/ntwn.

a)gagei=n tina ktl.: Leon, a rich citizen, had fled to Salamis to escape death at the hands of the Thirty. Socrates, with four other citizens, was commanded to proceed to Salamis and arrest Leon: the others obeyed, but Socrates resolutely refused. Cf. Hell. ii. 3. 39; Plato Apol. 32C.
e)pi\ qana/tw|: to put him to death, see on e)f' oi(=s i. 3. 11.
*melh/tou: i.e. the chief accuser. See Introd. § 5.

grafh\n e)/feuge: was prosecuted, hence with u(po/. The active meaning is expressed by diw/kein. G. 1241; H. 820. Cf. mh/ pws e)gw\ u(po\ *melh/tou tosau/tas di/kas fu/goimi Plato Apol. 19C.—tw=n a)/llwn ei)wqo/twn ktl.: these appeals to sympathy were a
common device in the courts of Athens. Socrates regarded such entreaties, though not formally prohibited by law, as in themselves para\ tou\s no/mous, and refused to use them. Cf. Plato Apol. 38D, E.
a)lla\ r(a|di/ws a)\n a)feqei/s: but although he would have been readily acquitted. For the participle with a)/n, representing the same tense of the indic., see G. 1308, 2; H. 987 b.
e)mme/nwn, paranomw=n: see on sth/santas i. 1. 9.
ou(/tws: in this strain.

*(ippi/an: Hippias of Elis was one of the most famous sophists of his day, and was very popular as a teacher of rhetoric, although his charges were as high as those of Protagoras (see on i.2.5). He is a frequent figure in the Platonic dialogues, where he appears to better advantage than here.
dia\ xro/nou: as in ii. 8. 1.
parege/neto: happened upon.
dida/casqai/ tina: to have any one trained. For the causative mid., see G. 1245; H. 815.

dikai/ous: applied to persons or things that are as they should be (comme il faut); and especially appropriate here, the discussion being on dikaiosu/nh. Cf. ou)/te ga\r a(/rma ge/noit' a)\n di/kaion a)di/kwn (i(/ppwn) sunezeugme/nwn Cyr. ii. 2. 26.
tw=n didaco/ntwn: const. like tw=n a)poluso/ntwn ii. 1. 5.

w(/sper e)piskw/ptwn: as mocking, with the accusative. For the intr. use of the verb, cf. i.3.7.—e)/ti ga\r su\ ktl.: for ga/r, see on i.3.10, and for the thought, cf. w(s a)ei\ tau)ta\ le/geis, w)= *sw/krates. *ou) mo/non ge, w)= *kalli/kleis, a)lla\ kai\ peri\ tw=n au)tw=n Plato Gorg. 490 E. Cf., also, i. 2. 37.
dia\ to\ polumaqh\s ei)=nai: by reason of your being widely learned. For the case of the pred. adj., see on au)to/s ii. 3. 11.
a)me/lei: as in i. 4. 7.
po/teron: sc. some alternative question like h)\ mh/ (or h)\ a)ei\) tau)ta\ le/geis, since the sent. h)\ ... a)pokri/nh| is a new question, not opposed to the first.
oi(=on: velut, for example.
po/sa kai\ poi=a *swkra/tous e)sti/n: how many and what letters are in (the word) Socrates. Cf. Oec. viii. 14.
peri\ a)riqmw=n toi=s e)rwtw=sin: for the position of the art., see on th\n sofi/an tou\s pwlou=ntas i. 6. 13.
peri\ me/n, peri\ me/ntoi: correlative.
w(/sper, kai/: with omission of ou(/tw, as in ii. 2. 2.
nh\ th\n *(/hran: see on i.5.5.
le/geis: “you claim.”

yhfizo/menoi: for the supplementary participle, see on skopou/menos ii. 1. 24.—
o(/pws a)\n a)poleifqei/hn sou ktl.: how I could ever tear myself away from you until I have heard of so great a blessing, since you have discovered it.
pri\n a)pofh/nh|: for pri/n with the subjv., see G. 1471, 2; H. 924.

a)rkei=, o(/ti tw=n a)/llwn katagela=|s: it is enough for you to laugh at the others, implying “you shall not laugh at me.”—e)rwtw=n me\n ktl.: cf. i(/na *swkra/ths to\ ei)wqo\s diapra/chtai, au)to\s me\n mh\ a)pokri/nhtai, a)/llou de\ a)pokrinome/nou lamba/nh| lo/gon kai\ e)le/gxh| Plato Rep. 337 E.
ti/ de/: “how so.”
ou)de/n: in no respect, i.e. never.—ei) de\ mh\ lo/gw| ktl.: “you ask me for words; but suppose I show you deeds.”
ou)d' a)\n ei(=s: as in i. 6. 2; iv. 3. 15.
gnw/mhn, o(/ ti nomi/zeis: cf. a)po/fhnai gnw/mhn o(/ ti soi dokei= An. i.6.9
e)a\n to/de ktl.: if possibly this will please you better. See H. 907, 1016 c. Cf. ske/yai e)a\n kai\ soi\ cundokh=| Plato Phaedo 64 C.
ga/r: as in i. 1. 6.
to\ au)to/: subj. of ei)=nai.
sou=: for a similar ‘prolepsis,’ see on qew=n h)/|sqhtai i. 4. 13.
o(poi=on, poi=on: variation of form without difference in meaning. Cf. o(/pws, pw=s Cyr. i. 6. 43; o(/ ti, ti/ Cyr. vii. 3. 10.
a(\ ... e)gra/yanto: cf. i.2.42 ff.
a)/ra: then.
spoudai=on pra=gma: a thing of any importance.
kai\ ga/r: “why, for that matter.”
dia/foron poiei=n: that you are acting otherwise.
h)/: after dia/foron, as after diafe/rein iii. 7. 7; iii. 11. 14.
proqu/mws: “loyally.”

*lukou=rgon katamema/qhkas, o(/ti ktl.: Lycurgus was the famous lawgiver of Sparta; he is usually assigned to the eighth century B.C., but in reality nothing is known definitely of his date. As to his legislation, Holm (Hist. of Greece, i. 177) believes that ‘it is impossible to distinguish what belongs to Lycurgus, what is early Doric, and what is due to the times after Lycurgus. Only one point seems certain, that the work of Lycurgus was the consolidation of the supreme power of an aristocratic warrior caste.’—ou)de\n dia/foron ktl.: see on iii.5.15, and cf. su\ de\ ou)/te *lakedai/mona proh|rou= ou)/te *krh/thn, a(\s dh\ e(ka/stote fh\|s eu)nomei=sqai Plato Crito 52 E.
a)/rista dia/gei: “is most flourishing.”
The thought of the passage is, that harmony, which is considered the greatest good of a state, is the result of obedience to the laws.
tou\s au)tou\s xorou\s kri/nwsin: decide on the same choruses, sc. as prize winners. So ai(rw=ntai just below.
ou)d' i(/na: “and, in general, not that.”
ti/ni d' a)/n tis ma=llon pisteu/seie parakataqe/sqai: “to whom would anybody more confidently intrust.”
tw=n dikai/wn: their rights.

a)noxa/s, sponda/s, sunqh/kas: cognate accs., after the analogy of pisteu/ein pi/stin. Cf. tau=ta de\ ti/s a)\n a)/llw| pisteu/seien h)\ qew=| i. 1. 5. The pisteu/seian below, however, is equivalent to intrust, like pisteu/seie above.
tw=|: for the contr. form, see G. 416, 1; H. 277.
to\ au)to/: as in 12.
a)podei/knumai: affirm.
tou/s g) e)n pa/sh| ktl.: “you mean those which in every land are recognized as in force on the same points.” For nomizome/nous, see on i.1.1.
e)/qento: established for themselves. Note the force of the mid. as contrasted with the act. teqeike/nai and qei=nai following.
pw=s a)/n: sc. oi( a)/nqrwpoi qei=nto.
ou)/te o(mo/fwnoi/ ei)si: nor (granting that they could come together) are they of one speech.
tou\s no/mous tou/tous: obviously repeated for emphasis.
nomi/zetai: i.e. no/mos e)sti/n.
se/bein: ‘the most general expression for religious veneration’ (Classen), in prose a rare substitute for se/besqai. Cf. qeou\s se/boien Ages. i. 27.
ou)ke/ti: as in iii. 4. 10.
ou(=tos (i.e. to\ mh\ mei/gnusqai): attracted into agreement with no/mos. H. 632 a.
ti/ dh/: how so, expresses surprise.
kai\ ga/r: as in 14.
ge/ toi: assuredly.
keime/nous: equivalent to teqeime/nous.
oi( me/n, oi( de/: partitive appos. with e)/nioi.
tou= kakw=s teknopoiei=sqai: i.e. producing imbecile or deformed children.

o(/ti nh\ *di/a ktl.: Hugo Grotius, the famous writer on international law, in his treatise De jure belli ac pacis expresses surprise at Socrates for condemning incestuous marriages on the ground only of disparity of age. But it has been well observed (by Winans) that Socrates is only attempting to set forth the physiological reason for the fact mentioned in 22.
dh=lon o(/ti, e)/fh: as in iii. 7. 1.
spoudai=a: vigorous.
ou(/tw: i.e. by such intermarriages.
ga\r ou)=n: see on iii.3.2.
parabai/netai de/: without a preceding me/n, a forcible opposition.

diw/kein: to seek the company of,
as in ii. 8. 6.—dia\ de\ to\ lusitelei=n ktl.: yet on account of the special advantage of associating with such men, they constantly seek their company.

qeoi=s tau=ta pa/nta e)/oike: all that seems very much like gods, by which Hippias confirms what he has already (19) in general admitted. The comparison is a condensed one (comparatio compendiaria); i.e. with the gods instead of with their works. See on pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous iii. 5. 4, and cf. o(moi/an tai=s dou/lais ei)=xe th\n e)sqh=ta Cyr. v. 1. 4.
to\ tou\s no/mous ta\s timwri/as e)/xein: the fact that the laws carry with them their own penalties.
a)/lla tw=n dikai/wn: “something different from righteousness.” For the gen. of distinction, see on o(dou= ii. 3. 16.

sxolh=|: as in iii. 14. 3.—kai\ toi=s qeoi=s ktl.: correlative to the thought of 18, which is here taken up and extended. In 18, men agree that to\ au)to\ no/mimo/n te kai\ di/kaio/n e)sti, and here the gods too hold the same opinion.
tou\s plhsia/zontas: i.e. not only Hippias, but the circle of Socrates's friends, who eagerly listened to this and similar discussions.

div2.p: Closely connected with eu)se/beia and dikaiosu/nh, which should form the foundations of human training, is e)gkra/teia (self-mastery), which alone enables a man to keep a practical grasp of life. Self-mastery enables a man not only to work successfully but also to enjoy thoroughly all true pleasures.

div3.p:
e)gkra/teian u(pa/rxein a)gaqo\n ei)=nai: it was a good thing for self-control to belong to. e)gkra/teian u(pa/rxein
is subj. of ei)=nai.
ma/lista pa/ntwn: above all men, belongs to the subj., while pa/ntwn ma/lista below is equivalent to above everything, and is connected with e)gkra/teian.
a)ei\ me\n ou)=n ktl.: “he both himself always kept in mind the things conducive to virtue.” Const. peri/ with memnhme/nos, and for the participle with diatele/w, see on iv.2.4.
kth=ma e)leuqeri/an: note the emphatic juxtaposition of this pred. and subject.
oi(=o/n te/ ge: see on iv.2.11.
ma/lista: sc. kalo\n kai\ megalei=on.
tw=n dia\ tou= sw/matos h(donw=n: see on i.5.6.
h(/kista: “far from it.”
e)leuqe/rion: pred., fitting a freeman.
ei)=ta: see on ii.2.14.
tou\s kwlu/sontas: for tou/s with the fut. participle, see on tou\s ta/contas iii. 4. 4.
poiei=n: for the inf. with verbs of hindering, see on poreu/esqai i. 6. 6.
ei)ko/tws: naturally.
ou)de\n h(=tton h)/: just as much as.
tau=ta, e)kei=na: sc. poiei=n. But cf. ta\ ka/kista a)nagka/zontas in 5, and see on fronti/zontas i. 1. 11.
poi/ous tina/s: see on toia/de tis i. 1. 1.
h(gh=|: sc. ei)=nai.
para/: lit. with, at the house of; here (to follow Eng. idiom), under.
doulei/an douleu/ousin: suffer slavery. For the cognate acc., see on a)gw=nas e)ni/kwn ii. 6. 26.
sofi/an, to\ me/giston a)gaqo/n: for the views of Socrates on the summum bonum, see Introd. § 19.— h)\ ou) dokei= soi ktl.: const. h)\ ou) dokei= soi (h( a)krasi/a) kwlu/ein kai\ poiei=n.
prose/xein toi=s w)felou=si: from attending to useful things.
ai)sqanome/nous: even when they have a perception.
e)kplh/casa: by bewildering them. Cf. e)ci/sthsin i. 3. 12.
swfrosu/nhs ti/ni h(=tton prosh/kein: who has a less share of discretion? For the gen. with verbs of sharing, see G. 1097, 2; H. 737.
au)ta\ ta\ e)nanti/a: pred., the direct opposites (of each other).
tou= e)pimelei=sqai: objective gen. with kwlutikw/teron.
w(=n prosh/kei: “duties.”
tou= poiou=ntos, pei/qontos, a)nagka/zontos: for the participle used substantively, see on to\ kratou=n i. 2. 43.

toi=s swfronou=si ta\ e)nanti/a: the opposite of what prudent men do.
For the condensed form of expression, see on qeoi=s tau=ta pa/nta e)/oike iv. 4. 24.
oi)/ei ti: the ti\ shows that the preceding participles are neuter.
ou)kou=n ktl.: const. ou)kou=n ei)ko\s (e)sti\) th\n e)gkra/teian ai)ti/an ei)=nai tw=n e)nanti/wn h)\ th\n a)krasi/an.
tw=n e)nanti/wn h)/: of the opposite of what.
a)/riston: for the gender, see on xrhsimw/teron ii. 3. 1.

o(/ti kai\ e)pi\ ta\ h(de/a ktl.: that even to those pleasures to which alone intemperance seems to lead men, it really cannot lead them. a)krasi/a is lack of self-control, the exact opposite of e)gkra/teia.
pw=s: how so?
w(/sper: inasmuch as.
e)/stin: it is possible.
perimei/nantas, a)nasxome/nous: circumstantial participles of manner, explaining karterei=n, and belonging to its subj. (sc. a)nqrw/pous).
w(s e)/ni h(/dista: see on iii.8.4. From ou)k e)w=sa to ge/nhtai may be regarded as a parenthesis explanatory of kwlu/ei.
toi=s a)nagkaiota/tois te kai\ sunexesta/tois: the most natural and most continuous pleasures.
h(/desqai a)ci/ws mnh/mhs: to have any pleasure worth recalling.
a)lla\ mh/n: see on i.1.6.
tou= maqei=n, tou= e)pimelhqh=nai: gens. of source with a)polau/ousi. G. 1130; H. 750.
pra/ttontes au)ta/: “in the very act of practicing them” (sc. to\ maqei=n kai\ to\ e)pimelei=sqai).
prosh/kein: as in 7.
katexome/nw| e)pi\ tw=| spouda/zein peri/: “wholly occupied in the pursuit of.”
ta\s e)gguta/tw h(dona/s: i.e. pleasures of the moment. Cf. ai( e)k tou= paraxrh=ma h(donai/ ii. 1. 20.
h(/ttoni tw=n h(donw=n: under subjection to the pleasures. Cf. h(/ttw gastro/s i. 5. 1.
ti/ ga/r: (sc. quite right,) for in what respect.
a)lla/: atqui.
ou(/tws: i.e. by self-control, and that discretion which carefully distinguishes the good from the bad, and cherishes it.

diale/gesqai,
diale/gontas: in the act. form, this verb means to pick out, select; diale/gesqai is to converse, then, specifically, “to arrive at truth by discussion.” For the lofty estimate placed on ‘dialectic’ by Plato, cf. a)=r' ou)=n dokei= soi, e)/fhn e)gw/, w(/sper qrigko\s (a coping stone) toi=s maqh/masin h( dialektikh\ h(mi=n e)pa/nw kei=sqai, kai\ ou)ke/t' a)/llo tou/tou ma/qhma a)nwte/rw o)rqw=s a)\n e)piti/qesqai, a)ll) e)/xein h)/dh te/los ta\ tw=n maqhma/twn; *)/emoig), e)/fh Rep. 534 E.

div2.p: An exposition of the Socratic method of discussion, the aim of which was always to arrive at the real essence of things through an accurate analysis of concepts. Xenophon gives his definition of the following: eu)se/beia (piety), dikaiosu/nh (righteousness), sofi/a (wisdom), to\ a)gaqo/n and to\ kalo/n (the good and the beautiful), a)ndrei/a (manliness), basilei/a (royalty), turanni/s (autocracy), a)ristokrati/a (aristocracy), ploutokrati/a (plutocracy), dhmokrati/a (democracy). In case of contradiction, Socrates knew how to bring the question back to the fundamental conception of the point at issue; and based his discussion on generally recognized truths.

div3.p: dialektikwte/rous: see on iv.5.12.
w(=n e(/neka: wherefore.
skopw=n: supplementary participle with e)/lhge.
diwri/zeto: cf. o(ri/sate i. 2. 35.
to\n tro/pon: his method.
w(=de/ pws, poi=o/n ti: see on toia/de tis i. 1. 1.
kai\ o(/s: for the rel. as dem., see on i.4.3.
ou) ga\r ou)=n: see on iv.4.23.
ta\ no/mima: “what is required by the law.”
h(mi=n: as in iv. 2. 14.
a)nqrw/pois: placed first, as being the contrast word between this question and the one at the end of 2.
a)llh/lois xrh=sqai: “to act towards one another.”—In this and the following section, we see again Socrates's assumption that he who knows the right will do it. See on iv. 2. 20.

oi)=das: cf. oi)/dasin Oec. xx. 14, oi)/damen An. ii.4.6, Ionic forms rare in Attic. Cf. ei)=pa ii. 2. 8. Xenophon's use of these forms may be explained by his long residence among non-Attic Greeks.—o)rqw=s ktl.: cf. the conclusion reached in 4.
pote/: “finally,” after this long discussion. Cf. mo/gis ou)=n pote h(mi=n a(/nqrwpos a)ne/w|ce th\n qu/ran Plato Prot. 314 E.
sofi/an: see on i.2.23.
a(\ e)pi/stantai, tau=ta: in regard to these things which they know.
h)\ w(=| sofoi/ ei)sin: than that by which they (sc. a)/nqrwpoi, implied by the previous ti\s) are wise.
ta\ o)/nta pa/nta e)pi/stasqai: cf. Lord Bacon's saying that he had ‘taken all knowledge for his province.’
ou)de\ pollosto/n: see on iii.1.6.
ou(/tw: i.e. so that to\ a)gaqo/n, like sofo/s, will prove to be a term of relative application.
to\ a)/llw| w)fe/limon (sc. o)\n) ktl.: “one man's meat is another man's poison.” The ‘good’ of which Socrates here speaks must be understood as practical advantage, not as the highest ideal good.
a)/llws: otherwise, sc. than as to\ a)gaqo/n was defined in 8, i.e. relatively.
h)/: “or possibly.”
pro\s tou=to e(ka/stw| kalw=s e)/xei xrh=sqai: it is well to use each thing to that end (for which it is useful).

a)ndrei/an: see on i.1.16; iii. 9. 1. Plato discusses the term a)ndrei/a in his Protagoras and Laches, Socrates being the chief speaker, as here, and the line of argument being the same. Cf. tau/thn (th\n a)ndrei/an fhmi\ ei)=nai) e)/gwge th\n tw=n deinw=n kai\ qarrale/wn e)pisth/mhn kai\ e)n pole/mw| kai\ e)n toi=s a)/llois a(/pasin Laches 195 A, a definition given as by Nicias, but claimed by him to proceed from Socrates.
me\n ou)=n: “much rather.”
ou): belongs to pro\s ta\ e)la/xista, hence the following nh\ *di/a is assuredly. Similarly ou)k with a)ndrei=oi in line 87.
oi( ta\ mh\ deina\ dedoiko/tes: cf. tou\s me\n ou)de\ ta\ deina\ dedie/nai, tou\s de\ kai\ ta\ mh\ fobera\ fobei=sqai i. 1. 14.
e)/ti h(=tton: sc. a)ndrei=oi.
kakou/s: sc. pro\s ta\ deina\ kai\ e)piki/nduna o)/ntas.
a)lla/: “only.”
oi(/ous xrh=sqai: equivalent to toiou/tous w(/ste xrh=sqai. See on i. 4. 6.
ou(=toi: as in 6.
mo/noi: they only.
oi( mh\ dihmarthko/tes: who have made no failure.
oi( diamarta/nontes tou/tou: those who fail utterly of this. For the gen. with verbs of missing, see G. 1099; H. 748.
a)rxa/s: forms of government.
a)nqrw/pwn, po/lewn: objective gen. with a)rxh/n.
kata\ no/mous: cf. i.2.41 ff.; iv. 4. 13.
tw=n ta\ no/mima e)pitelou/ntwn: those who discharged the obligations imposed by law, a very different meaning from that involved in the modern word ‘aristocracy.’
e)k timhma/twn: on the basis of property valuations.
h)/toi, h)/: see on iii.12.2.
sofw/teron (sc. tina\) ei)=nai o(\n au)to\s le/goi: sc. h)\ o(\n *swkra/ths le/goi.
e)pi\ th\n u(po/qesin: “to the fundamental question,” i.e. to the essential meaning of the quality under discussion.
e)panh=gen a)/n: for the iterative indic. with a)/n, see on e)/fh a)/n iv. 1. 2.
w(=de/ pws: the narrative now passes from general (peri/ tou) to particular cases.
fhmi\ ga\r ou)=n: cf. e)/sti ga\r ou)=n iii. 3. 2.
ti/ ou)=n ou)k e)peskeya/meqa: for the tense, see on iii.11.15.
xrhma/twn: “finances.”
kratoi/h (equivalent to krei/ttwn ei)/h): with reference to a)gaqou= poli/tou.

kaquperte/ran: sc. th\n po/lin
poiw=n.
e)panagome/nwn: sc. e)pi\ th\n u(po/qesin.
o(po/te dieci/oi: for the mode, see on diomologh/saito i. 2. 57.

dia\ tw=n ma/lista o(mologoume/nwn e)poreu/eto: “he proceeded from propositions generally admitted as true.” Cf. a)/rti ga\r dh\ katamanqa/nw, h(=| me e)phrw/thsas e(/kasta: a)/gwn ga/r me di) w(=n e)gw\ e)pi/stamai, a)napei/qeis Oec. xix. 15.
tau/thn th\n a)sfa/leian ei)=nai lo/gou: that this was the truly safe method of reasoning.
toigarou=n: and so it was, that. Cf. the use of this particle in An. i. 9.
w(=n e)gw\ oi)=da: equivalent to tou/twn ou(\s oi)=da.

*(/omhron: cf. Hom. q 171, where Odysseus, apparently describing himself, says o( d' a)sfale/ws a)goreu/ei. Cf., also, kai\ *(/omhros d' ei)=pe: o( d) a)sfale/ws a)goreu/ei: th=| a)podei/cei tw=n o(mologoume/nwn a)mfisbhtou/menon lu/ein duna/menos (being able to solve a vexed problem by his luminous statement of generally admitted propositions). tou=to kai\ *cenofw=n kai\ *pla/twn le/gousi peri\ *swkra/tous, o(/ti dia\ tw=n o(mologoume/nwn e)poreu/eto, e)pei\ dida/skein e)bou/leto Dionys. Hal. de Arte Rhet. xi. 8.
a)naqei=nai to\ ei)=nai: “conferred the title.”
w(s i(kano\n o)/nta: we might expect i(kanw=| o)/nti, to agree with *)odussei=. The acc. is due to the attraction of the nearer r(h/tora.
dia\ tw=n dokou/ntwn toi=s a)nqrw/pois: repeats dia\ tw=n o(mologoume/nwn above.

div2.p: Socrates also desired for his friends an acquaintance with certain branches of practical knowledge; but urged them to observe moderation even in these. Geometry, astronomy, and arithmetic are to be studied only so far as they will subserve some useful purpose in life; and we should not be diverted by them from other more needful things. Health should always be carefully conserved. Whatever cannot be solved by human insight should be referred to the gods for advice.
This chapter forms a sequel to i. 1. 6-9.

div3.p: o(/ti me\n ou)=n a(plw=s ktl.: cf. a(plou/stata e)chgei=to iv. 2. 40.
au)tou\s ei)=nai e)pemelei=to: “strove to have them,” a rare const. with e)pimele/omai, instead of o(/pws ei)=en or e)/sontai, or tou= ei)=nai.
w(=n de\ ei)de/nai: equivalent to tou/twn de\ a(\ ei)de/nai.
h)=gen (sc. peri\ tou/twn): “in regard to these matters he directed them.”
me/xri o(/tou: quo usque.
au)ti/ka: for example; a peculiar use of the adv., perhaps a condensed expression for au)ti/ka le/cw I will at once mention. Cf. Plato Prot. 359 E; Rep. 420 c.
e)/rgon a)podei/casqai: “to prove the correctness of a calculation in land surveying.”
a)pie/nai: see on poiw=n i. 2. 61. Cf. the Lat. discedere victorem.
dussune/twn: hard to comprehend.
ou)k a)/peiro/s ge au)tw=n h)=n: see on *qeo/dwros iv. 2. 10. In the Clouds, Aristophanes represents geometry as being taught in the school of Socrates.
i(kana/: “calculated.”
a)strologi/as: does not differ from a)stronomi/as. Cf. iv.2.10.
kai\ tau/ths me/ntoi: and yet this too (like geometry).
me/xri tou= du/nasqai: so far as to be able.
w(/ran: with nukto/s, equivalent to hour; with mhno/s, equivalent to day; with e)niautou=, equivalent to season or month.
nukto/s (with pra/ttetai): for the gen. of time, see on a)gora=s i. 1. 10.
tekmhri/ois: as signs, sc., as obj. of xrh=sqai, the observed facts of a)strologi/a.
tw=n ei)rhme/nwn: i.e. nukto/s, mhno/s, e)niautou=.
to\ manqa/nein: obj. of a)pe/trepen.
me/xri tou= ktl.: in appos. with me/xri tou/tou, with emphatic repetition of the me/xri.
kai/ (in line 31): even.

ta\ mh\ e)n th=| au)th=| perifora=|: i.e. planets, comets, etc., having motions in a different plane from the general apparent movement of the stars; cf. the ‘cycle and epicycle, orb in orb’ of Raphael's speech to Adam in Milton's Paradise Lost, viii. 84.
pla/nhtas: planets, lit. wanderers.
a)staqmh/tous a)ste/ras: prob. comets, as having no apparent fixed place.
zhtou=ntas katatri/besqai: to wear ourselves out investigating. For the supplementary participle, see G. 1580; H. 983.
i)sxurw=s a)pe/trepen: he strongly dissuaded from.
ou)de\ tou/twn a)nh/koos h)=n: Archelaus, a pupil of Anaxagoras, is said to have taught Socrates astronomy.
i(kana/: as in 3.
ou)rani/wn: objective gen. with frontisth/n. Obs. the ‘prolepsis.’
o( qeo/s: but qeoi=s without the art. just below. See on iv. 3. 13.
tau=ta merimnw=nta: see on fronti/zontas ta\ toiau=ta i. 1. 11.

*)anacago/ras: of Clazom&ebreve;nae, a contemporary of Pericles (about 440 B.C.), famous as a physical philosopher. He taught that the sun was a mass of incandescent matter and that the moon was made of earth. Accused of impiety, he was banished and retired to Lampsacus. Cf. Plato Apol. 26E, where Socrates characterizes as a)/topa these views of Anaxagoras.

to\ au)to\ ei)=nai pu=r te kai\ h(/lion: for te\ kai/, see on iii.4.3. Cf. ou(=tos (*)anacago/ras) e)/lege to\n h(/lion mu/dron ei)=nai dia/puron (was a glowing mass of red-hot metal) kai\ mei/zw th=s *peloponnh/sou Diog. Laert. ii. 8.
h)gno/ei w(s: ignored the fact that.
logismou/s: the art of reckoning, i.e. practical arithmetic.
tou/twn: objective gen. with pragmatei/an.
o(moi/ws toi=s a)/llois: equally with the other subjects.
manqa/nontas: circumstantial participle of manner with e)pimelei=sqai tou\s suno/ntas.
e)nde/xoito: was possible.

e(autw=| e(/kaston prose/xonta: each individual by observing his own case.—ti/ brw=ma ktl.: objs. of manqa/nonta understood.—tou= ga\r ou(/tw ktl.: for he said that it would be a difficult matter to find a physician who could tell better than a man that had thus attended to himself what was conducive to his health. tou= prose/xontos is gen. of comparison with ma=llon, and is placed at the beginning as involving the main question. For the thought, cf. Tiberius solitus erat eludere medicorum artes, atque eos qui post tricesimum aetatis annum ad internoscenda corpori suo utilia vel noxia alieni consilii indigerent (availed themselves of) Tacitus Ann. vi. 46.
shmai/nousi: as in i. 1. 9. The thought serves as an introduction to the concluding chapter.

div2.p: Those who think that, because Socrates suffered the death penalty, his utterances as to the daimo/nion are thereby discredited, are in error. For Socrates did not, like them, regard death as an evil. With tranquillity and even cheerfulness he died a noble and happy death. That he himself was assured of this is shown in his conversation with Hermogenes.
