He refused to adopt the usual form of defense, regarding his life as his best defense; and moreover his daimo/nion warned him against an elaborate speech. He died at the right time, before age had impaired his powers of mind and body; and the reproach of his taking-off lies not on him, but on those who condemned him. All who knew him mourned him sorely; for in Socrates died the noblest and happiest of men.

div3.p: o(/ti fa/skontos au)tou=, kategnw/sqh qa/natos: “because he asserted, and then was condemned to death.”

peri\ tou= daimoni/ou yeudo/menon: inasmuch as, according to his critics, he would have conducted himself differently in regard to appearing at his trial if the daimo/nion had predicted his death to him.
a)xqeino/taton: a poetic word.
th\n dia/noian meiou=ntai: are weakened in intellect. Socrates was over seventy years of age; cf. nu=n e)gw\ prw=ton e)pi\ dikasth/rion a)nabe/bhka, e)/th gegonw\s e(bdomh/konta Plato Apol. 17D.
th\n di/khn ei)pw/n: by pleading his case. di/khn is cognate accusative. Plato's Apology is regarded as a fairly correct report of the speech of Socrates before his judges.

*dh/lia: not to be confused with the o( ei)s *dh=lon pempo/menos xoro/s of iii. 3. 12, which was sent every four years. The *dh/lia here mentioned was a solemn embassy sent annually to Delos with thank offerings to Apollo, in commemoration of the victory of Theseus over the Minotaur, by which Athens was freed from the terrible tribute of seven youths and seven maidens. Cf. Plato Phaedo 58 A.

to\n no/mon e)a=n: also governed by dia/.—
diabiou/s: for second aors. of the -mi form, see G. 799; H. 489, 14.—For the demeanor of Socrates during the last hours in his cell, see the concluding chapters of Plato's Phaedo.
ou(/tws: i.e. eu)qu/mws te kai\ eu)ko/lws.

qeofile/steros: the noble and happy death of Socrates showed that he was beloved of the gods; and it does not follow from his death, either that his daimo/nion deceived him, or that what he had said of the daimo/nion was false. Cf. Plato Apol. 40A—C, 41 D.
*(ermoge/nous: see on ii.10.3.
*melh/tou: see on i.1.1.
gegramme/nou au)to\n to\n grafh/n: for the accs., see G. 1076; H. 725.
pa/nta ma=llon: see on ii.4.1.
le/gein: its subj. is the word with which au)to/s agrees, attracted into the nom. under the usual rule for indirect discourse.
tou=to meletw=n diabebiwke/nai: to have passed my whole life in the preparation of this (my defense).
poiw=n diagege/nhtai: “that all his life he had done,” the participle containing the main idea.
pra/ttwn di/kaia, a)di/kwn a)pexo/menos: obs. the ‘chiasmus.’
au)to/s, ei)pei=n: sc. e)/fh, as in 4.

paraxqe/ntes: persuaded. —
h)nantiw/qh to\ daimo/nion: cf. kai\ di\s h)/dh e)pixeirh/santo/s mou skopei=n peri\ th=s a)pologi/as, e)nantiou=tai/ moi to\ daimo/nion Apol. 4 Cf. also Plato Apol. 31D, 40 A, B.
u(fei/mhn a)/n: I would concede.
bebiwke/nai (sc. au)to/n): that he had lived.
a(/: equivalent to kai\ tau=ta.
pro\s tou\s a)/llous: see on pro\s e(auto/n i. 2. 52.
paraqewrw=n: like paraba/llwn in 11.
ou(/tw diatete/lhka gignw/skwn: I have constantly been of this mind.
ou(/tws e)/xontes peri\ e)mou= diatelou=sin: constantly have this opinion of me.
ou) dia\ to\ filei=n e)me/: not because they love me.
ta\ tou= gh/rws e)pitelei=sqai: to pay the debts of old age, i.e. to suffer the weakening of sight, hearing, and intellect.
o(ra=n, a)kou/ein, dianoei=sqai: with their advs., in appos. with ta\ tou= gh/rws.

a)pobai/nein: to turn out,
“to become.” — mh\ ai)sqanome/nw| ktl.: the thought is “if I should not notice it, that itself would be a proof of dullness, and such a life would be no life; and if I should notice it, life would naturally lose its joy.”

ei) ga\r to\ a)dikei=n ai)sxro/n e)sti ktl.: the thought seems to be, that a wrong act cannot successfully hide behind the forms of law; but the sent. is bracketed by some editt. as meaningless. On the section, cf. Apol. 26.
tw=n te, kai\ tw=n: see on te\ kai/ iii. 4. 3.
e)pimelei/as teu/comai u(po/: I shall enjoy consideration from. See on u(po/ iii. 4. 1.
marturh/sesqai: mid. as passive.

belti/ous de\ poiei=n tou\s e)moi\ suno/ntas: concludes and confirms the propositions laid down in i. 3. 1 and iv. 1. 1, after which the book comes to an end with a brief recapitulation of the contents of the entire work.
*swkra/thn gignwsko/ntwn oi(=os h)=n: for the ‘prolepsis,’ see on i.2.13.
e)moi\ me\n dh/: mihi quidem igitur.
a)/neu gnw/mhs: cf. a)/neu tou/twn (tw=n no/mwn) mhde\n pra/ttein peira=sqe Hell. i. 7. 29.
tou\s xrwme/nous au)tw=|: those who associated with him.
tau=ta: "this my description of the character of Socrates."
pro/s: as in 7.
